"totalArticleCount": 232, "title": {"eng": "Southwest scraps open seating, ending decades long practice"}, "summary": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines (LUV) announced Thursday that it will get rid of open seating in a sweeping change from its decades long practice. Instead, it will begin assigning seats and offer premium, extra leg room seating.\n\nShares of the domestic carrier rose more than 2% in early trading.\n\nSouthwest CEO Bob Jordan said \"our implementation of assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade to the Customer Experience, one that research shows Customers overwhelmingly prefer.\"\n"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Las Vegas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 74}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 77}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Aviation/Multimedia", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Aviation/Multimedia", "wgt": 74}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 85}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 232}, "sentiment": 0.1137254901960785, "breakingScore": 0.5070201405626783}
{"uri": "8243628858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:00:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:00:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:59:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://kicks105.com/ixp/191/p/texas-based-southwest-airlines-is-getting-rid-of-open-seating/", "title": "Texas-Based Southwest Airlines Is Getting Rid Of Open Seating", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline will also start offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights for the first time, which it said will improve efficiency by increasing the use of its aircraft.\n\nSouthwest said customers were clamoring for these changes - when people switch to a competitor from Southwest, the company said the No. 1 reason the unhappy passengers cite is open seating. But the change will also help the company charge some passengers more for their tickets.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest did not give details about when the changes will go into effect, but it said it would be discussed further in September.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" Jordan said in a news release about the changes. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders. We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver.\"\n\nThe airline had announced in April that it was looking at a change in its seating policy that has been in effect for its entire 50-year history. Southwest is under pressure from activist investors who have been pushing for changes in management and growth in profitability.\n\nSouthwest doesn't charge for carry on bags and has long allowed passengers to check two bags for free. The airline also doesn't charge customers to change flights.\n\nThe company made no mention in its statement about whether it will change its baggage or change fee policy. The premium seats, which will offer more legroom, will not be available until 2025 as it will require reconfiguring its planes.\n\nSouthwest used to be the most profitable US airline. But that is no longer the case.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.", "source": {"uri": "kicks105.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KICKS 105"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kelsee_pitman@kicks105.com", "name": "Kelsee Pitman", {"uri": "8243261186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:52:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:52:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:51:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.wxxv25.com/southwest-breaks-with-50-year-tradition-and-will-assign-seats-profit-falls-at-southwest-american/", "title": "Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American - WXXV News 25", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. "https://www.wxxv25.com/content/uploads/2024/07/s/n/southwest.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, {"uri": "8243153887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:39:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:39:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:38:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.orlandosentinel.com/2024/07/25/southwest-seats-orlando-red-ee/", "title": "Southwest Airlines to assign seats, start redeye to Orlando", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to end more than 50 years of tradition and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom. And, it's adding overnight redeye flights, the first of which will come to Orlando.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest Customers, and 86% of potential Customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" Southwest said in a press release. \"When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change. By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nIn addition to assigning seats, Southwest will offer a premium, extended legroom portion of the cabin that research shows many Customers strongly prefer. While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nSouthwest also announced it is adding 24-hour operation capabilities with the introduction of overnight, redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Orlando and Baltimore; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\n\"Southwest plans to phase in additional redeye flying in the carrier's coming schedules as part of its multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation,,\" the airline said. \"Redeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings, enabling Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without incremental aircraft capital deployment.\"\n\nThe Las Vegas-to-Orlando nonstop redeye flight was listed with a 10:50 p.m. departure and a 6:05 a.m. arrival in Orlando on Southwest's website. Seat prices ranged from $254 to $375 as of Thursday morning.\n\nThe change in seating policy comes as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.", "source": {"uri": "orlandosentinel.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Orlando Sentinel"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242996349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:57:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:57:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:56:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/chicago/news/southwest-airlines-ends-open-seating-introduces-redeye-flights/", "title": "Southwest Airlines ends open seating, introduces redeye flights", "body": "The Dallas-based airline announced Thursday it is putting an end to its open seating policy, will begin offering premium seating and is introducing redeye flight options.\n\nThe airline said the changes are the next step in a \"continuing strategic transformation\" and are designed to \"elevate the customer experience.\"\n\nAccording to research conducted by Southwest, 80% of customers and 86% of potential customers said they prefer an assigned seat.\n\nIn addition to assigning seats, Southwest will offer premium, extended legroom portions of plane cabins. One-third of seats will offer the extended option.\n\nSouthwest will sell tickets for redeye flights starting Thursday. The first overnight flights will land on Valentine's Day next year in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. Southwest said it plans to phase in additional redeye flying.\n\nThe announcement came as Southwest reported that its second-quarter profit dropped to $367 million -- down 46% from a year earlier.\n\nAirlines are grappling with reduced pricing power while facing higher costs as flights are being added faster than growth in demand for travel.\n\nRyan Green, previously the executive vice president and chief commercial officer, will take on the new role of executive vice president of commercial transformation to lead the development of the Southwest initiatives.\n\nPresident and CEO of Southwest, Bob Jordan, said the changes are part of \"a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience.\"\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" Jordan said in a news release about the changes. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders. We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver.\"\n\nThese changes come after mounting pressure from Elliott Management to boost profits. The hedge fund has called on the airline to enhance its board of directors, upgrade leadership and take a comprehensive business review.\n\nIn May, the airline began listing airfares on Google Flights, making it easier for travelers to compare their options on a single dashboard.\n\nA Southwest spokesperson said the move, which the carrier said it's testing, broadens its reach with {"uri": "2024-07-433321367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:02:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:02:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:38:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/25/southwest-breaks-with-50-year-tradition-and-will-assign-seats-profit-falls-at-southwest-american/", "title": "Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. {"uri": "8243127494", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:22:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:22:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:21:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.newson6.com/story/66a24cfde8174d41660ef4d7/southwest-airlines-announces-changes-to-seating-policy-adds-overnight-flights", "title": "Southwest Airlines Announces Changes To Seating Policy, Adds Overnight Flights", "body": "Southwest Airlines announced on Thursday the company will soon do away with the existing first-come-first-serve seating policy, opting to transition to assigned seating similar to other airlines.\n\nIn addition to changes to aircraft onboarding, the airline also said they will offer premium seating options, and introduce redeye, or overnight, flights.\n\nAccording to a press release from the airline, Southwest said during its quarterly financial results in April, the airline shared it was studying product preferences and expectations, including onboard seating. As a result of those studies, the company said these new amenities are expected to \"produce additional revenue and strengthen financial performance.\"\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" Southwest Airlines president, CEO and vice chairman of the board Bob Jordan said. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders.\"\n\nIn addition to assigning seats, the airlines new premium seating will offer extended legroom, and while cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest said it expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom.\n\nAs for new overnight flight plans, Southwest said the first overnight flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nSouthwest said it has plans to phase in additional redeye flying in the carrier's coming schedules as part of its multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation.\n\n\"We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver,\" Jordan said. \"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nSouthwest said additional details of the airline's {"uri": "8243709421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:25:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:25:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:24:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://s24806.pcdn.co/southwest-airlines-to-end-open-seating-offer-premium-seat-options-redeye-flights/", "title": "Southwest Airlines to End Open Seating, Offer 'Premium Seat' Options & Redeye Flights", "body": "Big changes are coming for Dallas-based Southwest Airlines and its passengers.\n\nThe company announced several initiatives including moving forward with plans to end open seating by assigning seats, offering premium seating options, and redesigning the carrier's boarding model. Southwest said it will also introduce redeye flights.\n\nThe moves are part of the company's transformation and are intended to elevate the customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive shareholder value, Southwest said.\n\nBob Jordan, Southwest's president, CEO, and vice chairman of the board, called the move to offer assigned seating and additional legroom \"a transformational change\" that impacts almost every aspect of the airline.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" Jordan said in a statement.\n\nHe said that the Southwest team is excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback \"to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver.\"\n\nSouthwest said it continually reviews customer expectations and that during its quarterly financial results in April, it shared that it was studying product preferences and expectations, including onboard seating.\n\nAlong with meeting customer demand, Southwest said the new amenities are expected to produce additional revenue and strengthen financial performance.\n\nJordan added, \"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on customer expectations -- and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nSouthwest said it will provide more details on its plan to deliver transformational commercial initiatives, improved operational efficiency, and capital allocation discipline during its Investor Day in late September.\n\nSouthwest said that after listening to customers and conducting extensive research, it decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights.\n\nSouthwest has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred. The airline also said it conducted \"robust operational testing\" that included live and over 8 million simulation-based boarding trials.\n\nThe airline said that the research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat. It said that when a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number-one reason for the change.\n\nSouthwest said that by moving to an assigned seating model, it expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\n\nThe carrier also said it will offer a premium, extended legroom portion of the cabin that research shows many customers strongly prefer. Specific cabin layout details are still in design, but Southwest said it expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\n\nDuring the past two years, Southwest has enhanced its onboard offerings with improvements such as faster Wi-Fi, in-seat power, and larger overhead bins. In February, Dallas Innovates wrote about Southwest's plans to upgrade cabins with premium seats from a German manufacturer, and offer redesigned cabin interiors and conveniences, new airline employee uniforms, and even new ways to prop up your mobile phone or tablet.\n\nSouthwest said that work is underway on a refreshed cabin design, including new, more comfortable RECARO seats.\n\nSouthwest also announced it is adding 24-hour operation capabilities with the introduction of overnight, redeye flights. Booking on initial routes is available through Southwest.com, with the first overnight flights landing on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nSouthwest said it intends to phase in more redeye flying in the carrier's coming schedules as part of its multiyear transformation to a 24-hour operation. The airline said redeye flying, along with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings, enabling Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without incremental aircraft capital deployment.\n\nRyan Green, previously executive vice president, & chief commercial officer, will take on the new role of EVP Commercial Transformation, leading development and rollout of these and other commercial initiatives already underway. Green currently leads the work on cabin transformation.\n\nPreviously, Green directed efforts to transform Southwest Airlines' Rapid Rewards loyalty program and the digital customer experience. He reports to Jordan in his new role.\n\nGreen said that he is eager to lead this step in the airline's transformation to better serve its customers.\n\n\"In addition to meeting the evolving needs of customers and fostering more loyalty, these changes are expected to generate additional revenue as we capitalize on greater demand for Southwest Airlines and offer customers the ability to purchase premium seating options,\" Green said in a statement. \"Together, these strategic initiatives play an integral role in the airline's comprehensive strategy to meet customer needs and enhance Shareholder value, while maintaining the unique culture, hospitality, and flexibility that make Southwest Southwest.\"\n\nThe company said it will share more details about product designs, cabin layout, timing, and incremental financial value at its Investor Day in late September.\n\n\"The board fully supports these efforts to usher in a new era for Southwest Airlines, and we have the ultimate confidence in Bob and our leadership team to design and deliver an experience that is unique and true to our Southwest Legacy,\" Executive Chairman Gary Kelly said in a statement.\n\nSign up {"uri": "2024-07-433675851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:10:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:10:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:55:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.azcentral.com/story/travel/airlines/2024/07/25/why-is-southwest-getting-rid-of-open-seating/74543233007/", "title": "Bye, A group. Here are the big changes Southwest Airlines just revealed", "body": "Soon, your seat on a Southwest Airlines flight won't depend on your boarding group.\n\nSouthwest revealed major changes to its boarding policy and flight schedule on Thursday, July 25, including phasing out its longstanding open seating policy in favor of assigned and premium seating.\n\nSouthwest also plans to introduce redeye flights. One of its first redeye flights will be from Phoenix.\n\nThe move comes as Southwest, which operates the second-largest flight capacity at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, is working to improve its profitability and the flying experience. In April, Southwest CEO Bob Jordan told investors in an earnings call that his staff was looking into whether ending open seating would satisfy customers' preferences.\n\nHere's what to know about the end of open seating on Southwest Airlines and what other changes may be coming.\n\nIs Southwest Airlines doing away with open seating?\n\nYes. Southwest will begin assigned seating on all flights in 2025.\n\nIn addition, Southwest will create a premium cabin section with extended-legroom seats. This premium section will encompass about one-third of the available seats.\n\nThe changes won't occur right away because the new cabin layouts require approval from the Federal Aviation Administration, according to Southwest's announcement.\n\nSouthwest will reveal more details about how assigned and premium seats will work and what the cabin layouts will look like during the airline's Investor Day in late September.\n\nWhen reached for comment by The Arizona Republic, Southwest did not say what the premium-seat legroom will be and whether standard legroom would change from the 32-inch average seat pitch in the current cabins.\n\nWhy is Southwest ending open seating?\n\nIt has to do with both customer preference and the airline's profitability.\n\nSouthwest said it conducted extensive research on passengers' seating preferences and found that 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer seat assignments. Customers cited the airline's open seating policy as the No. 1 reason why they chose to fly with a competing airline.\n\n\"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance,\" Jordan said in the airline's announcement.\n\nSouthwest is working to improve its financial position. The airline reported a net loss of $231 million in the first three months of 2024.\n\nThe airline brought in $7.4 billion in operating revenues from April to June 2024, but the $367 million it took in in profits was more than 46% less than its profit during the same period in 2023, according to its second-quarter 2024 financial report.\n\nAirline staff also expect its non-fuel operating costs, which include employees' salaries and aircraft maintenance, will increase around 11% to 13% in the next three months.\n\nWhat is open seating on Southwest Airlines?\n\nOn a flight with open seating, passengers don't have assigned seats.\n\nWhere they sit largely depends on their place in the boarding queue: Those boarding in Group A get the best choice of seats. After Group B, those who board in Group C usually are limited to middle seats and little to no overhead space for carry-ons.\n\nSouthwest's open seating policy was introduced with the airline's founding in 1971. Back then, the seating was first come, first served. The boarding groups began after a 2006 experiment with assigned seating revealed customers' frustrations with the first come, first served approach.\n\nDoes Southwest do redeyes?\n\nBesides ending open seating, Southwest announced Thursday that it would begin offering redeye flights that leave at night and arrive the next morning.\n\nSouthwest's first redeyes include a nonstop Phoenix-Baltimore flight, which will begin flying on Feb. 13, 2025. The flight leaves Sky Harbor at 11:05 p.m. Arizona time and arrives in Baltimore at 5:10 p.m. Eastern time. We found fares from $236 one way, comparable to or slightly cheaper than other Southwest fares between the two cities.\n\nSouthwest will introduce four other redeye routes in February 2025 -- Las Vegas-Baltimore, Las Vegas-Orlando, Los Angeles-Baltimore and Los Angeles-Nashville -- with more possible in the future.\n\nWill Southwest change its Bags Fly Free policy?\n\nSome travel industry analysts, such as Steve and Paul Glenn of the Nebraska-based travel management company Executive Travel, speculate that Southwest will eventually change its checked bag policy.\n\nRight now, the airline allows each passenger to check their first two bags for free -- a sharp contrast from competitors such as American Airlines, which recently changed its baggage policy to charge $40 for the first checked bag.\n\nThe Glenns forecasted in a June podcast that Southwest would reduce that to one free checked bag if its profitability doesn't improve.\n\nWhen asked by The Republic if Southwest would change its baggage policy, a Southwest spokesperson said, \"No additional changes forthcoming at this time.\"", "source": {"uri": "azcentral.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AZ Central"}, {"uri": "8243822114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:50:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:50:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:49:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/southwest-airlines-gets-rid-open-234100404.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines gets rid of open seating model", "body": "Jul. 25 -- Dallas-based Southwest Airlines announced the end of its open seating model, one of the airline's most unique policies.\n\nFor more than 50 years, Southwest has been known for open seats on its aircraft but now will lean into models for seating like its competitors. According to the airline, Southwest conducted research, and 8 million simulation-based boarding trials.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Bob Jordan, CEO of Southwest in a release. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders.\"\n\nSouthwest's research found 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. When customers choose a different airline, the open seating policy is the No. 1 reason cited for the change, Southwest reported.\n\nThe airline will also add premium, extended legroom to the cabin. Details of how the aircrafts' cabins will change are still in the design phase, but Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, the same as its narrowbody aircraft competitors.\n\nJordan also said financial results for the second quarter were \"impacted by both external and internal factors.\" Southwest had previously lowered its financial expectations for the quarter and reported a $7.4 billion operating revenue for the quarter, a 4.5% increase from the previous year. Unit revenue was slightly better than the company's previous expectation of up to 4.5% for the quarter, which Southwest attributed to the final days of June and \"the resulting benefit from incremental bookings from other carrier cancellations.\"\n\nSouthwest also announced the addition of red-eye flights. The flights will begin on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nOvernight flights at Southwest were rumored to begin in the next few years, but were rolled out ahead of expectations from leaders. Southwest will phase in additional redeye flying in its upcoming schedules as part of its \"multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation,\" the airline reported. It expects to provide incremental revenue and cost savings.\n\nThe changes come as activist investor Elliott Investment Management has called on Southwest to make dramatic alterations to the airline's business model to generate a return for shareholders. Elliott has disclosed a $1.9 billion stake in the air carrier.", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! Finance"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8243181177", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:58:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:58:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:58:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/southwest-breaks-with-50-year-tradition-and-will-assign-seats-profit-falls-at-southwest-american/", "title": "Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-07-433756529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:08:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:08:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:51:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://eu.enterprisenews.com/story/regional/massachusetts/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-is-ending-open-seating-heres-what-to-know-boston-logan-tf-green/74539229007/", "title": "Southwest Airlines is ending its open seating policy. Here's what to know", "body": "After more than 50 years, Southwest Airlines is getting rid of its unique open seating model and will now assign seats.\n\nIf you've ever flown on Southwest Airlines, you've probably experienced a mad dash to board because of the company's open seating policy.\n\nPretty soon, that process will be over; for the first time, Southwest will be offering assigned seating on all flights, the airline announced Thursday.\n\nHere's what to know about Southwest's new assigned seating policy, as well as other major changes to the airline's offerings.\n\nSouthwest ends open seating policy\n\nSouthwest has always used an open seating model for its flights, historically making it the only major airline not to give passengers assigned seats before boarding.\n\nThe airline's existing open seating policy gives passengers an assigned group and number on the day of the flight to determine the order in which they can board and find an available seat.\n\nSouthwest offers service across New England, with flights out of Boston's Logan International Airport, T.F. Green International Airport in Rhode Island, Manchester-Boston Regional Airport in New Hampshire and Bradley International Airport in Connecticut.\n\nWhen will Southwest's assigned seating start?\n\nSouthwest did not say when the new assigned seating policy will start, but the company said it will provide more details in September.\n\nWhy is Southwest adding assigned seating on its flights?\n\nThe airline said it decided to change in its open seating policy after doing research on customer preferences.\n\nSouthwest said its research found that 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. It also found open seating was the top reason customers chose other airlines over Southwest.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" said Bob Jordan, Southwest's President and CEO, in the announcement.\n\nSouthwest to offer extra legroom seats, overnight flights\n\nIn addition to its new assigned seating policy, Southwest announced it would be offering premium legroom seats on all flights. New cabin designs and renovations are ongoing, it said\n\nThe company is also launching overnight redeye flights beginning in February 2025.\n\nRedeye flights are currently on sale from Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore, and Nashville and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nSouthwest said it is planning to add more overnight flights in the future.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243329605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:41:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:41:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:40:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.12onyourside.com/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-offer-assigned-seating-new-boarding-procedures-breaking-with-50-year-tradition/", "title": "Southwest Airlines to offer assigned seating and new boarding procedures, breaking with 50-year tradition", "body": "(AP) - Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. {"uri": "8243219886", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:24:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:24:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:23:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://dothaneagle.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_ab089d5d-734a-571d-a502-6ae7ae1c5261.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees Need to get away?\n\nStart exploring magnificent places with our weekly travel newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site {"uri": "8242892562", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:54:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:54:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:53:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.nbcboston.com/news/business/money-report/southwest-to-get-rid-of-open-seating-offer-extra-legroom-in-biggest-shift-in-its-history/3437853/", "title": "Southwest to get rid of open seating, offer extra legroom in biggest shift in its history", "body": "Southwest expects to start selling seats with the new cabin option next year.\n\nSouthwest Airlines is ending open seating and will offer extra legroom seats on its airplanes as mounting pressure on the carrier to increase revenue prompts the biggest changes to its business model in its 53 years of flying.\n\nThe airline plans to start selling the first flights that will offer extra legroom next year, it said Thursday. The airline also plans to start overnight flights, starting in February.\n\nSouthwest executives have said for years that they were studying such changes and hinted in April that it was seriously considering assigning seats and offering pricier seats with more legroom. The airline currently puts customers in one of three boarding groups and assigns a number, setting off a mad dash to check in a day before the flight. Customers can get earlier boarding though if they pay for a higher-priced ticket, they'll get a better boarding slot.\n\nWhen travelers choose a competitor over Southwest, the airline found in its research that its open seating model was the No. 1 reason for that choice, the carrier said in a release that outlined the changes. It also said 80% of its own customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in a news release Thursday.\n\nThe airline is under even more pressure now to segment its product like other airlines after activist investor Elliott Investment Management disclosed in June a nearly $2 billion stake in the airline and called for new leadership as the airline underperformed competitors.\n\n\"We will adapt as our customers' needs adapt,\" Jordan said at an industry event last month.\n\nSouthwest said it expects about a third of the seats on its Boeing 737s will offer \"extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\" The Federal Aviation Administration would need to approve the cabin layouts, the airline added.\n\nThe Dallas-based airline had prided itself and raked in steady profits for most of its more than five decades of flying on its simple business model. Jordan said last month that not assigning seats was easier to offer when planes weren't so full.\n\nAnalysts criticized Southwest for moving too slowly. Rival carriers offer a host of options to upsell customers like extra legroom seats, premium economy or business class. Other airlines, however, like Delta, United and American, four years ago took a cue from Southwest and ended flight-change fees for most tickets.\n\nSouthwest will provide more details about the upcoming changes at an investor day at the end of September.", "source": {"uri": "nbcboston.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Boston"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://media.nbcboston.com/2024/04/107405249-17138953192024-02-08t232023z_123676527_rc2ly5atu2sj_rtrmadp_0_southwest-results_531dc4.jpeg?quality=85&strip=all&resize=1200%2C675", "originalArticle": {"uri": "8243362134", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:04:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:04:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:04:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://thedailyrecord.com/?p=709487", "title": "Southwest Airlines to start assigning seats, ending 50-year tradition", "body": "Southwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nThe airline said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. Southwest, far and away the dominant carrier at Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport, discovered that preferences have changed over the years and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" Southwest CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nIn addition to the seating switch, Southwest also plans to sell premium seating with more legroom - matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers - and to offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said redeyes will start flying in mid-February on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore, with more routes added over time.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest also faces increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a series of worrisome flights, including one that dove within 400 feet of the ocean off Hawaii, two that flew at extremely low altitudes while still miles from landing at airports in Oklahoma and Florida, and another that was discovered to have rudder-area damage after an unusual \"Dutch roll\" wiggle during a flight.\n\nSouthwest announced the seating move and other changes on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.", "source": {"uri": "thedailyrecord.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Maryland Daily Record"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@thedailyrecord.com", {"uri": "2024-07-433690186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:30:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:30:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:55:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/bye-group-big-changes-southwest-185557815.html", "title": "Bye, A group. Here are the big changes Southwest Airlines just revealed", "body": "Soon, your seat on a Southwest Airlines flight won't depend on your boarding group.\n\nSouthwest revealed major changes to its boarding policy and flight schedule on Thursday, July 25, including phasing out its longstanding open seating policy in favor of assigned and premium seating.\n\nSouthwest also plans to introduce redeye flights. One of its first redeye flights will be from Phoenix.\n\nThe move comes as Southwest, which operates the second-largest flight capacity at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, is working to improve its profitability and the flying experience. In April, Southwest CEO Bob Jordan told investors in an earnings call that his staff was looking into whether ending open seating would satisfy customers' preferences.\n\nHere's what to know about the end of open seating on Southwest Airlines and what other changes may be coming.\n\nIs Southwest Airlines doing away with open seating?\n\nYes. Southwest will begin assigned seating on all flights in 2025.\n\nIn addition, Southwest will create a premium cabin section with extended-legroom seats. This premium section will encompass about one-third of the available seats.\n\nThe changes won't occur right away because the new cabin layouts require approval from the Federal Aviation Administration, according to Southwest's announcement.\n\nSouthwest will reveal more details about how assigned and premium seats will work and what the cabin layouts will look like during the airline's Investor Day in late September.\n\nWhen reached for comment by The Arizona Republic, Southwest did not say what the premium-seat legroom will be and whether standard legroom would change from the 32-inch average seat pitch in the current cabins.\n\nWhy is Southwest ending open seating?\n\nIt has to do with both customer preference and the airline's profitability.\n\nSouthwest said it conducted extensive research on passengers' seating preferences and found that 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer seat assignments. Customers cited the airline's open seating policy as the No. 1 reason why they chose to fly with a competing airline.\n\n\"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance,\" Jordan said in the airline's announcement.\n\nSouthwest is working to improve its financial position. The airline reported a net loss of $231 million in the first three months of 2024.\n\nThe airline brought in $7.4 billion in operating revenues from April to June 2024, but the $367 million it took in in profits was more than 46% less than its profit during the same period in 2023, according to its second-quarter 2024 financial report.\n\nAirline staff also expect its non-fuel operating costs, which include employees' salaries and aircraft maintenance, will increase around 11% to 13% in the next three months.\n\nWhat is open seating on Southwest Airlines?\n\nOn a flight with open seating, passengers don't have assigned seats.\n\nWhere they sit largely depends on their place in the boarding queue: Those boarding in Group A get the best choice of seats. After Group B, those who board in Group C usually are limited to middle seats and little to no overhead space for carry-ons.\n\nSouthwest's open seating policy was introduced with the airline's founding in 1971. Back then, the seating was first come, first served. The boarding groups began after a 2006 experiment with assigned seating revealed customers' frustrations with the first come, first served approach.\n\nDoes Southwest do redeyes?\n\nBesides ending open seating, Southwest announced Thursday that it would begin offering redeye flights that leave at night and arrive the next morning.\n\nSouthwest's first redeyes include a nonstop Phoenix-Baltimore flight, which will begin flying on Feb. 13, 2025. The flight leaves Sky Harbor at 11:05 p.m. Arizona time and arrives in Baltimore at 5:10 p.m. Eastern time. We found fares from $236 one way, comparable to or slightly cheaper than other Southwest fares between the two cities.\n\nSouthwest will introduce four other redeye routes in February 2025 -- Las Vegas-Baltimore, Las Vegas-Orlando, Los Angeles-Baltimore and Los Angeles-Nashville -- with more possible in the future.\n\nWill Southwest change its Bags Fly Free policy?\n\nSome travel industry analysts, such as Steve and Paul Glenn of the Nebraska-based travel management company Executive Travel, speculate that Southwest will eventually change its checked bag policy.\n\nRight now, the airline allows each passenger to check their first two bags for free -- a sharp contrast from competitors such as American Airlines, which recently changed its baggage policy to charge $40 for the first checked bag.\n\nThe Glenns forecasted in a June podcast that Southwest would reduce that to one free checked bag if its profitability doesn't improve.\n\nWhen asked by The Republic if Southwest would change its baggage policy, a Southwest spokesperson said, \"No additional changes forthcoming at this time.\"\n\nMichael Salerno is an award-winning journalist who's covered travel and tourism since 2014. His work as The Arizona Republic's consumer travel reporter aims to help readers navigate the stresses of traveling and get the best value for their money on their vacations. He can be reached at Michael.Salerno@gannett.com. Follow him on X, formerly Twitter: @salerno_phx.\n\nSupport local journalism. {"uri": "2024-07-433448723", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:56:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:56:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:55:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.thenewstribune.com/news/business/article290419379.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines ditches open seating, will move to assigned seats", "body": "July 25 (UPI) -- Southwest Airlines' open seating for flights, a staple of the carrier since its inception, is going away after extensive research with passengers and an opportunity to increase revenue, the company said on Thursday.\n\nSouthwest was unique in allowing passengers to pick their own seats as they boarded the flight, based on when they entered the airplane, where they were separated by zones. The airline said that has worked for them for more than 50 years but admitted it was time for a change.\n\nThe airline will also offer premium seating for higher prices and will present details of a comprehensive plan in late September.\n\n\"After listening carefully to customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all lights,\" Southwest said in a statement. \"Preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest said it found in its research that customers are willing to pay for \"extended legroom\" and it expects that roughly one-third of its seats across the fleet will be able to provide such a service, which will provide a new stream of income.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" Bob Jordan, Southwest's president and CEO, said.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice at the right time for our customers, our people and our shareholders.\"\n\nSouthwest also announced redeye flights as part of its 24-hour operations with initial routes currently available. {"uri": "8243550290", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:41:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:41:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:40:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://gazette.com/southwest-airlines-is-getting-rid-of-open-seating-model-launches-red-eye-flights/article_46c9162d-35dc-5024-b5b4-984f98de2370.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines is getting rid of open seating model, launches red-eye flights", "body": "Dallas-based Southwest Airlines announced the end of its open seating model, one of the airline's most unique policies.\n\nFor over 50 years, Southwest has been known for open seats on its aircraft, but now will lean into models for seating like its competitors. According to the airline, Southwest conducted research and 8 million simulation-based boarding trials. The announcement came ahead of Southwest's earnings call planned for 11:30 a.m. CT on Thursday. More details are expected then and during the company's investor day in late September.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Bob Jordan, CEO of Southwest in a release. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders.\"\n\nSouthwest's research found 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat. When customers choose a different airline, the open seating policy is the No. 1 reason cited for the change, Southwest reported.\n\nThe airline will also add premium, extended legroom to the cabin. Details of how the aircrafts' cabins will change are still in the design phase, but Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, the same as its narrowbody aircraft competitors.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nJordan also said financial results for the second quarter were \"impacted by both external and internal factors.\" Southwest had previously lowered its financial expectations for the quarter and reported a $7.4 billion operating revenue for the quarter, a 4.5% increase from the previous year. Unit revenue was slightly better than the company's previous expectation of up to 4.5% for the quarter, which Southwest attributed to the final days of June and \"the resulting benefit from incremental bookings from other carrier cancellations.\"\n\nSouthwest also announced the addition of red-eye flights. The flights will begin on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nOvernight flights at Southwest were rumored to begin in the next few years, but were rolled out ahead of expectations from leaders. Southwest will phase in additional redeye flying in its upcoming schedules as part of its \"multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation,\" the airline reported. It expects to provide incremental revenue and cost savings.\n\nThe changes come as activist investor Elliott Investment Management has called on Southwest to make dramatic alterations to the airline's business model to generate a return for shareholders. Elliott has disclosed a $1.9 billion stake in the air carrier.\n\n\u00a92024 The Dallas Morning News. {"uri": "2024-07-433500785", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:45:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:45:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:37:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/southwest-airlines-plans-to-start-assigning-seats-breaking-with-a-50-year-tradition/article_dec7af63-c357-5467-8e49-572d4a33bdf4.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats, breaking with a 50-year tradition", "body": "Southwest passengers and airliners line up and move at Love Field in Dallas, Thursday, July 25, 2024. Southwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nDALLAS (AP) -- Goodbye, cattle call.\n\nSouthwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nThe airline said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. Southwest discovered that preferences have changed over the years and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" Southwest CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nIn addition to the seating switch, Southwest also plans to sell premium seating with more legroom - matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers - and to offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said redeyes will start flying in mid-February on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore, with more routes added over time.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest also faces increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a series of worrisome flights, including one that dove within 400 feet of the ocean off Hawaii, two that flew at extremely low altitudes while still miles from landing at airports in Oklahoma and Florida, and another that was discovered to have rudder-area damage after an unusual \"Dutch roll\" wiggle during a flight.\n\nSouthwest announced the seating move and other changes on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nAmerican cut its forecast of full-year earnings to between 70 cents and $1.30 per share, down from a previous prediction of $2.25 to $3.25 per share.\n\nShares of the leading U.S. airlines rose after the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. gained 3% and American Airlines Group Inc., based in Fort Worth, Texas, rose 5% in late-morning trading.
