{"uri": "8243171044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:51:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:51:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:50:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_a526f2db-f64d-536a-8a45-4411d7499fe6.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2014-02-", "textStart": 2868, "textEnd": 2875}], {"uri": "8243323817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:36:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:36:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:36:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/southwest-airlines-plans-to-start-assigning-seats-breaking-with-a-50-year-tradition/", "title": "Southwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats, breaking with a 50-year tradition - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "DALLAS (AP) -- Goodbye, cattle call.\n\nSouthwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nThe airline said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. Southwest discovered that preferences have changed over the years and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" Southwest CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nIn addition to the seating switch, Southwest also plans to sell premium seating with more legroom - matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers - and to offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said redeyes will start flying in mid-February on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore, with more routes added over time.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest also faces increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a series of worrisome flights, including one that dove within 400 feet of the ocean off Hawaii, two that flew at extremely low altitudes while still miles from landing at airports in Oklahoma and Florida, and another that was discovered to have rudder-area damage after an unusual \"Dutch roll\" wiggle during a flight.\n\nSouthwest announced the seating move and other changes on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nAmerican cut its forecast of full-year earnings to between 70 cents and $1.30 per share, down from a previous prediction of $2.25 to $3.25 per share.\n\nShares of the leading U.S. airlines rose after the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. gained 3% and American Airlines Group Inc., based in Fort Worth, Texas, rose 5% in late-morning trading. Delta, United, Alaska and JetBlue also gained.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.\n\nJoin our Newsletter for the latest news right to your inbox Email address Submit", "source": {"uri": "wsvn.com", According to \"robust\" research conducted by Southwest, 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seats. The top reason customers choose another competing airline is because Southwest's open seating concept is unappealing to them, the carrier added.\n\nAn end date to open seating has not yet been announced.\n\nSouthwest will also unveil another new option to all flights: premium seating that offers more legroom for customers.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said in the statement.\n\nSouthwest is also launching redeye, overnight flights beginning Feb. 14, 2025, the airline confirmed in the statement. The five initial nonstop markets will include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nSouthwest touts that these significant changes to {"uri": "8243444450", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:08:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:08:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:07:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://gizmodo.com/southwest-airlines-will-get-assigned-seating-in-2025-2000479014", "title": "Southwest Airlines Will Get Assigned Seating in 2025", "body": "The airline will also start redeye flights on Valentine's Day 2025.\n\nSouthwest Airlines will start selling assigned seats on all its planes next year according to an announcement from the company Thursday. The move is a radical change for an airline that has stood out for having an open seating model during its 53 years in business.\n\n\"After listening carefully to Customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights,\" Southwest said in a statement posted online.\n\nThe Dallas-based carrier wrote that \"preferences have evolved\" and that more customers have been wanting to get assigned seats for longer fights. The company says 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers want assigned seating. Southwest also said that when customers decide not to fly the airline anymore the number one reason cited is that the airline doesn't have assigned seating.\n\nSouthwest also announced Thursday that it was going to offer premium seats which have more legroom, another option that was not available on the airlines previously. The company notes that its research shows passengers really like having the option to upgrade, though that will require changes to the existing fleet of planes.\n\n\"While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft,\" the airline wrote Thursday.\n\nThe company seemed excited about the changes, though there were some folks online who were disappointed that Southwest was going to switch to assigned seats.\n\n\"As a loyal Southwest customer, I hate this. the whole reason I fly southwest is bc it\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s cheap & I can pick my seat!!! If you don\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t like it, fly on a different airline,\" one X user wrote on Thursday.\n\nAnother X user said the change was driven by greed.\n\n\"Southwest Airlines has ended the 'open seating' policy,\" an upset X user tweeted Thursday. \"They will now offer seats for a fees. You will have to pay for good seats. This is end of an era. A beautiful airline destroyed by greed.\"\n\nBut the airline clearly thinks this is all a good idea borne out by research.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" Bob Jordan, the president and CEO of Southwest, said in a statement.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice\u00e2\u20ac\" at the right time\u00e2\u20ac\"for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders. The company said one-third of the seats across Southwest's fleet will have extended legroom but did not offer a timeline for when the new seating policies will be implemented.\n\n\"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations,\" Bob Jordan, president, CEO, & vice chairman of the board, said in a release. \"It will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nSouthwest in its press release Thursday said the move to assigned seating was driven by customer feedback.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest Customers, and 86% of potential Customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" the release said. \"When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change.\"\n\nRedeye, or overnight, flights will also be available and Southwest customers can begin booking those flights today, the company announced. The first redeye flights will land on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial markets, Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nThe new flights are expected to boost revenue and reduce costs, the release states.\n\nIn the company's second-quarter financial report, which was also released Thursday, Southwest \"fell short of what we believe we are capable of delivering,\" Jordan said in the release.\n\nSouthwest brought in a net income of $367 million in the second quarter.\n\nTo implement the changes, Ryan Green, previously executive vice president, & chief commercial officer, will become executive vice president of commercial transformation. {"uri": "2024-07-433298722", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:42:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:42:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:30:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/southwest-breaks-with-50-year-tradition-and-will-assign-seats-profit-falls-at-southwest-american/article_7baeffa2-0fec-56ab-8a99-4a52de1a99e5.html", "title": "Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American", "body": "Southwest Airlines is doing away with a 50-year tradition and plans to start assigning seats\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nMore from this section\n\nPromoting the Value of Drug-Free Living at the UEFA Championship Games\n\nOptimal Blue Launches New Generative AI Assistant Capabilities\n\nMMI Taps Dan Jones as Chief Data Officer as It Expands Data Initiatives and Features", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/kulr8.com/content/tncms/custom/image/ebec0578-57d0-11ee-978f-b7da313020af.jpg?resize=600%2C315", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2014-02-", "textStart": 2791, "textEnd": 2798}], "sentiment": 0.2156862745098038, "wgt": 210, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-433775085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:39:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:39:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:41:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://kdvr.com/news/money/ap-southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/", "title": "Southwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats, breaking with a 50-year tradition", "body": "Southwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nThe airline said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. Southwest discovered that preferences have changed over the years and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" Southwest CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nSome Southwest passengers reacted with sadness and disappointment to news that open seating is going away.\n\n\"Hearing that announcement today, I was like, no, this is my favorite part of Southwest,\" said Lindsey Magness, who works in college athletics in Oklahoma City.\n\nMagness said that with open seating, she can try for a window seat or, depending on her mood, an aisle. And assigned seating doesn't always work either. Magness said American Airlines seated her away from her husband on their honeymoon trip earlier this summer\n\nBrandon Bowser of Odenton, Maryland, said he flies on different airlines based on which one has the best deal, but he has found Southwest's open boarding to be faster and less complicated than other airlines.\n\n\"The convenience that comes with being able to pick your own seat is what sets Southwest apart and makes them sort of a preferred airline,\" he said. \"A lot of my friends swear by Southwest, that's all they will fly, and they are completely irate about this decision.\"\n\nAt Chicago's O'Hare Airport, Kimberly King was happy to learn of the change. She was at a check-in kiosk with her four children for a flight home to California.\n\n\"I used to fly United a lot and I liked the assigned seats, especially with kids, kind of expecting and knowing where we were going to be,\" King said. \"The only reason really why I continue to fly Southwest is for the free bags.\"\n\nSouthwest still lets passengers check two bags for free. It's been a centerpiece of the airline's advertising campaigns for years. CEO Jordan said Southwest has no plans to end bags-fly-free \"at this point.\"\n\nThere are drawbacks to Southwest boarding. It's hard to get a good spot in line without paying an extra fee. Southwest executives said 60% of passengers check in the first 30 seconds. Those who miss the rush fear there won't be room in the overhead bins for their carry-on bag. Late boarders can struggle to see an open seat anywhere, and start roaming up and down the aisle -- Southwest calls them \"spinners.\"\n\nThere are a number of tricks that passengers use to game the system.\n\nSome take advantage of early boarding for people who need extra time. Others ignore the age limit (6 or under) for children in families that are allowed to board right after the \"A\" group. Once on the plane, some passengers hold choice seats for mates who are far behind them in line.\n\nPhotos appear occasionally on social media of an unusually large number of people in wheelchairs at Southwest gates. They get to board early.\n\n\"It's certainly one of the things that anger people even if it doesn't have a material impact on them,\" said Brett Snyder, a travel agent and author of the Cranky Flier blog. \"In some cases those are people who have absolutely legitimate reasons. In other cases, it's the 'Jetway Jesus' phenomenon.\"\n\nThat's a reference to recoveries so miraculous that the disability causing the person to need a wheelchair to reach the gate is cured during flight, and they walk off the plane like everybody else.\n\nSnyder doubts that fans of open seating will abandon Southwest.\n\n\"Those people will still fly Southwest,\" he said. \"They may grumble about it, but there's no one else they can go to that has open seating.\"\n\nIn addition to the boarding change, Southwest also plans to convert about one-third of the seats on its planes to premium seating with more legroom, matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers.\n\nThe airline's newest schedule also includes a few redeye flights -- a first for Southwest.\n\nThe overnight flights will start in mid-February on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. More routes will be added over time, the airline said.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest also faces increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a series of worrisome flights, including one that dove within 400 feet of the ocean off Hawaii, two that flew at extremely low altitudes while still miles from landing at airports in Oklahoma and Florida, and another that was discovered to have rudder-area damage after an unusual \"Dutch roll\" wiggle during a flight.\n\nSouthwest announced the seating move and other changes on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue. Airlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million. CEO Robert Isom said the airline was held back by a sales strategy that it is now rolling back and by an oversupply of domestic flights.\n\nAmerican said its earnings per share in the third quarter will be break-even, well below Wall Street's expectation of 48 cents per share. American also cut its forecast of full-year earnings to between 70 cents and $1.30 per share, down from a previous prediction of $2.25 to $3.25 per share.\n\nShares of the leading U.S. airlines rose Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. gained 5.5% and American Airlines Group Inc., based in Fort Worth, Texas, rose 4%. Delta, United, Alaska and JetBlue also gained.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Wyatte Grantham-Philips in New York and video journalist Teresa Crawford in Chicago contributed to this report.", {"uri": "8243279158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:05:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:05:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:04:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://balleralert.com/profiles/blogs/southwest-airlines-announces-new-assigned-seating-policy-and-redeye-flight-options/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Announces New Assigned Seating Policy And Redeye Flight Options", "body": "Southwest Airlines has just announced a huge change to its seating policy.\n\nOn Thursday, the Dallas-based airline announced that its open seat policy will end and be replaced by premium seating and redeye flight options. Southwest says the changes are part of its ongoing \"strategic transformation\" to improve customer experience.\n\nAccording to the airline, research showed that 80% of its current customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seating instead of having the option to freely select a seat after boarding the plane. As a result, Southwest decided to add premium, extended legroom sections on their planes, with one-third of the seats offering this option.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" President and CEO of Southwest, Bob Jordan, said. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders. We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver.\"\n\nAdditionally, Southwest will begin selling redeye tickets this week. The first overnight flight will land on Valentine's Day 2025, connecting five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore. {"uri": "8243125128", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:20:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:20:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:19:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/business/southwest-airlines-open-seating-changes-read-full-company-statement/5630666/", "title": "Southwest Airlines open seating changes: Read full company statement", "body": "Southwest Airlines announced plans Thursday to begin assigned seating on its flights, a change to its longstanding, much-talked-about open seating policy\n\nIn a change to its longstanding policy of open seating, Southwest Airlines announced on Thursday, it will begin assigning seats and offering additional legroom for a fee.\n\nThe airline also said it plans to start selling overnight flights in February and expanding its 24-hour operation. The premium legroom offering is expected to be available for flights sometime next year.\n\nSouthwest said its hopes these changes meet customer expectations and demands while driving additional revenue. The airline said it plans to release additional details at an investor day event in September, according to CNBC.\n\nBelow, you can find the full section of the Southwest Airlines press release announcing the change to assigned and premium seating:\n\n\"As the next step in a continuing strategic transformation, Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE: LUV) (the \"Company\") is announcing several new initiatives designed to elevate the Customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive Shareholder value. As part of its ongoing focus on product evolution, the airline is moving forward with plans to assign seats, offer premium seating options, redesign the boarding model, and introduce redeye flying.\n\nSouthwest continually reviews Customer expectations. During its quarterly financial results in April, the airline shared that it was studying product preferences and expectations, including onboard seating. In addition to meeting Customer demand, the new amenities are expected to produce additional revenue and strengthen financial performance. Southwest will provide more details on its comprehensive plan to deliver transformational commercial initiatives, improved operational efficiency and capital allocation discipline during its Investor Day in late September.\n\nAssigned and Premium Seating\n\nAfter listening carefully to Customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights. The airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred. Additionally, Southwest conducted robust operational testing that included live and over 8 million simulation-based boarding trials. The airline is confident that these Customer enhancements will meet expectations and not compromise the airline's operational efficiency.\n\nThe research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest Customers, and 86% of potential Customers, prefer an assigned seat. When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change. By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future Customers.\n\nIn addition to assigning seats, Southwest will offer a premium, extended legroom portion of the cabin that research shows many Customers strongly prefer. While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\n\nThe decision to update the seating and boarding model is part of Southwest's ongoing modernization efforts. During the past two years, Southwest has enhanced its onboard offerings with improvements such as faster WiFi, in-seat power, and larger overhead bins. Work is well underway on a refreshed cabin design, including new, more comfortable RECARO seats. The addition of assigned and premium seating will give Customers more choice and is expected to further enhance the all-in value Southwest Airlines is known for.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnewyork.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC New York"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNBC", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "CNBC"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shareholder_value", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Shareholder value"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "New York Stock Exchange"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narrow-body_aircraft", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Narrow-body aircraft"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Wi-Fi"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airliner", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Airliner"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Aviation/Simulation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Aviation/Simulation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 69}], "image": "https://media.nbcnewyork.com/2024/07/GettyImages-2153584135.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&resize=1200%2C675", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1529411764705881, "wgt": 209, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-433525216", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:10:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:10:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:37:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/southwest-airlines-plans-to-start-assigning-seats-breaking-with-a-50-year-tradition/article_7baeffa2-0fec-56ab-8a99-4a52de1a99e5.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats, breaking with a 50-year tradition", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines\n\nDALLAS (AP) -- Goodbye, cattle call.\n\nSouthwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nThe airline said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. Southwest discovered that preferences have changed over the years and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" Southwest CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nIn addition to the seating switch, Southwest also plans to sell premium seating with more legroom - matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers - and to offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said redeyes will start flying in mid-February on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore, with more routes added over time.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest also faces increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a series of worrisome flights, including one that dove within 400 feet of the ocean off Hawaii, two that flew at extremely low altitudes while still miles from landing at airports in Oklahoma and Florida, and another that was discovered to have rudder-area damage after an unusual \"Dutch roll\" wiggle during a flight.\n\nSouthwest announced the seating move and other changes on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nAmerican cut its forecast of full-year earnings to between 70 cents and $1.30 per share, down from a previous prediction of $2.25 to $3.25 per share.\n\nShares of the leading U.S. airlines rose after the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. gained 3% and American Airlines Group Inc., based in Fort Worth, Texas, rose 5% in late-morning trading. Delta, United, Alaska and JetBlue also gained.\n\nMore from this section\n\nMost airlines except one are recovering from the CrowdStrike tech outage. The feds have noticed\n\nAlliance Group's Oscar Lievano Joins the Georgia First Generation Foundation to Empower First-Generation Students\n\nSecret Service director steps down after assassination One-third of seats will offer the extended option.\n\nSouthwest will sell tickets for redeye flights starting Thursday. The first overnight flights will land on Valentine's Day next year in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. Southwest said it plans to phase in additional redeye flying.\n\nRyan Green, previously the executive vice president and chief commercial officer, will take on the new role of executive vice president of commercial transformation to lead the development of the initiatives.\n\nPresident and CEO of Southwest, Bob Jordan, said the changes are part of \"a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience.\"\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" Jordan said in a news release about the changes. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders. We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver.\"\n\nThese changes come after mounting pressure from Elliott Management to boost profits. legroom.\n\n\"Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights,\" read Southwest Airlines' seating announcement. \"The airline has been known for its unique open {"uri": "2024-07-433656809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:44:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:44:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:17:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.sfgate.com/travel/article/southwest-officially-kills-hated-boarding-practice-19596591.php", "title": "Southwest finally kills 'number one reason' travelers ditched airline", "body": "The new policy kills off the airline's polarizing group boarding process, sometimes called the Southwest cattle call, which assigns flyers to a boarding group after checking in. The revamp brings the airline more in line with major carriers like American, Delta and United.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" Bob Jordan, president and CEO of the airline, said in a news release.\n\nSouthwest said it conducted \"extensive research\" before making the change and found that 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seating.\n\n\"When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" Southwest Airlines said in a news release.\n\nSouthwest also plans to introduce premium seating, allowing customers to purchase a seat with more legroom. The airline said a third of its seats will become premium seating. It's unclear when the changes to its boarding style or premium seating will take effect.\n\nWhen asked what the seat changes would mean for loyal Southwest Airlines customers with status in its Rapid Rewards program, the airline declined to comment.\n\nSouthwest is also launching flights for flyers who prefer a redeye. Redeye routes from Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore are scheduled to land on Valentine's Day 2025.", "source": {"uri": "sfgate.com", {"uri": "8242910707", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:04:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:04:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:03:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.paddleyourownkanoo.com/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-abandons-open-seating-policy-in-radical-change-to-its-iconic-onboard-experience/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Abandons Open Seating Policy in Radical Change to its Iconic Onboard Experience", "body": "Southwest Airlines is to radically change its onboard experience by abandoning its iconic open seating policy as part of a plan to improve its lagging financial performance, the Dallas-based airline confirmed on Thursday.\n\nUnder pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management, which took a stake in the carrier earlier this year in an attempt to oust the airline's leadership team, Southwest is introducing assigned seating and premium seating options for the first time in its more than 50-year history.\n\nSouthwest Airlines hasn't concealed the fact that the new seating options are designed to increase revenue opportunities, but the airline also says that switching to assigned seating is something that customers are actually begging for.\n\nIn fact, research conducted by the airline revealed that 80% of existing Southwest customers say they prefer assigned seating, and 86% of potential customers want to have an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" the airline explained on Thursday.\n\n\"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future Customers.\"\n\nSouthwest appears to have made its announcement early in an attempt to dampen calls from some shareholders to oust the airline's leadership team, so many of the details of its new seating policy are still in the works.\n\nFor example, Southwest says it will also offer extra-legroom seats for the first time in its history, but specific cabin layout details are still in design. That being said, Southwest expects roughly one-third of all seats to offer extra legroom, which would bring the carrier in line with its industry peers.\n\nThe addition of extra legroom seats has been anticipated for some time, given that Southwest recently picked out a new type of slim-line seat without adding any additional rows to its planes.\n\nIn an attempt to offer the kind of premium experiences that customers are craving, Southwest is also working to improve its onboard Wi-Fi and is in the process of installing in-seat power across its fleet.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" explained embattled chief executive Bob Jordan on Thursday.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders\".\n\nJordan has resisted calls to step aside following Elliott's decision to acquire a big stake in Southwest, but the decision to announce radical passenger experience changes months before Southwest's annual investor day is a clear sign of how much pressure he is under.\n\nAs it stands, there are no details on how much extra legroom seating might cost or what other fee-based services Southwest might add to its seating options.\n\nWhat we do know, however, is that Southwest will finally introduce red-eye flights from Valentine's Day 2025, as part of a plan to further increase revenues and realize cost savings.\n\nThe rollout of overnight flying will be slow, and Southwest intends to launch red-eye flights in just five markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.", "source": {"uri": "paddleyourownkanoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Paddle Your Own Kanoo"}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 207, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243737248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:00:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:00:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:59:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-plans-to-start-assigning-seats-breaking-with-a-50-year-tradition/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Plans to Start Assigning Seats, Breaking With a 50-Year Tradition", "body": "Southwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nThe airline said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. Southwest discovered that preferences have changed over the years and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\nRelated Story: Fresno Airline Flights Cancelled Amid Global IT Shutdown\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" Southwest CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nSome Southwest passengers reacted with sadness and disappointment to news that open seating is going away.\n\n\"Hearing that announcement today, I was like, no, this is my favorite part of Southwest,\" said Lindsey Magness, who works in college athletics in Oklahoma City.\n\nMagness said that with open seating, she can try for a window seat or, depending on her mood, an aisle. And assigned seating doesn't always work either. Magness said American Airlines seated her away from her husband on their honeymoon trip earlier this summer\n\nBrandon Bowser of Odenton, Maryland, said he flies on different airlines based on which one has the best deal, but he has found Southwest's open boarding to be faster and less complicated than other airlines.\n\n\"The convenience that comes with being able to pick your own seat is what sets Southwest apart and makes them sort of a preferred airline,\" he said. \"A lot of my friends swear by Southwest, that's all they will fly, and they are completely irate about this decision.\"\n\nAt Chicago's O'Hare Airport, Kimberly King was happy to learn of the change. She was at a check-in kiosk with her four children for a flight home to California.\n\n\"I used to fly United a lot and I liked the assigned seats, especially with kids, kind of expecting and knowing where we were going to be,\" King said. \"The only reason really why I continue to fly Southwest is for the free bags.\"\n\nSouthwest still lets passengers check two bags for free. It's been a centerpiece of the airline's advertising campaigns for years. CEO Jordan said Southwest has no plans to end bags-fly-free \"at this point.\"\n\nRelated Story: Smoking Laptop in Passenger's Bag Prompts Evacuation on American Airlines ...\n\nThere are drawbacks to Southwest boarding. It's hard to get a good spot in line without paying an extra fee. Southwest executives said 60% of passengers check in the first 30 seconds. Those who miss the rush fear there won't be room in the overhead bins for their carry-on bag. Late boarders can struggle to see an open seat anywhere, and start roaming up and down the aisle -- Southwest calls them \"spinners.\"\n\nThere are a number of tricks that passengers use to game the system.\n\nSome take advantage of early boarding for people who need extra time. Others ignore the age limit (6 or under) for children in families that are allowed to board right after the \"A\" group. Once on the plane, some passengers hold choice seats for mates who are far behind them in line.\n\nPhotos appear occasionally on social media of an unusually large number of people in wheelchairs at Southwest gates. They get to board early.\n\n\"It's certainly one of the things that anger people even if it doesn't have a material impact on them,\" said Brett Snyder, a travel agent and author of the Cranky Flier blog. \"In some cases those are people who have absolutely legitimate reasons. In other cases, it's the 'Jetway Jesus' phenomenon.\"\n\nThat's a reference to recoveries so miraculous that the disability causing the person to need a wheelchair to reach the gate is cured during flight, and they walk off the plane like everybody else.\n\nSnyder doubts that fans of open seating will abandon Southwest.\n\nRelated Story: American Airlines Retreats After Blaming a 9-Year-Old for Not Seeing a Hidden ...\n\n\"Those people will still fly Southwest,\" he said. \"They may grumble about it, but there's no one else they can go to that has open seating.\"\n\nIn addition to the boarding change, Southwest also plans to convert about one-third of the seats on its planes to premium seating with more legroom, matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers.\n\nThe airline's newest schedule also includes a few redeye flights -- a first for Southwest.\n\nThe overnight flights will start in mid-February on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. More routes will be added over time, the airline said.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest also faces increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a series of worrisome flights, including one that dove within 400 feet of the ocean off Hawaii, two that flew at extremely low altitudes while still miles from landing at airports in Oklahoma and Florida, and another that was discovered to have rudder-area damage after an unusual \"Dutch roll\" wiggle during a flight.\n\nSouthwest announced the seating move and other changes on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue. Airlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million. CEO Robert Isom said the airline was held back by a sales strategy that it is now rolling back and by an oversupply of domestic flights.\n\nAmerican said its earnings per share in the third quarter will be break-even, well below Wall Street's expectation of 48 cents per share. American also cut its forecast of full-year earnings to between 70 cents and $1.30 per share, down from a previous prediction of $2.25 to $3.25 per share.\n\nShares of the leading U.S. airlines rose Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. gained 5.5% and American Airlines Group Inc., based in Fort Worth, Texas, rose 4%. Delta, United, Alaska and JetBlue also gained.", "source": {"uri": "gvwire.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GV Wire"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@gvwire.com", "name": "Associated Press", {"uri": "8243613805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:44:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:44:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:44:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.flyertalk.com/articles/southwest-moves-to-assigned-seating-to-improve-financial-performance.html", "title": "Southwest Moves to Assigned Seating to Improve Financial Performance", "body": "Gone will be the days where Southwest Airlines travelers will board in groups based on when they checked in, as the carrier is moving to a model they say is more customer friendly and profitable.\n\nThe airline announced they would move to assigned seating with a premium seating option, as well as adding 24-hour operation capabilities with the addition of overnight \"redeye\" flights.\n\nIn justifying the move to assigned seating, Southwest says the change is based on customer demand. Although they have offered group boarding for over 50 years, the airline says they decided to make the move after operational testing including 8 million simulation-based boarding trials and live testing.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" the airline said in a press release. \"When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change. By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nAs part of the move, the airline will also offer a premium economy offering with additional legroom. While no specifics are available as the carrier says \"specific cabin layout details are still in design,\" they expect to offer the premium seats across one-third of the fleet.\n\nFinally, the airline will also move to offering overnight flights across a test group of five markets. Starting in February 2025, Southwest will operate redeye flights from Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nThe moves come as activist investor Elliott Investment Management is calling for the removal of Southwest's executive leadership due to financial shortcomings. Southwest says the new moves are designed to improve their overall financial performance.", "source": {"uri": "flyertalk.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FlyerTalk - The world's most popular {"uri": "2024-07-433303105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:46:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:46:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.fox13memphis.com/news/southwest-breaks-with-50-year-tradition-and-will-assign-seats-profit-falls-at-southwest-american/article_c4ac352e-4a81-11ef-854c-1775c65c66cd.html", "title": "Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American", "body": "MEMPHIS, Tenn. - Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nDownload the FOX13 Memphis app to receive alerts from breaking news in your neighborhood.\n\nCLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD\n\nTrending {"uri": "2024-07-433268728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:16:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:16:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:07:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.koaa.com/life/travel/in-major-shift-southwest-is-getting-rid-of-open-seating-and-will-now-assign-seats", "title": "In major shift, Southwest is getting rid of open seating and will now assign seats", "body": "After more than 50 years, Southwest Airlines is getting rid of its unique open seating model and will now assign seats. (Scripps News)\n\nAfter more than 50 years, Southwest Airlines is getting rid of its unique open seating model and will now assign seats.\n\nThe airline made the move to meet the evolving preferences of customers who say they want seat assignments. Southwest also said it conducted testing that included live and more than 8 million simulation-based boarding trials before making the change.\n\nResearch from the airline shows 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. And when customers opt to stop flying with Southwest in favor of a competitor, the number one reason they cite leaving is open seating.\n\nThe major shift comes as the airline faces mounting pressure to increase revenue.\n\nWith open seating, travelers would board according to their boarding group and seat selection was first come, first served on the plane. The seating model was unique to Southwest. With the switch, seating will be determined in advance, following suit with other airlines.\n\nSouthwest said it will also offer a premium section of the plane with extended legroom, which research shows customers \"strongly prefer.\" About a third of the cabin will have seats with extended legroom.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Southwest president, CEO, and vice chairman of the board Bob Jordan, in a press release.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" Jordan said. \"We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver. We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nSouthwest will also introduce overnight, red-eye flights in February 2025.\n\nOver the past two years, the airline has offered faster WiFi, in-seat power, and larger overhead bins.", "source": {"uri": "koaa.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KOAA"}, "authors": [{"uri": "elina_tarkazikis@koaa.com", "name": "Elina The airline also plans to start overnight flights, starting in February.\n\nSouthwest executives have said for years that they were studying such changes and hinted in April that it was seriously considering assigning seats and offering pricier seats with more legroom. When travelers choose a competitor over Southwest, the airline found in its research that its open seating model was the No. 1 reason for that choice, the carrier said in a release that outlined the changes. It also said 80% of its own customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is under even more pressure now to segment its product like other airlines after activist investor Elliott Investment Management disclosed in June a nearly $2 billion stake in the airline and called for new leadership as the airline underperformed competitors.\n\n\"We will adapt as our customers' needs adapt,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said at an industry event last month.\n\nSouthwest said it expects about a third of the seats on its Boeing 737s will offer \"extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\"\n\nThe Dallas-based airline had prided itself and raked in steady profits for most of its more than five decades of flying on its simple business model. Jordan said last month that not assigning seats was easier to offer when planes weren't so full.\n\nAnalysts criticized Southwest for moving too slowly. Rival carriers offer a host of options to upsell customers like extra legroom seats, premium economy or business class. Other airlines, however, like Delta, United and American, four years ago took a cue from Southwest and ended flight-change fees for most tickets.\n\nSouthwest will provide more details about the upcoming changes at an investor day at the end of September.", "source": {"uri": "nbcphiladelphia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC10 Philadelphia"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": When will the airline start assigning seats?", "body": "After more than 50 years, Southwest Airlines is getting rid of its unique open seating model and will now assign seats.\n\nYou want to get away, but you also want to make sure you have a good seat? You'll finally be able to.\n\nSouthwest Airlines, which flies out of Philadelphia International Airport, announced Thursday several changes to improve the customer experience including assigned seats and premium seating.\n\nSouthwest Airlines opening seating change\n\nFor more than 50 years, Southwest has had first-come seating arrangements with passengers boarding in groups. Passengers in the first boarding group got their choice of seat. Subsequent boarding groups got what was available after each group boarded.\n\nThose seating arrangements are changing to assigned and premium seating. According to Southwest, 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential Southwest customers prefer assigned seats.\n\nTravel: Two new routes are coming to the Wilmington Airport this fall. Here's what to know\n\nTravel deals: Avelo adds early holiday travel deals, announces exit of 6 domestic markets\n\nSouthwest Airlines adding premium seating\n\nSouthwest Airlines is adding premium seating with an extended legroom portion of the cabin. Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom.\n\nSouthwest already unveiled a cabin refresh earlier this year and is in the middle of upgrading its fleet with changes announced in 2022, including in-seat USB charging and stronger Wi-Fi.\n\nSouthwest hasn't announced a date for the seating changes.\n\nSouthwest Airlines adding red eyes\n\nSouthwest is adding red-eye flights. The initial red-eye flight routes are:\n\nThe airline plans to eventually increase the number of markets with red-eye flights and offer 24-hour operational capabilities. {"uri": "2024-07-433710045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:58:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:58:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:24:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.wivb.com/news/national/when-will-southwest-begin-assigning-seats/", "title": "When will Southwest begin assigning seats?", "body": "(NEXSTAR) - Southwest Airlines on Thursday announced plans to begin assigning seats to passengers -- abandoning the open-seating policy that's been a trademark of the carrier for half a century.\n\n\"The airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred,\" reads a media release from Southwest.\n\nIn defending the change, the airline cited \"extensive research\" which included surveys of Southwest customers and \"potential\" Southwest customers, the majority of whom (80% and 86%, respectively) wanted assigned seating. Southwest added that its open-seating plan is \"the number one reason\" customers choose to fly with a competing airline, according to the release.\n\nSouthwest's unique seating policy, as it currently exists, initially began as a way to load passengers faster, thereby limiting the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground. It works like this: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. The earliest to check in are placed in an \"A\" boarding group, with \"B\" and \"C\" groups containing those who checked in later.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\nThe change isn't exactly happening overnight, though. In a statement obtained by Nexstar, a Southwest representative confirmed that customers will have some time to get used to the idea.\n\n\"We expect to make bookings available in 2025,\" the representative said in response to a question about the assigned-seating timeline. \"More specifics will be discussed at our Investor Day in September.\"\n\nIn addition to assigned seating, Southwest announced Thursday its plans to begin offering premium seating options and overnight flights, the latter of which are scheduled to begin departing on Feb. 14, 2025.\n\nThese decisions were made to offer \"more choice\" and \"enhance\" value for Southwest travelers, the company says. But of course, the carrier's bottom line is always a consideration.\n\n\"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations -- and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance,\" said Bob Jordan, the president and CEO of
