{"uri": "2024-07-433485534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:31:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:31:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:11:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.thestreet.com/travel/did-southwest-get-rid-of-open-seating", "title": "Southwest Airlines finally makes the seating change many feared", "body": "The feature is so iconic that one Delta (DAL) flight attendant once went TikTok viral for exclaiming \"this isn't Southwest!\" when passengers kept moving around the cabin and switching seats.\n\nHowever, while open seating earned Southwest the loyalty of many travelers, it has also cost the airline profits, given that seat selection is a profit stream that many carriers rely on. Amid a string of worse-than-expected earnings reports, chief executive Bob Jordan previously said that the airline was \"exploring new initiatives\" and changes to \"the way we seat and the way we board our aircraft.\"\n\n'Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying'\n\nOn July 25, Southwest released a second-quarter earnings report showing that revenue fell by 46% to $367 million, while nonfuel expenses are expected to rise a further 13% by the end of the year. In a statement, Jordan said that \"urgent and deliberate steps\" were needed to increase profits and one such change is the introduction of premium seating.\n\nMore on travel:\n\nWhile Southwest is not yet releasing the details of what this would look like or how much it would cost, the general concept is paying extra for assigned seating. Jordan said that Southwest executives will be meeting to discuss the details further in September. The biggest remaining question is whether the open seating plan will remain after those with assigned seats have boarded or whether the system will be replaced entirely.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" Southwest said in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nHere are the other changes Southwest plans to make (and how they affect travelers)\n\nOther changes announced by Southwest include the introduction of its first red-eye flights. The airline has, for years, flown exclusively during daytime hours but has hinted that it was looking to launch routes in which one can board at night and arrive the next day. The new routes will start running from Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville and Phoenix to Baltimore starting on Feb. 14, 2025.\n\nFor those questioning whether to book an assigned seat, Southwest said that it also plans to offer spaces with additional legroom -- the airline expects one third of cabins on new or retrofitted planes to feature seats with more space to stretch out.\n\nAll of this represents a massive change to how Southwest formerly conducted business, which may leave some who are used to the old system unhappy, but, according to Jordan, it will help the airline return to profit.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" Jordan said.", "source": {"uri": "thestreet.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TheStreet"}, {"uri": "8242948725", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:28:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:28:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:27:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://fortune.com/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-assigned-seats-open-seating-policy-founding-50-years-ago/", "title": "Southwest Airlines will offer assigned seats, ditching the open seating policy it's had since its founding over 50 years ago", "body": "Southwest Airlines Co. will begin offering assigned seats, ditching the free-for-all policy that has been a defining feature of the carrier for more than half a century.\n\nThe airline announced the seismic change to its business model Thursday alongside a new premium-class option and plans for redeye flights. While Southwest indicated earlier this year that it was reconsidering the seating policy, it's now facing heightened pressure to revamp underperforming operations from activist investor Elliott Investment Management.\n\nThe steps represent a strategic shift for the carrier, which has steadfastly maintained open seating while other airlines raked in revenue by charging extra for more-desirable seats. That unfulfilled opportunity is a major tenet of Elliott's campaign -- that Southwest has refused to modernize its business to appeal to today's travelers.\n\nAdoption of premium seating could open the door for the carrier -- which has long appealed primarily to leisure travelers -- to potentially offer business- and first-class sections in the future.\n\nSouthwest still won't charge for checked bags. The \"bags fly free\" policy has been a focal point of Southwest promotions and advertisements, and some analysts have speculated charging for bags could cost the airline customers. It's the only US carrier that doesn't impose fees to check two.\n\nSouthwest will begin offering assigned seats and premium seating with more legroom next year. It will start flying overnight, cross-country routes on Feb. 13. Those flights are for sale from Las Vegas, Los Angeles and Phoenix to Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport; Las Vegas to Orlando; and Los Angeles to Nashville.\n\nDetails on which seats will carry fees and the extra cost are still being decided, Southwest said. All seats will be assigned, but there won't be a separate cabin for premium offerings. The carrier has studied various seating options in the past, but always rejected a shift to assigned spots, saying passengers didn't support such a move.\n\nWhile Southwest has long stood by some of its central policies, it hasn't been entirely resistant to change. It began routes to nearby international destinations and, more recently, added flights to Hawaii. The airline previously revamped its boarding system, offered early boarding options at an additional cost and developed a corporate booking tool to win more business travelers.\n\nSouthwest said in April that it had begun evaluating premium products and others changes, well before Elliott disclosed a $1.9 billion stake last month. But until Thursday, the airline said it wouldn't disclose any details until an investor meeting slated for September.\n\nElliott wants to oust Chief Executive Officer Bob Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly for poor execution and a \"stubborn unwillingness to evolve the company's strategy.\" They are \"not up to the task of modernizing Southwest,\" the activist has said.\n\nSouthwest earlier this month named a veteran airline industry executive to its board to help address other concerns raised by Elliott. The carrier also adopted a \"poison pill\" shareholder rights plan to discourage the activist from gaining a larger share.", "source": {"uri": "fortune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fortune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mary_schlangenstein@fortune.com", "name": "Mary Schlangenstein", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Investment_Management", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Elliott Investment Management"}}, {"uri": "8242927959", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:15:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:15:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:14:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.travelandtourworld.com/news/article/southwest-expands-with-redeye-flights-and-premium-seating-enhancements/", "title": "Southwest Expands With Redeye Flights And Premium Seating Enhancements - Travel And Tour World", "body": "Southwest Airlines announces major changes with assigned and premium seating, new redeye flights, and 24-hour operations, enhancing customer experience and revenue.\n\nAs part of its ongoing strategic transformation, Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE: LUV) (\"the Company\") is unveiling several new initiatives aimed at enhancing the customer experience, boosting financial performance, and increasing shareholder value. These plans include assigning seats, offering premium seating options, redesigning the boarding process, and introducing redeye flights.\n\nSouthwest Airlines continually reviews customer expectations. In April, during its quarterly financial results, the airline announced it was studying product preferences and expectations, including onboard seating. The new amenities are designed to meet customer demand while generating additional revenue and enhancing financial performance. Southwest will provide more details on its comprehensive plan to deliver transformational commercial initiatives, improved operational efficiency, and disciplined capital allocation during its Investor Day in late September.\n\nAssigned and Premium Seating\n\nAfter carefully listening to customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest has decided to implement assigned seating and introduce premium seating options on all flights. For over 50 years, the airline has been known for its unique open seating model, but customer preferences have evolved, with more travelers favoring assigned seats on longer flights. Extensive operational testing, including live trials and over 8 million simulation-based boarding trials, has assured the airline that these enhancements will meet customer expectations without compromising operational efficiency.\n\nResearch indicates that 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seating. When customers choose to fly with a competitor, open seating is the primary reason for the switch. By adopting an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more travelers, both current and future.\n\nIn addition to assigned seating, Southwest will introduce a premium seating option with extended legroom, which many customers strongly prefer. While specific cabin layout details are still being finalized, Southwest anticipates that roughly one-third of seats across its fleet will offer extended legroom, comparable to industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\n\nThis decision to update the seating and boarding model is part of Southwest's ongoing modernization efforts. Over the past two years, the airline has improved its onboard offerings by introducing faster WiFi, in-seat power, and larger overhead bins. A refreshed cabin design, including new, more comfortable RECARO seats, is well underway. The addition of assigned and premium seating will provide customers with more choices and is expected to further enhance the all-in value that Southwest Airlines is known for.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" said Bob Jordan, President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders. We are excited to incorporate Customer and Employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver. We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nRedeye Flights Now for Sale\n\nSouthwest has announced the addition of 24-hour operation capabilities with the introduction of overnight, redeye flights. Booking for initial routes is now available on Southwest.com, with the first overnight flights landing on Valentine's Day 2025 in five nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore. Southwest plans to expand redeye flights in upcoming schedules as part of its multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation. This move, along with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to generate incremental revenue and cost savings, enabling Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without additional aircraft capital deployment.\n\nNew EVP Commercial Transformation\n\nRyan Green, previously Executive Vice President & Chief Commercial Officer, will assume the new role of Executive Vice President Commercial Transformation to lead the development and rollout of these and other commercial initiatives. Green, who has deep knowledge of customer trends and currently oversees cabin transformation efforts, has also directed the transformation of Southwest Airlines' Rapid Rewards\u00ae loyalty program and the digital customer experience. In his new role, he will report to President, CEO, and Vice Chairman of the Board Bob Jordan.\n\n\"I'm eager to lead this next step in our transformation to serve our Customers with an even better Southwest. In addition to meeting the evolving needs of Customers and fostering more loyalty, these changes are expected to generate additional revenue as we capitalize on greater demand for Southwest Airlines and offer Customers the ability to purchase premium seating options,\" Green said. \"Together, these strategic initiatives play an integral role in the airline's comprehensive strategy to meet Customer needs and enhance Shareholder value, while maintaining the unique Culture, Hospitality, and flexibility that make Southwest - Southwest.\"\n\nThe Company will provide more details about product designs, cabin layout, timing, and incremental financial value at its Investor Day in late September. The shift to assigned and premium seating marks a significant change. Along with incorporating new technologies and procedures for a smooth transition, the new cabin layout will require approval from the Federal Aviation Administration. Southwest anticipates making bookings available in 2025.\n\nGary Kelly, Executive Chairman of the Board, said, \"The Board fully supports these efforts to usher in a new era for Southwest Airlines, and we have the ultimate confidence in Bob and our Leadership Team to design and deliver an experience that is unique and true to our Southwest Legacy.\"", "source": {"uri": "travelandtourworld.com", {"uri": "2024-07-433482637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:27:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:27:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:27:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.newsobserver.com/news/business/article290420459.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines finally makes the seating change many feared", "body": "The feature is so iconic that one Delta (DAL) flight attendant once went TikTok viral for exclaiming \"this isn't Southwest!\" when passengers kept moving around the cabin and switching seats.\n\nRelated: I just flew Southwest for the first time ever -- here is what it was like\n\nHowever, while open seating earned Southwest the loyalty of many travelers, it has also cost the airline profits, given that seat selection is a profit stream that many carriers rely on. Amid a string of worse-than-expected earnings reports, chief executive Bob Jordan previously said that the airline was \"exploring new initiatives\" and changes to \"the way we seat and the way we board our aircraft.\"\n\n'Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying'\n\nOn July 25, Southwest released a second-quarter earnings report showing that revenue fell by 46% to $367 million, while nonfuel expenses are expected to rise a further 13% by the end of the year. In a statement, Jordan said that \"urgent and deliberate steps\" were needed to increase profits and one such change is the introduction of premium seating.\n\nMore on travel:\n\nWhile Southwest is not yet releasing the details of what this would look like or how much it would cost, the general concept is paying extra for assigned seating. Jordan said that Southwest executives will be meeting to discuss the details further in September. The biggest remaining question is whether the open seating plan will remain after those with assigned seats have boarded or whether the system will be replaced entirely.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" Southwest said in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nRelated: Get the best cruise tips, deals, and news on the ships from our expert cruiser\n\nHere are the other changes Southwest plans to make (and how they affect travelers)\n\nOther changes announced by Southwest include the introduction of its first red-eye flights. The airline has, for years, flown exclusively during daytime hours but has hinted that it was looking to launch routes in which one can board at night and arrive the next day. The new routes will start running from Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville and Phoenix to Baltimore starting on Feb. 14, 2025.\n\nFor those questioning whether to book an assigned seat, Southwest said that it also plans to offer spaces with additional legroom -- the airline expects one third of cabins on new or retrofitted planes to feature seats with more space to stretch out.\n\nAll of this represents a massive change to how Southwest formerly conducted business, which may leave some who are used to the old system unhappy, but, according to Jordan, it will help the airline return to profit.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" Jordan said.\n\nRelated: Veteran fund manager picks favorite stocks for 2024", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243644861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:14:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:14:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:14:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.unionleader.com/news/business/transportation/southwest-abandons-open-seating-after-53-years/article_3be55af4-4ab3-11ef-bfec-0b5f2aa7bcc7.html", "title": "Southwest abandons open seating after 53 years", "body": "Southwest Airlines announced Thursday that it will do away with its longtime practice of open seating, abandoning a feature that helped establish its egalitarian identity in the name of boosting revenue and adapting to evolving customer tastes.\n\nThe carrier, long known for its unique model of having passengers board in groups of 30 and then choose their seats once on board, said it will now assign seats and unveil \"premium seating options\" that offer more legroom. In its announcement, the carrier said it expects that about one-third of seats across its fleet will have extra legroom. The company did not provide a timeline for the changes.\n\nSouthwest, which started service to Manchester in 1998, currently averages eight daily flights out of Manchester. The airline flies to Orlando, Tampa, Chicago and Baltimore.\n\nSouthwest is averaging 1,277 daily outbound seats from Manchester in July and August, giving Southwest 52% of the total outbound seats from all airlines serving Manchester, according to the airport.\n\nIn 2003, Southwest had 22 daily flights from Manchester. That included a non-stop flight to Las Vegas -- which at 2,356 miles was the second-longest flight for Southwest nationwide.\n\nThursday's move quickly drew negative reaction from die-hard Southwest fans who say the airline is jeopardizing its identity.\n\nSaty Reddy, a lawyer who lives in the Bay Area and flies Southwest frequently with his family, said the shift marks \"the end of the people's airline.\"\n\nBen\u00e9t J. Wilson, a veteran aviation journalist and Southwest superfan who lives in Baltimore, said she woke up to \"a ton of texts and messages from friends giving me this news.\" The new policies will inevitably make Southwest feel different -- but also more like its competitors, she said.\n\n\"It's like another airline, any old plain airline,\" Wilson said. \"Southwest has swag and personality, bon vivant. Part of that was the open seating. Now I just feel like it will kind of change how the airline feels to me.\"\n\nSouthwest fan Grant Goodman, 24, sent a message to a reporter Thursday morning saying he felt betrayed. The Atlanta-based actor described himself as \"a dedicated front row, middle seat enthusiast.\"\n\n\"My favorite endurance hobby was checking in at the 24-hour mark,\" he said in an interview. \"The button -- I got it down.\"\n\nGoodman said he appreciated how passengers could book a flight 48 hours before departure, check in 24 hours in advance and still have a shot at a seat upfront.\n\n\"It was basically like a democracy,\" he said.\n\nThe company acknowledged that changing the seating policy was a big shift for the airline, which boasts that it set out to \"democratize the sky\" with low-cost travel when it began offering service in 1971.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said in a statement.\n\nThe company said its research showed that 80% of its customers and 86% of \"potential\" customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" it said in a news release.\n\nJordan first hinted at the change in April. \"Early indications both for our customers and for Southwest look pretty darn interesting,\" he said at the time.\n\nThe changes are the most significant shift in decades for the airline, which built its reputation as a scrappy discount underdog but has evolved to become one of the dominant carriers in the United States. Even so, Southwest has been under pressure to boost revenue. As other airlines have found ways to charge for various \"upgrades,\" including more legroom and early boarding, Southwest's model left it with few options.\n\nThe carrier will also begin offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights, confirming an announcement from earlier this year. It said the flights will begin in February, with the first overnight flight landing on Valentine's Day 2025.\n\nRyan Fisher, a digital marketing analyst and frequent Southwest flier based in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, said the switch is not a surprise, but it's still disappointing.\n\n\"If people are willing to pay up for that seat guarantee, I get it,\" Fisher said in a direct message on X. \"I'm just not that person ... so this news overall is disappointing for a Southwest loyalist like myself.\"\n\nSouthwest fan Goodman anticipates that the airline's changes will result in higher prices for passengers. He expects Southwest to continue offering free checked bags, a differentiating perk the company's leadership has promised to keep. But he mourned the loss of the open-seating policy.\n\n\"It was the commoner's airline,\" he said. \"That feeling, I think, has kind of fallen a little bit.\"", "source": {"uri": "unionleader.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UnionLeader.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "lori_aratani@unionleader.com", "name": "Lori Aratani", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manchester", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Manchester"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Manchester"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore", {"uri": "8243437355", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:02:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:02:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:01:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://rollingout.com/2024/07/25/southwest-elminates-free-choice-seating/", "title": "Southwest eliminates free choice seating policy", "body": "Southwest Airlines has made a major shift in its boarding process. The airline will no longer offer free choice seating to people as they board. Like most airlines, Southwest customers will be in assigned seats. The change will allow Southwest to charge a higher rate for premium seating and satisfy customers. The airline said open seating was the No. 1 reason passengers claimed they were unhappy, CNN reported.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" a statement from the airline read. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nCNN reported that Southwest suffered a 51% drop in adjusted profit to $370 million, although revenue for the quarter was boosted due to greater passenger traffic. Southwest has the strongest credit rating of any airline but has been struggling with mismanagement, other outside factors, and changing industry dynamics. Shares of Southwest were down by more than 4%.\n\nRyan Green, previously Southwest's executive vice president and chief commercial officer, will now be the company's executive vice president of commercial transformation.\n\n\"I'm eager to lead this next step in our transformation to serve our Customers with an even better Southwest. In addition to meeting the evolving needs of Customers and fostering more loyalty, these changes are expected to generate additional revenue as we capitalize on greater demand for Southwest Airlines and offer Customers the ability to purchase premium seating options,\" Green said. \"Together, these strategic initiatives play an integral role in the airline's comprehensive strategy to meet Customer needs and enhance Shareholder value, while maintaining the unique Culture, Hospitality, and flexibility that make Southwest - Southwest.\"\n\nSouthwest will also offer overnight \"red-eye\" flights for the first time to improve efficiency.", "source": {"uri": "rollingout.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rolling Out"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "CNN"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_rating", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Credit rating"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_president", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Vice president"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hospitality", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Hospitality"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shareholder_value", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Shareholder value"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Fleet_Maintenance", "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Fleet Maintenance", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 72}], "image": "https://rollingout.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/shutterstock_606188015-scaled.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1843137254901961, "wgt": 203, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243345074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:56:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:56:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:51:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/finance/southwest-airlines-finally-makes-the-seating-change-many-feared/article_c08a9dff-cd08-5283-bb31-5eb835e7996c.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines finally makes the seating change many feared", "body": "For generations, Dallas-based Southwest Airlines (LUV) has stood out from other airlines by not assigning seats but letting travelers board in groups and then choose from whatever is available.\n\nThe feature is so iconic that one Delta (DAL) flight attendant once went TikTok viral for exclaiming \"this isn't Southwest!\" when passengers kept moving around the cabin and switching seats.\n\nRelated: I just flew Southwest for the first time ever -- here is what it was like\n\nHowever, while open seating earned Southwest the loyalty of many travelers, it has also cost the airline profits, given that seat selection is a profit stream that many carriers rely on. Amid a string of worse-than-expected earnings reports, chief executive Bob Jordan previously said that the airline was \"exploring new initiatives\" and changes to \"the way we seat and the way we board our aircraft.\"\n\n'Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying'\n\nOn July 25, Southwest released a second-quarter earnings report showing that revenue fell by 46% to $367 million, while nonfuel expenses are expected to rise a further 13% by the end of the year. In a statement, Jordan said that \"urgent and deliberate steps\" were needed to increase profits and one such change is the introduction of premium seating.\n\nMore on travel:\n\nAnother National Park just made it more difficult for you to visitDelta Air Lines makes a baggage change that travelers will likeUnited Airlines passenger incident triggers quick response\n\nWhile Southwest is not yet releasing the details of what this would look like or how much it would cost, the general concept is paying extra for assigned seating. Jordan said that Southwest executives will be meeting to discuss the details further in September. The biggest remaining question is whether the open seating plan will remain after those with assigned seats have boarded or whether the system will be replaced entirely.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" Southwest said in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nRelated: Get the best cruise tips, deals, and news on the ships from our expert cruiser\n\nHere are the other changes Southwest plans to make (and how they affect travelers)\n\nOther changes announced by Southwest include the introduction of its first red-eye flights. The airline has, for years, flown exclusively during daytime hours but has hinted that it was looking to launch routes in which one can board at night and arrive the next day. The new routes will start running from Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville and Phoenix to Baltimore starting on Feb. 14, 2025.\n\nFor those questioning whether to book an assigned seat, Southwest said that it also plans to offer spaces with additional legroom -- the airline expects one third of cabins on new or retrofitted planes to feature seats with more space to stretch out.\n\nAll of this represents a massive change to how Southwest formerly conducted business, which may leave some who are used to the old system unhappy, but, according to Jordan, it will help the airline return to profit.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" Jordan said.\n\nRelated: Veteran fund manager picks favorite stocks for 2024", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243382522", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:19:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:19:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:18:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.capitalgazette.com/2024/07/25/major-bwi-carrier-southwest-airlines-will-assign-seats-breaking-with-50-year-tradition/", "title": "Major BWI carrier Southwest Airlines will assign seats, breaking with 50-year tradition", "body": "Southwest Airlines, the largest carrier at Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport, will start assigning seats and selling premium seating in a break from its more than 50-year tradition of open seating.\n\nThe airline said Thursday it is making the changes after finding that passenger preferences about seating options have changed. The moves also could generate revenue and boost financial performance, the company said.\n\nSouthwest also plans to redesign its boarding model and introduce redeye flights.\n\nThe airline became the nation's biggest low-cost carrier because of its open economy seating policy. It is BWI Airport's top passenger airline by market share and served nearly 70% of the airport's customers in 2022, state figures show.\n\nThe Dallas-based carrier started its unusual boarding process decades ago as a way for the airline to save money, instead of assigning passenger seats. The airline requires customers to check in 24 hours before departure or pay extra to guarantee a better place in line.\n\nBut passenger preferences have evolved as people take longer flights and prefer a seat assignment, the company said. The company said 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\nAnd those who switch airlines cite Southwest's open seating as the top reason for the change. Southwest's new premium seating will offer extended legroom, which will account for about a third of seating offerings.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Bob Jordan, president and CEO, in Thursday's announcement.\n\nSouthwest also plans to introduce overnight, redeye flights in five markets, including Baltimore, which will have redeyes to Las Vegas, Los Angeles and Phoenix. Other redeyes will be offered between Las Vegas and Orlando and Los Angeles and Nashville.\n\nSouthwest announced the changes as it reported a sharp drop in second-quarter earnings despite higher revenue. It had announced in April that it was studying product preferences and expectations, including onboard seating.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. {"uri": "8243114958", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:17:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:17:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:13:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.nl/southwest-is-ditching-its-unassigned-seat-policy-for-the-first-time/", "title": "Southwest is ditching its unassigned seat policy for the first time", "body": "Southwest Airlines has had an unassigned seating policy for over 50 years. The carriers now plans to assign seats on all flights and offer premium seating options. The changes come as the airline faces pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management.\n\nSouthwest Airlines is eliminating its open seating model for the first time. Instead, it will start assigning seats before all flights and offering premium seating options.\n\nThe announcement on Thursday is part of the airline's mission to improve financial performance, increase its stock price, and enhance customer experience. It comes as an activist investor with a large stake pushes for big changes, including a new CEO\n\n\"Southwest represents the most compelling airline turnaround opportunity in the last two decades,\" the hedge fund Elliott Investment Management said in June when it began its crusade.\n\nPaul Singer, Elliott Management's founder. Elliott is pushing for major changes at Southwest. Foto: CNBC / Getty Contributor\n\nSince launching 57 years ago, the airline has had an open seating policy, meaning passengers choose their seats once they board their flight.\n\nThat will now change.\n\nSouthwest said research carried out showed that 80% of customers and 86% of potential customers favored an assigned seat system. The number one reason a passenger chooses a competitor is the open seating model, the company added.\n\nSouthwest did not give an exact date for the changes but said more details will be revealed in September.\n\nMore add-on revenue could be a lifesaver for Southwest\n\nSouthwest also announced that it will be introducing premium seating with extended legroom, with possibly up to one-third of a cabin being allocated to this kind of seat.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" said Southwest's CEO, president and vice chairman of the board, Bob Jordan.\n\nPaid seat upgrades are lucrative revenue sources for airlines and have largely allowed mainline carriers like American or Delta to avoid some of the financial stress that's hit low-cost carriers this year.\n\nThe airline will also add 24-hour operations from February of next year, with new overnight redeye flights available.\n\nChanges to Southwest's seating policy were announced on the same day the company reported a significant drop in profits for the second quarter of the year. Southwest reported net income of $367 million for the quarter, down from $683 million in the same period in 2023.\n\nWhile profits fell, revenues climbed, hitting a record $7.4 billion for the quarter.\n\nRead the original article on Business Insider", "source": {"uri": "businessinsider.nl", "dataType": "news", "title": "Business Insider Nederland"}, "authors": [{"uri": "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": The Dallas-based airline announced Thursday it would be scrapping its open seating policy in favor of assigned seating. The shift more closely aligns with the changing consumer preferences.\n\nThe implementation of assigned seating is just one among the handful of changes Southwest detailed in its recent press release. Here's what we know.\n\nPeople are also reading: Austin-Bergstrom ranks 10th best in the U.S., only Texas airport to make new list\n\nSouthwest Airlines introduces assigned seating policy\n\nIn a press release Thursday, Southwest acknowledged \"preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred.\" The airline hopes moving to assigned seats and revamping its boarding process will broaden Southwest's appeal to both new and existing customers: Research found 80% of current Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seating.\n\nThe airline did not provide an exact date for the switch.\n\nChanges to 'enhance customer experience, improve financial performance'\n\nIn addition to assigned seating, Southwest is also rolling out premium seating options on all flights, and introducing red-eye flights.\n\n\"While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft,\" the airline said.\n\nSouthwest already unveiled a cabin refresh earlier this year and is in the middle of upgrading its fleet with changes announced in 2022, including in-seat USB charging and stronger Wi-Fi.\n\nSouthwest said the changes are \"designed to elevate the customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive shareholder value\" without sacrificing operational efficiency.\n\nThe airline reported it had analyzed financial results from the first three months of 2024, as well as product preferences and expectations, to create a comprehensive plan. Customer sentiment is a major driver behind the change.\n\nSouthwest said in a release that 80% of surveyed customers and 86% of surveyed potential customers preferred assigned seating to open seating. When customers opt for other air carriers over Southwest, most cite open seating as the reason for their decision.\n\nIn addition to assigned seats, Southwest is also designing a section of its cabins to have higher-priced seats with more legroom. These seats are slated to take up about one-third of the seats across the Southwest fleet.\n\nThe new cabin layout will require Federal Aviation Administration approval, and moving to assigned seating will require new procedures for managing that process.\n\nSouthwest said it will have more details on the changes later this year and expects to have them implemented sometime in 2025.\n\nMoving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change. ... Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice,\" Southwest CEO Bob {"uri": "8243663053", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:34:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:34:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:33:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/economy/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-announces-end-open-seating/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Announces the End of Open Seating", "body": "Southwest Airlines is making a major change to its unique business model -- no more open seating.\n\nThe Texas-based airline, which has been known for the open seating method for more than 50 years, announced it will \"redesign the boarding model\" in a statement Thursday.\n\n\"After listening carefully to Customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights... preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred,\" company officials said.\n\nResearch conducted by the company found that 80 percent of Southwest customers and 86 percent of potential customers \"prefer\" an assigned seat.\n\n\"Additionally, Southwest conducted robust operational testing that included live and over 8 million simulation-based boarding trials. The airline is confident that these Customer enhancements will meet expectations and not compromise the airline's operational efficiency,\" the statement added.\n\nIn addition to assigned seating, Southwest is gearing up to transform about one-third of the seats across the airline to premium extra legroom accommodations.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" Southwest president and CEO Bob Jordan said.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders.\"\n\nThe move is already garnering mixed reviews on social media, with some loyal customers reconsidering their allegiance.\n\n\"As a loyal Southwest customer, I hate this,\" wrote one traveler on X. \"\"[T]he whole reason I fly southwest is [because] it's cheap & I can pick my seat!!! If you don't like it, fly on a different airline.\"\n\nAnother customer said the policy change will corrupt the \"social contract.\"\n\n\"Eff. This policy really made Southwest's flights great. Never experienced any crazy passengers on Southwest because the seat-yourself model kept out non-critical thinkers, and there was an understood social contract,\" he wrote on X. \"Now it's going to be {"uri": "8243695947", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:09:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:09:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:08:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/southwest-begin-assigning-seats-192359328.html", "title": "When will Southwest begin assigning seats?", "body": "(NEXSTAR) - Southwest Airlines on Thursday announced plans to begin assigning seats to passengers -- abandoning the open-seating policy that's been a trademark of the carrier for half a century.\n\n\"The airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred,\" reads a media release from Southwest.\n\nIn defending the change, the airline cited \"extensive research\" which included surveys of Southwest customers and \"potential\" Southwest customers, the majority of whom (80% and 86%, respectively) wanted assigned seating. Southwest added that its open-seating plan is \"the number one reason\" customers choose to fly with a competing airline, according to the release.\n\nCan you get compensation if your flight was delayed or canceled by the CrowdStrike outage?\n\nSouthwest's unique seating policy, as it currently exists, initially began as a way to load passengers faster, thereby limiting the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground. It works like this: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. The earliest to check in are placed in an \"A\" boarding group, with \"B\" and \"C\" groups containing those who checked in later.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\nThe change isn't exactly happening overnight, though. In a statement obtained by Nexstar, a Southwest representative confirmed that customers will have some time to get used to the idea.\n\n\"We expect to make bookings available in 2025,\" the representative said in response to a question about the assigned-seating timeline. \"More specifics will be discussed at our Investor Day in September.\"\n\nPan Am is returning to skies in 2025. What's included for $65K?\n\nIn addition to assigned seating, Southwest announced Thursday its plans to begin offering premium seating options and overnight flights, the latter of which are scheduled to begin departing on Feb. 14, 2025.\n\nThese decisions were made to offer \"more choice\" and \"enhance\" value for Southwest travelers, the company says. But of course, the carrier's bottom line is always a consideration.\n\n\"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations -- and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance,\" said Bob Jordan, the president and CEO of Southwest.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 Nexstar Media, Inc. {"uri": "8242973067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:44:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:44:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:42:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://kion546.com/money/cnn-business-consumer/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-is-getting-rid-of-open-seating/", "title": "Southwest Airlines is getting rid of open seating - KION546", "body": "New York (CNN) -- Southwest Airlines is shifting to assigned seats for the first time in its history, a change that will allow the low-fare carrier to charge a premium for some of the seats on its planes.\n\nThe airline will also start offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights for the first time, which it said will improve the efficiency by increasing the use of its aircraft.\n\nSouthwest said customers were clamoring for these changes - when people switch to a competitor from Southwest, the company said the No. 1 reason the unhappy passengers cite is open seating. But the change will also help the company charge some passengers more for their tickets.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest did not give details about when the changes will go into effect, but it said it would be discussed further in September.\n\nThe airline had announced in April that it was looking at a change in its seating policy that has been in effect for its entire 50 year history. Southwest is under pressure from activist investors who have been pushing for changes in management and growth in profitability.\n\nSouthwest has long been known as a low-cost, low-fare carrier, but it has been facing competition from the three other major carriers, American, United and Delta, which get much of their revenue from charging more for premium seating. It also faces growing rivalries on the other end of the spectrum: ultra-low cost carriers, such as Spirit and Frontier, which offer bargain-priced seats for which customers have to pay extra for just about anything including carry on bags.\n\nSouthwest doesn't charge for carry on bags and has long allowed passengers to check two bags for free. The airline also doesn't charge customers to change flights.\n\nThe company made no mention in its statement about whether it will change its baggage or change fee policy. The premium seats, which will offer more legroom, will not be available until 2025 as it will require reconfiguring its planes.\n\nSouthwest used to be the most profitable US airline. But that is no longer the case.\n\nThursday, it reported a 51% drop in profit to $370 million, despite reporting record revenue for the quarter.\n\nAlthough Southwest still has the healthiest credit rating of any US airline, it has been struggling with a number of issues in recent years - some as a result of its own mismanagement, but some because of outside factors and changing industry dynamics.\n\nThe airline went 47 consecutive years without reporting an annual loss - until 2020, when the pandemic nearly halted all demand for air travel.\n\nSouthwest's fleet is made up entirely of Boeing 737 jets. That had reduced its operating costs, because it allowed its pilots to fly any of its planes, giving it a flexibility and efficiency not available to its larger rivals. But it also made it most susceptible to Boeing's substantial problems in recent years - both a 20-month grounding of the 737 Max in 2019 and 2020 following two fatal crashes, and a slowdown in production this year due to concerns about the quality and safety of its planes.\n\nBut its low-cost efforts also hurt Southwest at times, most notably in December 2022, when its suffered a catastrophic service meltdown that caused it to cancel about 17,000 flights, or nearly half of its schedule, during the busy holiday travel period. While other airlines recovered quickly from a winter storm that month, Southwest's computer technology, denounced as \"antiquated\" by its unions, made it difficult for it to schedule its pilots and flight attendants and resume normal operations.\n\nThat meltdown cost Southwest around $1 billion, including a $140 million fine. But it underwent a massive update to its technology since then, and notably, Southwest managed to recover quickly from the global tech outage last week. This time, it was rival Delta that took days to recover.\n\nShares of Southwest (LUV) were down 2% in premarket trading on its news.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional context and developments.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "2024-07-433502880", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:48:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:48:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.inc.com/bill-murphy-jr/southwest-airlines-no-open-seating-assigned-seats-change.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines Just Announced a Giant Change, and 80% of Customers Will Be Very Happy", "body": "For decades, this was the reality at Southwest Airlines.\n\nUnlike almost every other big airline, Southwest was different because it had open seating on all its flights--no assigned seats.\n\nPassengers preferred it, Southwest said, and even chose them specifically because of it. The data backed it up.\n\nBut not anymore. As Southwest announced Thursday morning:\n\n\"After listening carefully to Customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights.\n\nThe airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred.\"\n\nFor passengers and people who follow the airlines, it's hard to overstate how big a change this is. Southwest listed several other key points:\n\nAbout one-third of seats will be in the new extended legroom sections of the cabin. The new layouts will require approval from federal regulators, and so bookings under the new system won't begin until next year.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" said Bob Jordan, Southwest's president, CEO and vice chairman of the board. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice ...\"\n\nSouthwest also said its previously announced new redeye flights are now available for booking.\n\nAs big as these changes to the Southwest cabin experience are, they're not unexpected.\n\nSouthwest has been facing an activist shareholder, a hedge fund that has a nearly $2 billion stake in the company, and has been demanding change--everything from the kinds of changes announced today to the idea of replacing the top leadership like Jordan.\n\nLooking more broadly, it's also part of a trend among all businesses to \"unbundle\" products and services, so that customers who are willing to pay more for a better experience do so--and those who decline don't have their experience subsidized by others.\n\nIn retrospect, Southwest has moved incrementally toward this unbundled model, for example, by adding ways for passengers to pay more to get a higher boarding priority, which theoretically would allow them to choose better seats.\n\nHowever, this was highly imperfect, as customers would reserve multiple seats for other, lower-priority passengers. Reportedly, Southwest Airlines flight attendants were getting tired of being asked to intervene in seat disputes.\n\nThere are still a few other onboard experiences that set Southwest apart from its competitors. The biggest among these might now be the airline's \"bags fly free\" policy, which gives passengers the ability to two checked bags at no additional cost.\n\nSouthwest confirms that this policy remains unchanged. Also, there are no plans to change the airline's food and beverage service, which is limited compared to competitors.\n\nChange is hard in business, especially when you realize that the thing that customers used to love about you might not be so appealing to them anymore.\n\nBut it can happen to any company--and it can be hard to admit to yourself as a leader.\n\nSo, pay attention to Southwest. If you ever find your business in a similar situation, you might be glad to have seen how they handled this big change.", "source": {"uri": "inc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inc.com"}, {"uri": "8243424062", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:51:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:51:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:50:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/travel/12019192/southwest-improved-massive-changes-more-legroom/", "title": "Southwest Airlines makes massive change to business model after 53 years", "body": "GETTING ready for a trip? Thanks to a new Southwest change, it's time to spread your wings -- and your legs.\n\nThe airline has announced plans to eliminate open seating and offer extra legroom on its planes.\n\nThe change comes as pressure mounts on Southwest to change its 53-year-old business model and increase revenue.\n\nThe airline hinted in April that it was considering cabin changes.\n\nCEO Bob Jordan told CNBC that they were considering single-class, open-seating cabins to increase profits.\n\n\"We're looking into new initiatives, things like the way we seat and board our aircraft,\" Jordan said.\n\nCurrently, Southwest offers a single economy class cabin with no seating assignments.\n\nSeats are first-come, first-serve, although the airline does offer early boarding for an extra fee.\n\nSouthwest customers are placed in one of three boarding groups and then assigned a number, which places travelers in a race to get on the plane.\n\nOver the past two years, the budget airline has made changes, such as improved WiFi, in-seat power, and larger oversized bins, in attempts to boost revenue.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" said Bob Jordan in a statement.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice, at the right time, for our customers, our people, and our shareholders.\"\n\nOn top of assigned seats, the airline explained that the premium portion of the cabin would upgrade \"roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\"\n\nLuckily for loyal Southwest fliers, the company will not make any changes to its two free checked bags policy.\n\nThe airline will also be adding new flights to its program, introducing overnight redeye flights.\n\nSouthwest plans to bolster its 24-hour operation with late-night flights starting Valentine's Day 2025.\n\nThe first redeye flights will include routes from Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\n\"Redeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings,\" Southwest explained.\n\n[It will enable] Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without incremental aircraft capital deployment.\"\n\nCustomers can purchase the first flights to offer the extra legroom starting next year.\n\nThe airline is expected to deliver more details about these changes on an investor {"uri": "8243119929", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:17:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:17:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:16:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/business/travel/southwest-get-rid-open-seating-offer-extra-legroom-biggest-shift-histo-rcna163610", "title": "Southwest to get rid of open seating, offer extra legroom in biggest shift in its history", "body": "Southwest Airlines airplanes at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport on May 18, 2024.Gary Hershorn / Getty Images\n\nSouthwest Airlines is ending open seating and will offer extra legroom seats on its airplanes as mounting pressure on the carrier to increase revenue prompts the biggest changes to its business model in its 53 years of flying.\n\nThe airline plans to start selling the first flights that will offer extra legroom next year, it said Thursday. It also plans to begin overnight flights, starting in February.\n\nSouthwest executives have said for years that they were studying such changes and hinted in April that the airline was seriously considering assigning seats and offering pricier seats with more legroom. The airline currently puts customers in one of three boarding groups and assigns a number, setting off a mad dash to check in a day before the flight. Customers can get earlier boarding though if they pay for a higher-priced ticket, they'll get a better boarding slot.\n\nWhen travelers choose a competitor over Southwest, the airline found in its research that its open seating model was the No. 1 reason for that choice, the carrier said in a release that outlined the changes. It also said 80% of its own customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in a news release Thursday.\n\nSouthwest did not, however, unveil any changes to its beloved two free checked bags policy.\n\nThe airline is under even more pressure now to segment its product like other airlines after activist investor Elliott Investment Management disclosed in June a nearly $2 billion stake in Southwest and called for new leadership as the carrier underperformed competitors.\n\n\"We will adapt as our customers' needs adapt,\" Jordan said at an industry event last month.\n\nSouthwest said it expects about a third of the seats on its Boeing 737s will offer \"extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\" The Federal Aviation Administration would need to approve the cabin layouts, the airline added.\n\nThe Dallas-based carrier had prided itself and raked in steady profits for most of its more than five decades of flying on its simple business model. Jordan said last month that not assigning seats was easier to offer when planes weren't so full.\n\nAnalysts criticized Southwest for moving too slowly. Rival carriers offer a host of options to upsell customers like extra legroom seats, premium economy or business class. Other airlines, however, like Delta, United and American, four years ago took a cue from Southwest and ended flight change fees for most tickets.\n\nSouthwest will provide more details about the upcoming changes at an investor day at the end of September.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-433252985", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:04:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:04:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:38:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.kob.com/news/business-money/southwest-breaks-with-50-year-tradition-and-will-assign-seats-profit-falls-at-southwest-american/", "title": "Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nThe change in seating policy comes as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": Airline to change rules", "body": "Frequent Southwest Airlines flyers who grew accustomed to the airlines' open seating policy will have to adjust to a new way of flying, as the airline is set to make wholesale changes to its seating policy.\n\nHere's what you need to know.\n\nSouthwest Airlines doesn't use assigned seats or offer first class options, yet.\n\nThe low-cost carrier said it is ditching its decades-long open seating policy and moving to assigned seats and premium seating with extra legroom.\n\n\"Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights,\" read Southwest Airlines' seating announcement. \"The airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred.\n\n\"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest Airlines' press release did not provide a specific start date for its new assigned and premium seating program.\n\nThe press release did indicate that Southwest Airlines officials intend to provide an update during its investor day in late September, meaning changes could take effect immediately thereafter.\n\nSouthwest Airlines' press release doesn't explicitly state how much premium seating will cost you, nor if the airline will offer any special seating deals through its Southwest Airlines Rapid Rewards program.\n\nDamon C. {"uri": "8242963617", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:37:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:37:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:36:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/southwest-airlines-is-getting-rid-of-open-seating/", "title": "Southwest Airlines is getting rid of open seating - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "New York (CNN) -- Southwest Airlines is shifting to assigned seats for the first time in its history, a change that will allow the low-fare carrier to charge a premium for some of the seats on its planes.\n\nThe airline will also start offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights for the first time, which it said will improve the efficiency by increasing the use of its aircraft.\n\nSouthwest said customers were clamoring for these changes - when people switch to a competitor from Southwest, the company said the No. 1 reason the unhappy passengers cite is open seating. But the change will also help the company charge some passengers more for their tickets.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest did not give details about when the changes will go into effect, but it said it would be discussed further in September.\n\nA tectonic shift\n\nThe airline had announced in April that it was looking at a change in its seating policy that has been in effect for its entire 50 year history. Southwest is under pressure from activist investors who have been pushing for changes in management and growth in profitability.\n\nSouthwest has long been known as a low-cost, low-fare carrier, but it has been facing competition from the three other major carriers, American, United and Delta, which get much of their revenue from charging more for premium seating. It also faces growing rivalries on the other end of the spectrum: ultra-low cost carriers, such as Spirit and Frontier, which offer bargain-priced seats for which customers have to pay extra for just about anything including carry on bags.\n\nSouthwest doesn't charge for carry on bags and has long allowed passengers to check two bags for free. The airline also doesn't charge customers to change flights.\n\nThe company made no mention in its statement about whether it will change its baggage or change fee policy. The premium seats, which will offer more legroom, will not be available until 2025 as it will require reconfiguring its planes.\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 CNN. All Rights Reserved. {"uri": "2024-07-433583129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:13:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:13:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:00:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.star-telegram.com/news/local/fort-worth/article290421359.html", "title": "Dallas-based Southwest Airlines making huge change to seating policy. Here's why", "body": "Dallas-based Southwest Airlines is changing its seating policy for the first time in over 50 years.\n\nThe airline announced Thursday morning that it will switch from open to assigned seating and offer premium seating options on all flights. The change comes after over five decades of the open seating policy, which was unique for the airline among its competitors.\n\nThe company said in a press release that the new initiatives are designed to elevate customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive shareholder value.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Bob Jordan, President, CEO and vice chairman of Southwest's board.\n\nSouthwest's change comes after over 8 million simulation-based boarding trials, which showed that a majority of customers prefer assigned seating.\n\nThe research also indicated that the No. 1 reason customers stop flying with Southwest was the open seating policy, the company said. Additionally, Southwest is planning to offer premium, extended legroom to the cabin in \"roughly\" one-third of seats across its fleet.\n\nIn making the assigned seating and premium legroom changes, the company said it expects to broaden its appeal and attract more customers.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" Jordan said.\n\nSouthwest is also expanding its range of services by offering redeye flights.\n\nA redeye is a flight that departs at night and arrives at its destination in the morning.\n\nThe first overnight flights land on February 14, 2025, in five initial nonstop markets:\n\nSouthwest plans to phase in additional redeye flights in the airline's repertoire in the next few years.", "source": {"uri": "star-telegram.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-433265955", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:13:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:13:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:56:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/southwest-breaks-with-50-year-tradition-and-will-assign-seats-profit-falls-at-southwest-american/article_c1788431-13d9-5419-8a80-8a5802203477.html", "title": "Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American", "body": "Southwest Airlines is doing away with a 50-year tradition and plans to start assigning seats\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nThe change in seating policy comes as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
