{"uri": "8243286473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:10:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:10:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:09:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.themanual.com/travel/southwest-airlines-assigned-seats/", "title": "Southwest Airlines switches to assigned seats", "body": "For the past 50 years, Southwest Airlines used an open-seating model, where passengers picked seats on a first-come, first-served basis. Today, the carrier announced that's set to change, as it plans to introduce assigned seats and premium seating options. The announcement coincided with disappointing second-quarter profits, which dropped 46% from a year prior.\n\nSouthwest Airlines changes course based on customer research\n\nBefore making the change, Southwest conducted consumer research, which showed a strong preference for assigned seats. Additionally, the new policy should strengthen revenue and improve financial results.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nAccording to Southwest, \"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat. When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change. By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nBesides that, premium seating options with enhanced legroom cater to another research-based passenger preference. Though cabin designs are yet to be finalized, Southwest plans about one-third of seating fleet-wide to be premium.\n\nBob Jordan, President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board at Southwest, stated, \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders.\"\n\n\"We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver. We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nEditors' Recommendations Luxury in the skies: Alaska Airlines expands first-class and premium seating Save on your getaway: Fiji Airways begins partnership with this U.S. carrier Visiting Sonoma? American reports earnings on Thursday, July 25, 2024.\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nThe change in seating policy comes as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. {"uri": "8243169605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:50:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:50:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:49:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_1f128353-12fa-5a06-8dd2-491e63cd52c7.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nPeople are also reading... Ex-Buffalo Sabres captain Kyle Okposo's thank-you letter to city, franchise North Tonawanda's best days seemed to be past. Now it's not only thriving - it's cool The Foxglove Pub in Hamburg is open again ... and this time the owners plan to keep it that way 97 Rock's 'Slick Tom' Tiberi fired over Facebook meme showing Trump in coffin Henry Nowak, longtime Buffalo congressman and Canisius basketball star, has died Three charged following fights at Williamsville's Old Home Days Mystery still unsolved: Niagara Falls Police conclude probe into Rainbow Bridge crash that killed couple Two charged with making terrorist threats in separate Niagara County cases Where to take out-of-town guests to eat around Buffalo Officials identify woman killed in small plane crash near Youngstown Erie County real estate transactions These 10 Buffalo Bills have the most at stake as training camp begins. Take a look Inside the NHL: A summer look at the Sabres' cap situation, for now and into the future Religious group accused of cult-like tactics seeks to buy former Catholic seminary in Aurora Josh Allen leads a revamped Bills offense in 2024. These five moments are shaping the new approach\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8242835538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:19:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:19:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:19:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://viewfromthewing.com/southwest-launches-redeye-flights-prepares-for-assigned-premium-seats-and-basic-economy/", "title": "Southwest Launches Redeye Flights, Prepares For Assigned Premium Seats And Basic Economy - View from the Wing", "body": "Southwest Airlines holds its second quarter earnings call today, in the face of major revenue disappointments and a campaign by an activist investor to oust current management and force the airline to shift its business model to become more like American Airlines, Delta, and United.\n\nBefore Elliott Capital's near-$2 billion investment, Southwest was already talking up changes to offer more premium products that customers would pay more for. There's been a trend towards premium, and also long haul international, both of which the airline has been unable to take advantage of. Their product and route network haven't aligned with what customers have most wanted to buy.\n\nThey're expected to offer extra legroom seats at the front of the cabin, in what's being referred to as Love Cabin. These seats would be assigned. Southwest could offer blocked middle seats for sale in Love Cabin, along the lines of Frontier, where the airline sells a seat block to both the aisle and middle seat passenger as an option. And they're preparing to increase fleet utilization - cheaper additional flying using current aircraft - by offering redeye flights for the first time. New union contracts now provide for redeye operations, and the airline no longer has to turn their systems off and on in a reset each night which required operations to halt.\n\nWe'll have to wait for details on what kind of basic economy product they might offer as a replacement for their cheapest Wanna Get Away fare. Presumably these passengers would board last and have last choice of seats, and perhaps change restrictions as well. This would likely be a new 'Group D' boarding that permitted only a small personal item, and only one free checked bag.\n\nSouthwest has quietly loaded their first redeye flights into the system. Routes discovered, but not yet announced, so far include:\n\nWe will certainly see Hawaii redeye flights. Currently Southwest can't really sell most connections to the middle of the country and east coast without an overnight stop without flying redeyes.\n\nThe current expectation is that we'll begin seeing extra legroom seats coming quickly - four rows at the front of cabins plus exit row seats available only for those with these seats pre-assigned. Planes could begin reconfiguration as soon as September, and would be rapidly cycled through the fleet over the course of just several months. While I imagine this could slip, there is talk of targeting February 1, 2025 for selling these assigned seats.\n\nThis would mean that Southwest partially abandons 'open seating' and also that those with preboarding would only be permitted to sit behind row four.\n\nSouthwest is also rumored to be eliminating seat saving. No more spreading out bags of donuts on seats so that one passenger can reserve seats for friends and family with lower boarding order, such as basic economy.\n\nIf the airline is going to further monetize its boarding process, it makes no sense to allow one member of a large party to pull everyone else in basic economy forward.", "source": {"uri": "viewfromthewing.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243761118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:26:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:26:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:25:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-announces-assigned-seating-policy-ends-tradition/", "title": "Major Airline Ends Decades-Long Tradition With Huge Policy Shakeup", "body": "Southwest Airlines announced a major policy change Thursday, abandoning their nearly 60-year-long tradition of letting passengers choose their own seats onboard the aircraft.\n\nSouthwest will now follow suit with other major airlines and will begin assigning seats to passengers, according to a press release. The new policies are \"designed to elevate the Customer experience, improve financial performance and drive Shareholder value,\" the release states.\n\nIn addition to assigned seating, the airline is planning to redesign the boarding process, offer premium seats with extra legroom and introduce redeye flights, according to the release\n\nSouthwest said the company came to the decision after conducting research and considering customer feedback. (RELATED: Southwest Airlines To Fire 2,000 Employees, Cancel Service To Four Airports).\n\n\"The airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred,\" the release stated. \"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest Customers, and 86% of potential Customers, prefer an assigned seat.\"\n\nSouthwest believes this switch will \"broaden\" the airline's appeal and \"attract more flying from its current and future Customers.\"\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders. We are excited to incorporate Customer and Employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver,\" Bob Jordan, the President, Vice Chairman of the Board, and CEO of Southwest, said in the press release.\n\nThe major airline is also introducing redeye flights set to begin on Feb. 14, 2025, the release noted. There are five scheduled routes and the airline intends to add more in the future so far, according to the release.\n\nUsers took to Twitter to share their disappointment in the airline's change.\n\n\"Southwest Airlines announcing it will now assign seats has shaken my world to its core,\" Clay Travis, Outkick founder, and radio host, wrote on Twitter. \"But this is going to be a huge mess. Not a fan of the change.\"\n\n\"This is [the] end of an era. {"uri": "8242891071", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:53:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:53:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:52:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/texas/news/southwest-airlines-ends-open-seating-introduces-redeye-flights/", "title": "Southwest Airlines ends open seating, introduces redeye flights", "body": "The Dallas-based airline announced it is putting an end to its open seating policy, will begin offering premium seating and is introducing redeye flight options.\n\nThe airline said it's the next step in a \"continuing transformation,\" to \"elevate the customer experience.\"\n\nAccording to research conducted by Southwest, 80% of customers and 86% of potential customers said they prefer an assigned seat.\n\nIn addition to assigning seats, Southwest will offer premium, extended legroom portions of plane cabins. One-third of seats will offer the extended option.\n\nStarting Thursday, Southwest will begin selling tickets for redeye flights. The first overnight flights will land on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. Southwest said it plans to phase in additional redeye flying in the coming schedules.\n\nLeading the development of these initiatives is Ryan Green, previously the executive vice president, & chief commercial officer. He will take on the new role of executive vice president of commercial transformation.\n\nPresident and CEO of Southwest, Bob Jordan, said this change is part of an upgrade to the airline and to focus on customer expectations.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Bob Jordan, president, CEO, & vice chairman of the board. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders. We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver.\"\n\nIn May, the airline began listing airfares on Google Flights, making it easier for travelers to compare their options on a single dashboard.\n\nA Southwest spokesperson said the move, which the carrier said it's testing, broadens its reach with consumers while allowing {"uri": "8243177102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:55:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:55:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:55:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.stltoday.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_86c52f00-2a75-5e69-9cde-bcc3546ec34c.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nCardinals' TV ratings on record-low pace amid continuing distribution problems: Media Views Tammie Holland, longtime St. Louis radio personality, dies at 53 Third bear sighting reported in southern Illinois, sheriff says Former St. Louis Rams lineman ordered to pay $500,000 to injured worker Woman from Valley Park drowns in Big River trying to help another canoeist Kohn's Kosher Deli facing lawsuit of nearly $150,000 Ranch in Wildwood is sanctuary for abused miniature horses O'Fallon, Mo., woman charged with making politically motivated false child sex abuse claim Messenger: A disturbing twist in the case of security guards who tackled BJC patient St. Louis Public Schools halts hiring over questions on new administrator from Texas BenFred: So, you're looking to trade with the Cardinals. Who are you (realistically) targeting? BenFred: Smart contract stance lets Cardinals be nimble as Goldschmidt tries to salvage season Messenger: He fixed up his mobile home. He made it too nice. The city wants him out. Ankle injury interrupts Tommy Edman's rehab games, delays his return: Cardinals Extra Judge pauses $500 monthly checks to poor St. Louis families\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit in the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started decades ago as a way for the airline to save money by reducing the amount of time it took for a plane to land, load new passengers, and take off again -- turn time, as it is called in the business.\n\nMost airlines assign each passenger to a seat when they buy a ticket. Southwest requires customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure unless they pay extra to guarantee a better place in the boarding line. Those who hate it call it a \"cattle call\" but many Southwest loyalists love it.\n\nHowever, as flights have become more full it has gotten harder to score a window or aisle seat without paying extra. Also, some passengers appear to game the system: They use a wheelchair to get to the gate, where they are given priority in boarding, then miraculously walk off the plane without assistance after the flight.\n\nThe airline said in surveys 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. It said open seating is the top reason that travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nSouthwest also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes over time.\n\nThe changes in seating policy and redeye flights come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nThe airline said it will provide more details about its upcoming changes at an investor day in September.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. Delta, JetBlue and United slipped more than 1%.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. The move will also introduce premium seating that provides extra legroom to passengers, according to a Thursday press release.\n\nSouthwest Airlines also released its second-quarter results for 2024, in which it detailed plans to receive 20 new Boeing 737-8 planes later this year.\n\nThe introduction of assigned seating was hinted at earlier this year by Southwest Airlines CEO Bob Jordan, who said the airline was looking at \"new initiatives\" to satisfy customers. Multiple airlines, such as Delta, United, and Spirit, charge customers extra to choose their seats prior to boarding.\n\nThursday's announcement also revealed the introduction of redeye flights, with these overnight routes beginning in February 2025.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nSouthwest Airlines experienced a net income of $367 million in its second quarter, an improved performance from the $231 million net loss from its previous quarter but still \"short of what we believe we are capable of delivering,\" Jordan said. However, he added that Southwest Airlines is \"excited about what the future holds.\"\n\nIn April, Southwest Airlines announced it would close its operations at four airports, citing its \"disappointing\" performance in the first 2024 quarter. {"uri": "8243557521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:49:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:49:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:48:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.wishtv.com/news/business/southwest-airlines-is-ditching-open-seating/", "title": "Southwest Airlines is ditching open seating", "body": "New York (CNN) -- Southwest Airlines is shifting to assigned seats for the first time in its history, a change that will allow the low-fare carrier to charge a premium for some of the seats on its planes.\n\nThe airline will also start offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights for the first time, which it said will improve the efficiency by increasing the use of its aircraft.\n\nSouthwest said customers were clamoring for these changes - when people switch to a competitor from Southwest, the company said the No. 1 reason the unhappy passengers cite is open seating. But the change will also help the company charge some passengers more for their tickets.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest did not give details about when the changes will go into effect, but it said it would be discussed further in September.\n\nThe airline had announced in April that it was looking at a change in its seating policy that has been in effect for its entire 50 year history. Southwest is under pressure from activist investors who have been pushing for changes in management and growth in profitability.\n\nSouthwest has long been known as a low-cost, low-fare carrier, but it has been facing competition from the three other major carriers, American, United and Delta, which get much of their revenue from charging more for premium seating. It also faces growing rivalries on the other end of the spectrum: ultra-low cost carriers, such as Spirit and Frontier, which offer bargain-priced seats for which customers have to pay extra for just about anything including carry on bags.\n\nSouthwest doesn't charge for carry on bags and has long allowed passengers to check two bags for free. The airline also doesn't charge customers to change flights.\n\nThe company made no mention in its statement about whether it will change its baggage or change fee policy. The premium seats, which will offer more legroom, will not be available until 2025 as it will require reconfiguring its planes.\n\nSouthwest announced in April that it would be cutting flights from Indianapolis to four destinations, Cozumel International Airport in Mexico and George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston. The company blamed the decision on a first-quarter loss of $231 million and a delayed delivery of Boeing 737 Max 8 planes.", "source": {"uri": "wishtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WISH-TV | {"uri": "8243156905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:41:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:41:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:40:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://dallas.culturemap.com/news/travel/southwest-airlines-assign-seats/", "title": "Dallas' Southwest Airlines changes longtime policy, will assign seats", "body": "Dallas-based Southwest Airlines Co. is doing the unthinkable: It will start to assign seats.\n\nThe airline has been known for its open seating model for more than 50 years, but according to a release, customers have stated a preference for seat assignments, and that is what Southwest will do.\n\nAs part of this transformation, the airline will also offer premium seating options on all flights, redesign the boarding model, and introduce redeye flying.\n\nDuring its quarterly financial results in April, the airline shared that it was studying product preferences and expectations, including onboard seating.\n\nAssigned and Premium Seating\n\nAfter listening carefully to Customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest determined that 80 percent of current customers and 86 percent of potential customers preferred an assigned seat. They discovered that when customers chose a competitor, open seating was cited as the number one reason for the change.\n\nIn addition to assigning seats, Southwest will offer a premium, extended legroom portion of the cabin, \"strongly preferred\" by many customers. While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\n\nThe decision to update the seating and boarding model is part of Southwest's ongoing modernization efforts. During the past two years, they've made improvements such as faster WiFi, in-seat power, and larger overhead bins. Work is underway on a refreshed cabin design, including new, more comfortable Recaro seats.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" said Bob Jordan, President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders.\"\n\nRedeye Flights Now for Sale\n\nSouthwest is also adding 24-hour operation capabilities with the introduction of overnight, redeye flights. Booking on initial routes is available today through Southwest.com, with the first overnight flights landing on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets:\n\nSouthwest plans to phase in additional redeye flying in the carrier's coming schedules as part of its multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation.\n\nRedeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings, enabling Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without incremental aircraft capital deployment.\n\nNew EVP Commercial Transformation\n\nGiven the significance of the changes, Ryan Green, previously Executive Vice President, & Chief Commercial Officer, will take on the new role of Executive Vice President Commercial Transformation, leading development and rollout of these and other commercial initiatives already underway. Green has deep knowledge of Customer trends and currently leads the work on cabin transformation. He previously directed efforts to transform Southwest Airlines' Rapid Rewards\u00ae loyalty program and the digital Customer experience. He reports to President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board Bob Jordan in this new role.\n\nThe Company will share further details about product designs, cabin layout, timing, and incremental financial value at its Investor Day in late September. Founded in 1971, Southwest Airlines Co. operates at 121 airports across 11 countries.", "source": {"uri": "dallas.culturemap.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CultureMap Dallas"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8243254999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:48:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:48:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:47:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://abc7.com/southwest-airlines-does-away-with-open-seating-biggest-change-in-5/15094313/", "title": "Southwest Airlines does away with open seating, biggest change in 53 years", "body": "After 53 years offering passengers the ability to choose their own seats, Southwest Airlines is ushering in a new era for its boarding process and will be assigning seats, as well as offering premium seating on all flights.\n\nThe Dallas-based carrier announced several new initiatives on Thursday, billing the redesigned boarding model as \"enhancements to transform customer experience and improve financial performance,\" and stating in a press release that adding assigned seats and premium seating meets \"evolving customer preferences.\"\n\nSouthwest president and CEO Bob Jordan previously hinted at the possible change back in April, saying at the time that the move to \"assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company.\"\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" said Jordan, who also serves as vice chairman of the board. \"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations -- and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nThe company has not yet said when the seating changes will go into effect, but plans to provide more details on the product designs, cabin layout and timing at its Investor Day in late September.\n\nAny new cabin layout in this seating transformation will need to undergo approvals from the Federal Aviation Administration.\n\nSouthwest conducted \"robust operational testing\" of both live and more than 8 million simulation-based boarding trials, citing research that showed 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" the company noted. \"The airline is confident that these customer enhancements will meet expectations and not compromise the airline's operational efficiency.\"\n\nThe specific cabin layout details are still in design, but Southwest said it \"expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\"\n\nIn the last two years, Southwest's modernization efforts have included enhancements to other onboard offerings such as faster WiFi, in-seat power, larger overhead bins and more comfortable RECARO seats.\n\nIn addition to the seating changes, Southwest also announced it is officially adding 24-hour operation capabilities with overnight redeye flights \"to further optimize the network and increase aircraft utilization.\"\n\nBooking on initial routes is available starting Thursday, with the first overnight flights landing on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nThursday's announcements came in tandem with the airline's second quarter financial results, which fell short of expectations, according to Jordan.\n\nSouthwest's RASM (Revenue per Available Seat Mile), which is a measure of total revenue from each seat flown per mile, regardless of whether it's empty or full, has decreased by 3.8% year-over-year.\n\nThe CEO said the airline is \"taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives\" to help with financial top and bottom line growth.\n\n\"As we announced this morning, our implementation of assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade to the Customer Experience, one that research shows Customers overwhelmingly prefer,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "abc7.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC7"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jordan"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Jordan"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laser", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8243320053", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:36:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:36:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:33:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/no-more-group-southwest-airlines-145715883.html", "title": "No more \"A\" group? Southwest Airlines plans to switch to assigned seating, other changes", "body": "After more than 50 years, Southwest Airlines is getting rid of its open seating policy. The Dallas-based airline announced Thursday it would be scrapping its open seating policy in favor of assigned seating. The shift more closely aligns with the changing consumer preferences.\n\nThe implementation of assigned seating is just one among the handful of changes Southwest detailed in its recent press release. Here's what we know.\n\nPeople are also reading: Austin-Bergstrom ranks 10th best in the U.S., only Texas airport to make new list\n\nIn a press release Thursday, Southwest acknowledged \"preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred.\" The airline hopes moving to assigned seats and revamping its boarding process will broaden Southwest's appeal to both new and existing customers: Research found 80% of current Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seating.\n\nThe airline did not provide an exact date for the switch.\n\nIn addition to assigned seating, Southwest is also rolling out premium seating options on all flights, and introducing red-eye flights.\n\n\"While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft,\" the airline said.\n\nSouthwest already unveiled a cabin refresh earlier this year and is in the middle of upgrading its fleet with changes announced in 2022, including in-seat USB charging and stronger Wi-Fi.\n\nSouthwest said the changes are \"designed to elevate the customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive shareholder value\" without sacrificing operational efficiency.\n\nThe airline reported it had analyzed financial results from the first three months of 2024, as well as product preferences and expectations, to create a comprehensive plan. The airline will share the details of the plan during its Investor Day in late September.\n\n-- USA TODAY reporter Eve Chen contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8243430007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:56:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:56:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:55:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/when-will-southwest-airlines-start-assigning-seats/3500549/", "title": "When will Southwest start assigning seats? What to know after airline announces big change", "body": "Southwest Airlines has been known for its unique \"open boarding\" model for more than 50 years.\n\nOne of the most famous features of Southwest Airlines is about to change.\n\nIn an announcement Thursday, the company said it will \"redesign the boarding model\" by eliminating open seating and instead move forward with assigned seats and premium seating options. The airline also plans to add overnight redeye flight routes, the announcement said.\n\n\"After listening carefully to customers and conducting extensive research, Southwest decided it will assign seats and offer premium seating options on all flights,\" the announcement said. \"The airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred.\"\n\nOfficials began studying customer preferences and expectations around the onboarding process in April, the announcement said, with the new changes designed to \"elevate the customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive Shareholder value.\"\n\nThe airline said it will release more details about the plan, including a timeline, during an investor meeting in September.\n\nFollowing the announcement, here's what we know right now.\n\nThe decision was based on customer preference, the airline said.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest Customers, and 86% of potential Customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" the announcement said.\n\nThe announcement went on to say that customers who stopped flying Southwest and instead chose to fly with a competitor citied open seating as the top reason for the change.\n\n\"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers,\" the announcement added.\n\nThe company also said the changes were part of \"modernization efforts\" part of already implemented improvements, including faster Wi-Fi, in-seat power chargers and larger overhead bins.\n\nAccording to the announcement, Southwest Airlines will move forward with assigning seats \"on all flights.\"\n\nThe airline will also begin offering \"premium extended legroom\" in some parts of the cabin, the announcement said, though cabin layout details were still in design.\n\nOfficials in the announcement said a \"refreshed\" cabin design was underway, with \"new, more comfortable RECARO seats.\"\n\nMore details about the changes regarding product designs, cabin layout, timing and more will be announced in late September, the airline said, adding that the move to assigned seating will be \"significant.\"\n\n\"In addition to incorporating new technologies and procedures for a seamless transition, the new cabin layout will require approvals from the Federal Aviation Administration,\" the airline said.\n\nAccording to the announcement, Southwest expects to make bookings available on the new layouts in 2025.\n\nBooking on initial routes for overnight flights begins Thursday, the announcement said, with the first overnight flight set to land on Valentine's Day of 2025 in five markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nThe plan is to phase in additional overnight flights {"uri": "2024-07-433577544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:08:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:08:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.consumeraffairs.com/news/southwest-airlines-to-make-impressive-consumer-facing-changes-072524.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines to make impressive consumer-facing changes", "body": "Southwest Airlines says enough is enough, and after seeing the airline industry catch far too much flack over poor customer service, it's making several new initiatives designed to elevate the customer experience.\n\nIt plans to assign seats, and introduce - get this -- redeye flights as part of its ongoing commitment to product evolution.\n\nThe airline says that while you might not think they pay attention to every little thing travelers say about them, they do. And here's what they saw and what they're going to start doing as early as this fall:\n\nAssigned and Premium Seating\n\nOpen seating has been a hallmark of Southwest for a long time, but unfortunately, some travelers have ruined the experience for the rest of us. Recently, one family put grandma in a wheelchair so she - and the entire family - could board first and have their choice of seats. No mas. In doing its homework, Southwest noted that customer preferences have evolved with more people taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred.\n\nOpen-seating has cost the airline dearly. It said that when a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change. It feels that assigned seating will broaden its appeal and encourage more current and future customers to fly Southwest.\n\nAnd, like other airlines, there will be an option to upgrade to extended legroom seating, too. It's too early to tell how many of those seats will be available per plane because cabin layout details are still in design, but Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom.\n\nRedeye flights for sale\n\nRedeye flights are a good thing for the airlines that have them - increased aircraft utilization and lower operating costs. They're good for travelers, too, because they are usually cheaper, a fact not lost on Southwest.\n\nWith that knowledge well in hand, the airline is adding 24-hour operation capabilities with the introduction of overnight flights beginning Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nAfter those are off the ground and all the kinks worked out, Southwest plans to phase in additional redeye flying as part of its multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation.\n\nSouthwest said that redeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is a win-win. The traveler gets a good deal and redeye flights are expected to provide increased revenue and cost savings. \"enabling Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without incremental aircraft capital deployment.\"\n\nWill this mean that other airlines are going to start paying more attention to what consumers give a darn about? {"uri": "2024-07-433404626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:15:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:15:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:15:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.travelweekly.com/Travel-News/Airline-News/Southwest-will-scrap-open-seating", "title": "Southwest will adopt assigned seating and add extra-legroom seats", "body": "Southwest will implement assigned seats, ending the open-boarding policy that has been one of the airline's defining features.\n\nSouthwest will also redesign its cabins to add extra-legroom seats, which will encompass approximately one-third of all seats.\n\nThe airline expects to open bookings for the assigned-seating system sometime in 2025. The airline added that details about seating products -- including cabin layout, the timing of cabin conversions and how much incremental revenue will be generated -- will be provided at a September investor day event. Cabin reconfigurations will require FAA approval.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" CEO Bob Jordan said Thursday. \"Although our unique open-seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people and our shareholders. We are excited to incorporate customer and employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver.\"\n\nSouthwest had telegraphed plans to begin assigning seats, as well as potential considerations for cabin reconfigurations, in late April. The moves have been spurred by the airline's underperformance financially compared to its primary competitors, especially United and Delta.\n\nA consumer shift toward premium seats since the pandemic is a key reason for Southwest's anemic financial performance in recent years.\n\nSouthwest is also facing pressure from activist investment firm Elliott Management, which took an 11% stake in the company in June and called for commercial changes as well as the replacement of Jordan and board chairman Gary Kelly. Jordan refused to step down.\n\nSouthwest said Thursday that it has conducted over 8 million simulation-based boarding trials. In addition, airline research indicates that more 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the No. 1 reason for the change,\" the airline said. \"By moving to an assigned-seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nUpending its boarding process and adding extra-legroom seats aren't the only initiatives Southwest announced Thursday.\n\nSouthwest will add red-eye flights\n\nThe carrier also unveiled a Valentine's Day 2025 launch date for its long-planned inception of red-eye flying. Tickets for the five initial redeye flights are now on sale. The routes include Las Vegas-Baltimore, Las Vegas-Orlando, Los Angeles-Baltimore, Nashville-Baltimore and Phoenix-Baltimore.\n\nThe airline plans to gradually phase in more overnight flights as part of a multiyear transformation to a 24-hour operation. Southwest said that the combination of red-eye flying and turn-time reduction will enable nearly all new capacity over the coming three years to be implemented without additional expenditures on aircraft.\n\nTo facilitate the various new commercial initiatives, Southwest has created a new position called executive vice president of transformation. Southwest will also begin to offer another option for passengers: a premium, extended legroom option.\n\nFederal regulators are raising scrutiny of Southwest Airlines after a series of troubling incidents\n\n\"The decision to update the seating and boarding model is part of Southwest's ongoing modernization efforts. {"uri": "2024-07-433261038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:08:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:08:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:43:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.travelandtourworld.com/news/article/southwest-airlines-unveils-new-initiatives-to-revolutionize-customer-experience/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Unveils New Initiatives To Revolutionize Customer Experience", "body": "Southwest Airlines unveils a major transformation with new customer-focused upgrades, including assigned seating and redeye flights, to enhance service and financial performance.\n\nSouthwest Airlines Co. (NYSE: LUV) is advancing its strategic evolution by unveiling a series of new measures aimed at enhancing the customer experience, boosting financial results, and increasing shareholder returns. The airline is initiating several changes, including assigned seating, premium seating options, a revamped boarding process, and the introduction of overnight flights. This initiative comes as part of Southwest's commitment to continual product development, as evidenced by discussions during its April financial disclosures where it revealed ongoing evaluations of customer seating preferences and expectations. These innovations are anticipated to not only meet customer demands but also to generate additional revenue and fortify the airline's financial health. More comprehensive details regarding these transformational commercial strategies and their expected impacts on operational efficacy and capital management will be shared at Southwest's Investor Day in late September.\n\nAssigned and Premium Seating\n\nIn response to detailed customer feedback and extensive research, Southwest has resolved to implement assigned seating across all its flights and introduce a premium seating option. Historically celebrated for its unique open seating approach for over five decades, the airline recognizes that customer preferences have shifted, particularly among passengers on longer flights who favor assigned seating. The airline's extensive evaluations, including live experiments and over 8 million simulated boarding processes, assure that these new changes will satisfy customer expectations without compromising operational effectiveness.\n\nResearch distinctly shows a strong preference for assigned seating, with 80% of existing Southwest customers and 86% of prospective customers favoring this model. The lack of assigned seating has been frequently cited as a primary reason for customers choosing other airlines. By adopting assigned seating, Southwest aims to expand its customer base and enhance its appeal to both existing and potential flyers.\n\nMoreover, the airline plans to introduce a premium section with extra legroom in about one-third of its seats, aligning with industry standards for narrowbody aircraft seating. While details of the cabin layout are still being finalized, this addition reflects the significant customer preference for enhanced comfort during flights.\n\nThese updates are integral to Southwest's broader modernization agenda, which over the past two years has included onboard enhancements like quicker WiFi, in-seat power options, and larger overhead bins. The modernization will continue with a revamped cabin design featuring new, more comfortable RECARO seats. By offering both assigned and premium seating options, Southwest aims to provide customers with greater choice and reinforce the airline's commitment to delivering exceptional value.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" said Bob Jordan, President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders. We are excited to incorporate Customer and Employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver. We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nSouthwest Airlines is expanding its service offerings to include 24-hour operations with the launch of overnight redeye flights. Customers can now book these flights for routes starting on Valentine's Day 2025, initially available between Las Vegas and Baltimore, Las Vegas and Orlando, Los Angeles and Baltimore, Los Angeles and Nashville, and Phoenix and Baltimore. This move marks the beginning of Southwest's strategic transition to a full 24-hour operation model. Future schedules will incorporate more redeye flights, enhancing the airline's operational flexibility and service coverage. This initiative is expected to generate additional revenue and cost savings through technological advancements and streamlined procedures, which will support the airline's capacity expansion over the next three years without the need for additional aircraft investment.\n\nNew Leadership Role to Spearhead Initiatives\n\nIn light of these significant operational changes, Ryan Green, who has served as Executive Vice President and Chief Commercial Officer, will assume a new position as Executive Vice President of Commercial Transformation. In this role, Green will oversee the implementation of these new services as well as other ongoing commercial projects. His extensive experience with customer engagement and his previous leadership over the cabin redesign and enhancement of the Southwest Airlines Rapid Rewards\u00ae loyalty program, as well as the digital customer interface, positions him well for this role. He will report directly to Bob Jordan, the President, CEO, and Vice Chairman of the Board, in his new capacity.\n\n\"I'm eager to lead this next step in our transformation to serve our Customers with an even better Southwest. In addition to meeting the evolving needs of Customers and fostering more loyalty, these changes are expected to generate additional revenue as we capitalize on greater demand for Southwest Airlines and offer Customers the ability to purchase premium seating options,\" Green said. \"Together, these strategic initiatives play an integral role in the airline's comprehensive strategy to meet Customer needs and enhance Shareholder value, while maintaining the unique Culture, Hospitality, and flexibility that make Southwest - Southwest.\"\n\nSouthwest Airlines will provide more detailed information about its new product designs, cabin layouts, scheduling, and the projected financial benefits at its upcoming Investor Day in late September. The shift towards assigned and premium seating marks a major transformation for the airline. This transition will not only involve the introduction of new technologies and procedures to ensure smooth operations but will also require regulatory approvals from the Federal Aviation Administration. The airline anticipates making these new seating options available for booking in 2025.\n\nGary Kelly, Executive Chairman of the Board, said, \"The Board fully supports these efforts to usher in a new era for Southwest Airlines, and we have the ultimate confidence in Bob and our Leadership Team to design and deliver an experience that is unique and true to our Southwest Legacy.\"", "source": {"uri": "8243331728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:42:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:42:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:42:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.mlive.com/news/2024/07/southwest-airlines-moving-to-assigned-seating-as-part-of-brand-revamp.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines moving to assigned seating as part of brand revamp", "body": "DALLAS -- After more than 50 years of offering open seating on its flights, Southwest Airlines announced Thursday it is moving to assigned seating. While a timetable was not released for when the switch will take place, executives say more information will be released at a shareholders meeting in September.\n\nSouthwest says it conducted a tremendous amount of research ahead of making the decision to assign seats and customer feedback showed the company the option is something guests want. Research showed that 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer to have an assigned seat. The company also found the number one reason why customers choose to stop flying Southwest is because of the open seating policy.\n\nCurrently, customers who fly with Southwest must \"check-in\" for their flight 24 hours before the scheduled departure time. Once you check-in, you're assigned a boarding number and once the flight starts boarding, you are allowed to board the plane based on which number you have. Once you're on the plane, you're free to pick any open seat on the plane.\n\nPassengers who end up at the back of the line often end up having to sit separately from those who are traveling in the same party as them.\n\nCustomers who pay a premium or have elevated status with the Southwest rewards program have the option of checking in earlier, which supposedly gives the customer a better shot at boarding the plane earlier than others.\n\nThe company is also reworking the seating arrangements on planes in order to add seating that offers extra legroom. Those seats will be available for customers to purchase at a premium as well.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Bob Jordan, President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders.\"\n\nOnce the new seating is installed across the fleet, Southwest expects one-third of the seats it offers will feature the extra legroom.\n\nThe changes in offerings for guests comes at a time when the company is also in the midst of a downturn in revenue. According to the Associated Press, Southwest reported its second-quarter profit dropped 46% year-over-year, to $367 million.", "source": {"uri": "mlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "mlive"}, {"uri": "8243233315", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:33:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:33:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:32:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Travel/southwest-airlines-moves-assigned-seats-adds-premium-cabin/story?id=112261721", "title": "Southwest Airlines moves to assigned seats, adds premium cabin with more legroom, redeye flights", "body": "The Dallas-based carrier will share more comprehensive details in September.\n\nAfter 53 years offering passengers the ability to choose their own seats, Southwest Airlines is ushering in a new era for its boarding process and will be assigning seats, as well as offering premium seating on all flights.\n\nThe Dallas-based carrier announced several new initiatives on Thursday, billing the redesigned boarding model as \"enhancements to transform customer experience and improve financial performance,\" and stating in a press release that adding assigned seats and premium seating meets \"evolving customer preferences.\"\n\nSouthwest president and CEO Bob Jordan previously hinted at the possible change back in April, saying at the time that the move to \"assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company.\"\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" said Jordan, who also serves as vice chairman of the board. \"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations -- and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nThe company has not yet said when the seating changes will go into effect, but plans to provide more details on the product designs, cabin layout and timing at its Investor Day in late September.\n\nAny new cabin layout in this seating transformation will need to undergo approvals from the Federal Aviation Administration.\n\nSouthwest conducted \"robust operational testing\" of both live and more than 8 million simulation-based boarding trials, citing research that showed 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" the company noted. \"The airline is confident that these customer enhancements will meet expectations and not compromise the airline's operational efficiency.\"\n\nThe specific cabin layout details are still in design, but Southwest said it \"expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\"\n\nIn the last two years, Southwest's modernization efforts have included enhancements to other onboard offerings such as faster WiFi, in-seat power, larger overhead bins and more comfortable RECARO seats.\n\nIn addition to the seating changes, Southwest also announced it is officially adding 24-hour operation capabilities with overnight redeye flights \"to further optimize the network and increase aircraft utilization.\"\n\nBooking on initial routes is available starting Thursday, with the first overnight flights landing on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nThursday's announcements came in tandem with the airline's second quarter financial results, which fell short of expectations, according to Jordan.\n\nSouthwest's RASM (Revenue per Available Seat Mile), which is a measure of total revenue from each seat flown per mile, regardless of whether it's empty or full, has decreased by 3.8% year-over-year.\n\nThe CEO said the airline is \"taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives\" to help with financial top and bottom line growth.\n\n\"As we announced this morning, our implementation of assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade to the Customer Experience, one that research shows Customers overwhelmingly prefer,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "abcnews.go.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3568627450980393, "wgt": 186, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243294726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:16:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:16:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:15:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/southwest-airlines-getting-rid-open-110624863.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines is getting rid of open seating", "body": "Southwest Airlines is shifting to assigned seats for the first time in its history, a change that will allow the low-fare carrier to charge a premium for some of the seats on its planes.\n\nThe airline will also start offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights for the first time, which it said will improve the efficiency by increasing the use of its aircraft.\n\nSouthwest said customers were clamoring for these changes - when people switch to a competitor from Southwest, the company said the No. 1 reason the unhappy passengers cite is open seating. But the change will also help the company charge some passengers more for their tickets.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest did not give details about when the changes will go into effect, but it said it would be discussed further in September.\n\nThe airline had announced in April that it was looking at a change in its seating policy that has been in effect for its entire 50 year history. Southwest is under pressure from activist investors who have been pushing for changes in management and growth in profitability.\n\nSouthwest has long been known as a low-cost, low-fare carrier, but it has been facing competition from the three other major carriers, American, United and Delta, which get much of their revenue from charging more for premium seating. It also faces growing rivalries on the other end of the spectrum: ultra-low cost carriers, such as Spirit and Frontier, which offer bargain-priced seats for which customers have to pay extra for just about anything including carry on bags.\n\nSouthwest doesn't charge for carry on bags and has long allowed passengers to check two bags for free. The airline also doesn't charge customers to change flights.\n\nThe company made no mention in its statement about whether it will change its baggage or change fee policy. The premium seats, which will offer more legroom, will not be available until 2025 as it will require reconfiguring its planes.\n\nSouthwest used to be the most profitable US airline. But that is no longer the case.\n\nThursday, it reported a 51% drop in adjusted profit to $370 million, despite reporting record revenue for the quarter that was boosted by strong passenger traffic.\n\nBut this has been a tough environment for US airlines to make money. Significant increases in labor costs and higher fuel prices, two of the largest expenses in the industry, have eaten into profits. And relatively low average fares have exacerbated the damage.\n\nRival American Airlines also reported its profit fell 44% in the second quarter, despite its own record revenue.\n\nAlthough Southwest still has the healthiest credit rating of any US airline, it has been struggling with a number of issues in recent years - some as a result of its own mismanagement, but some because of outside factors and changing industry dynamics.\n\nShares of Southwest (LUV) were down more than 4% in premarket trading on its news.\n\nThe airline went 47 consecutive years without reporting an annual loss - until 2020, when the pandemic nearly halted all demand for air travel.\n\nSouthwest's fleet is made up entirely of Boeing 737 jets. That had reduced its operating costs, because it allowed its pilots to fly any of its planes, giving it a flexibility and efficiency not available to its larger rivals. But it also made it most susceptible to Boeing's substantial problems in recent years - both a 20-month grounding of the 737 Max in 2019 and 2020 following two fatal crashes, and a slowdown in production this year due to concerns about the quality and safety of its planes.\n\nBut its low-cost efforts also hurt Southwest at times, most notably in December 2022, when its suffered a catastrophic service meltdown that caused it to cancel about 17,000 flights, or nearly half of its schedule, during the busy holiday travel period. While other airlines recovered quickly from a winter storm that month, Southwest's computer technology, denounced as \"antiquated\" by its unions, made it difficult for it to schedule its pilots and flight attendants and resume normal operations.\n\nSouthwest made changes in its software and operations in the wake of those service issues. And last week, as many of the world's airlines were forced to cancel 5,000 flights in a single day due to a flawed software update from cyber security firm CrowdStrike, Southwest was one of the few carriers that avoided the issue and did not have to cancel flights. This time it was rival Delta Air Lines that suffered the service meltdown.\n\nBut that December 2022 meltdown cost Southwest around $1 billion, including a $140 million fine from the Department of Transportation. And it resulted in a loss in the fourth quarter of 2022 as well as the first quarter of 2023 as passengers were reluctant to book on airline in the immediate aftermath of the service problems.\n\nThe company reported losses in the fourth quarter of 2023 and first quarter of 2024 as well amid higher labor and fuel costs. Losing money in four of six quarters before the most recent period is a stunning and unwanted reversal of fortunes for Southwest. The airline had previously posted losses only during the pandemic, Great Recession and after the September 11 terrorist attacks - even while its rivals were flying in and out of bankruptcy. It also brought unwanted attention from activists investors at Elliott Investment Management, which announced in June it had taken a $1.9 billion stake in the airline and called for management changes.\n\nSouthwest has also gotten unwanted attention from the Federal Aviation Administration, which announced earlier this month it is stepping up oversight of its operations due to a number of potentially dangerous incidents involving its planes in recent months.\n\nIn March, a Southwest jet veered off course and had a close call with an air traffic control tower during an attempted landing at New York's LaGuardia Airport. In April, a plane plunged to within 400 feet of the surface of the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Hawaii. In June another plane came within 525 feet of the ground over an Oklahoma town when it was still nine miles away from the Oklahoma City airport. And later that month a plane took off on a closed runway at the airport in Portland Maine which had a repair vehicle on it that had to race to get out of its way. Earlier this month, a plane got within 150 feet of the ground when it was still five miles away from the airport in Tampa, according to data from Flightradar24.\n\n\"The FAA has increased oversight of Southwest Airlines to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations,\" the agency said in a statement.\n\nSouthwest said it has formed an internal team to also look at the incidents.\n\n\"Southwest is working closely with the Federal Aviation Administration in the review of recent events,\" it said.\n\nCNN's Ross Levitt, Gregory Wallace, Chris Boyette and Pete Muntean contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! Finance"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delta_Air_Lines", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Delta Air Lines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8242874577", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:44:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:44:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:42:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/25/southwest-airlines-luv-earnings-q2-2024.html", "title": "Southwest profit falls 46% as airline takes 'urgent' steps to increase revenue", "body": "Southwest Airlines airplanes are serviced at their gates at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport on May 18, 2024, in Fort Lauderdale, Florida.\n\nSouthwest Airlines on Thursday forecast a potential drop in unit revenue for the third quarter as an oversupplied U.S. market has forced airlines to discount tickets during what is usually the most lucrative period of the year.\n\nSouthwest said unit revenue for the current quarter could fall as much as 2% over last year and non-fuel costs could rise as much as 13%, with higher costs weighing on the airline through the end of 2024.\n\nHere is how Southwest performed in the second quarter compared with Wall Street expectations, according to consensus estimates from LSEG:\n\nSouthwest said its second-quarter revenue rose 4.5% from last year to $7.35 billion, a record, but its profit dropped more than 46% to $367 million. Revenue per available seat mile, a gauge airline pricing power, fell 3.8%, roughly in line with Southwest's reduced forecast last month.\n\n\"Our second quarter performance was impacted by both external and internal factors and fell short of what we believe we are capable of delivering,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in an earnings release.\n\nAdjusting for one-time items, Southwest reported per-share earnings of 58 cents a share, above analysts' expectations.\n\nThe airline is in the middle of an overhaul as pressure mounts from investors to do more increase revenue. Elliott Investment Management disclosed a nearly $2 billion stake in the carrier last month and called for a leadership change.\n\nEarlier Thursday, Southwest announced that it will do away with its open seating plan and offer some seats on its Boeing aircraft that have extra legroom and add overnight flights, the biggest changes to its business model in its more than five decades of flying. The changes, which start next year, would make Southwest more like its network carrier rivals.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives that are designed to drive meaningful top and bottom-line growth,\" Jordan said.", "source": {"uri": "cnbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNBC"},
