{"uri": "2024-07-433425793", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:35:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:35:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:20:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.wtva.com/news/national/southwest-airlines-is-getting-rid-of-open-seating/article_ffa36951-1459-5498-90ca-3ee2360f59c6.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines is getting rid of open seating", "body": "New York (CNN) -- Southwest Airlines is shifting to assigned seats for the first time in its history, a change that will allow the low-fare carrier to charge a premium for some of the seats on its planes.\n\nThe airline will also start offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights for the first time, which it said will improve the efficiency by increasing the use of its aircraft.\n\nSouthwest said customers were clamoring for these changes - when people switch to a competitor from Southwest, the company said the No. 1 reason the unhappy passengers cite is open seating. But the change will also help the company charge some passengers more for their tickets.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nSouthwest did not give details about when the changes will go into effect, but it said it would be discussed further in September.\n\nA tectonic shift\n\nThe airline had announced in April that it was looking at a change in its seating policy that has been in effect for its entire 50 year history. Southwest is under pressure from activist investors who have been pushing for changes in management and growth in profitability.\n\nSouthwest has long been known as a low-cost, low-fare carrier, but it has been facing competition from the three other major carriers, American, United and Delta, which get much of their revenue from charging more for premium seating. It also faces growing rivalries on the other end of the spectrum: ultra-low cost carriers, such as Spirit and Frontier, which offer bargain-priced seats for which customers have to pay extra for just about anything including carry on bags.\n\nSouthwest doesn't charge for carry on bags and has long allowed passengers to check two bags for free. The airline also doesn't charge customers to change flights.\n\nThe company made no mention in its statement about whether it will change its baggage or change fee policy. The premium seats, which will offer more legroom, will not be available until 2025 as it will require reconfiguring its planes.\n\nAn ailing business\n\nSouthwest used to be the most profitable US airline. But that is no longer the case.\n\nThursday, it reported a 51% drop in adjusted profit to $370 million, despite reporting record revenue for the quarter that was boosted by strong passenger traffic.\n\nBut this has been a tough environment for US airlines to make money. Significant increases in labor costs and higher fuel prices, two of the largest expenses in the industry, have eaten into profits. And relatively low average fares have exacerbated the damage.\n\nRival American Airlines also reported its profit fell 44% in the second quarter, despite its own record revenue.\n\nAlthough Southwest still has the healthiest credit rating of any US airline, it has been struggling with a number of issues in recent years - some as a result of its own mismanagement, but some because of outside factors and changing industry dynamics.\n\nShares of Southwest (LUV) were down more than 4% in premarket trading on its news.\n\nEnding five decades of precedent\n\nThe airline went 47 consecutive years without reporting an annual loss - until 2020, when the pandemic nearly halted all demand for air travel.\n\nSouthwest's fleet is made up entirely of Boeing 737 jets. That had reduced its operating costs, because it allowed its pilots to fly any of its planes, giving it a flexibility and efficiency not available to its larger rivals. But it also made it most susceptible to Boeing's substantial problems in recent years - both a 20-month grounding of the 737 Max in 2019 and 2020 following two fatal crashes, and a slowdown in production this year due to concerns about the quality and safety of its planes.\n\nBut its low-cost efforts also hurt Southwest at times, most notably in December 2022, when its suffered a catastrophic service meltdown that caused it to cancel about 17,000 flights, or nearly half of its schedule, during the busy holiday travel period. While other airlines recovered quickly from a winter storm that month, Southwest's computer technology, denounced as \"antiquated\" by its unions, made it difficult for it to schedule its pilots and flight attendants and resume normal operations.\n\nSouthwest made changes in its software and operations in the wake of those service issues. And last week, as many of the world's airlines were forced to cancel 5,000 flights in a single day due to a flawed software update from cyber security firm CrowdStrike, Southwest was one of the few carriers that avoided the issue and did not have to cancel flights. This time it was rival Delta Air Lines that suffered the service meltdown.\n\nBut that December 2022 meltdown cost Southwest around $1 billion, including a $140 million fine from the Department of Transportation. And it resulted in a loss in the fourth quarter of 2022 as well as the first quarter of 2023 as passengers were reluctant to book on airline in the immediate aftermath of the service problems.\n\nThe company reported losses in the fourth quarter of 2023 and first quarter of 2024 as well amid higher labor and fuel costs. Losing money in four of six quarters before the most recent period is a stunning and unwanted reversal of fortunes for Southwest. The airline had previously posted losses only during the pandemic, Great Recession and after the September 11 terrorist attacks - even while its rivals were flying in and out of bankruptcy. It also brought unwanted attention from activists investors at Elliott Investment Management, which announced in June it had taken a $1.9 billion stake in the airline and called for management changes.\n\nIncidents raise safety concerns\n\nSouthwest has also gotten unwanted attention from the Federal Aviation Administration, which announced earlier this month it is stepping up oversight of its operations due to a number of potentially dangerous incidents involving its planes in recent months.\n\nIn March, a Southwest jet veered off course and had a close call with an air traffic control tower during an attempted landing at New York's LaGuardia Airport. In April, a plane plunged to within 400 feet of the surface of the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Hawaii. In June another plane came within 525 feet of the ground over an Oklahoma town when it was still nine miles away from the Oklahoma City airport. And later that month a plane took off on a closed runway at the airport in Portland Maine which had a repair vehicle on it that had to race to get out of its way. Earlier this month, a plane got within 150 feet of the ground when it was still five miles away from the airport in Tampa, according to data from Flightradar24.\n\n\"The FAA has increased oversight of Southwest Airlines to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations,\" the agency said in a statement.\n\nSouthwest said it has formed an internal team to also look at the incidents.\n\n\"Southwest is working closely with the Federal Aviation Administration in the review of recent events,\" it said.\n\nCNN's Ross Levitt, Gregory Wallace, Chris Boyette and Pete Muntean contributed to this report.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional context and developments.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-09-11", "textStart": 5545, "textEnd": {"uri": "8243041732", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:25:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:25:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:25:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1341499", "title": "Title of the Page", "body": "The airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nAmerican \"did not perform to our initial expectations\" because of a since-abandoned sales strategy and an oversupply of domestic flights, CEO Robert Isom said. He said the airline was responding with a strategy that boosts profits and \"makes it easy for customers to do business with American.\"\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nThe change in seating policy comes as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nShares of all major airlines dipped before the opening bell Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. fell 6% and American Airlines Group Inc. fell 7%. According to the airline, Southwest conducted research into the matter and 8 million simulation-based boarding trials.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Bob Jordan, CEO of Southwest in a release. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSouthwest also announced the addition of red-eye flights. The flights will begin on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nAviation News\n\nStay prepared. {"uri": "8243319962", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:33:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:33:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:33:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://jalopnik.com/southwest-airlines-drops-open-seating-1851604736", "title": "Southwest Airlines Drops Open Seating", "body": "Southwest Airlines is about to start assigning seats on flights and sell some with extra legroom. The changes are being made in an effort to appeal to more passengers who skip it for other airlines like Delta, United and American. Additionally, the plan will serve as a way to fend off an activist investor who is pushing for an overhaul of the airline's leadership and operating strategy.\n\nOpen seating has sort of been Southwest's calling card since it started operations over a half-century ago, according to the Washington Post. That business model, which was unique among major carriers, produced decades of uninterrupted profits and democratized flying while doing so. For the most part, people seemed to really like it, but alas, all good things must come to an end.\n\nHere's what the Wall Street Journal reports about the decision to end open seating:\n\nBut Southwest executives said the company needs to adapt to what today's customers want, marking what may be its biggest-ever shift.\n\n\"This is the right change at the right time,\" Southwest Chief Executive Bob Jordan said in an interview.\n\nIt isn't clear when flying with assigned seats and premium rows will start, but Southwest said bookings for them are expected to begin next year. The exact timing of the changes depend on the airline gaining regulatory approval and retrofitting its planes.\n\nIt expects to share more details at an investor presentation in late September. Southwest also plans to operate red-eye flights for the first time starting next year.\n\nThis move comes as profit margins continue to lag behind competitors, and it pulls back from new cities it entered into during an expansion strategy a few years ago.\n\nSouthwest also just reported a second-quarter profit of $367 million, which works out to a 46 percent drop from the same time last year. That news came despite record quarterly operating revenue.\n\nElliott Investment Management, an influential hedge fund that has amassed a $1.9 billion stake in the company, has criticized the airline for being slow to adapt to modern flying. Elliott wrote in a letter to Southwest's board that changes it has been contemplating are too little, too late, and that many investors have lost confidence in the airline's leaders.\n\nSouthwest said it started studying potential changes last fall, before Elliott in June disclosed its stake in the airline.\n\nJordan declined to estimate exactly how much extra revenue the airline's new initiatives will bring in, but said he expects it to be \"significantly north\" of the nearly $1 billion Southwest currently generates selling extras like those that allow passengers to board sooner.\n\nSouthwest is rolling out a whole new boarding plan to go along with its assigned seating, according to the Journal:\n\nSouthwest's plan eases pressure on fliers to check in precisely 24 hours in advance or to pay extra to get a good spot in queues at airport gates.\n\nFans of the airline have said they loved open seating. When flights were emptier, they could often land a window or aisle seat. That is happening far less frequently though, as planes are more packed.\n\nThe airline said it surveyed thousands of customers to understand what they want and what they would be willing to pay for. It found that 80% favored assigned seats -- an overwhelming share that Jordan said took him by surprise. \"Our customers really, really, really want it,\" he said.\n\n[...]\n\nCurrently, Southwest's boarding procedure involves sorting customers into three groups (A, B or C), assigning them a number, and calling for them to line up in order. Passengers who pay for boarding and check-in upgrades, have elite status or pay for pricier ticket options can improve their position.\n\nTo test out different boarding methods, Southwest enlisted employees along with their families to practice getting on and off planes over several days in Houston. The passengers were loaded up with carry-ons and strollers, and some used wheelchairs. They tried different boarding and assigned seating configurations to determine whether assigning seats would slow things down -- one reason the airline previously opted not to do it.\n\nI'll be honest folks, I've never flown on Southwest, so I can't tell you if this sounds like a good thing or a bad thing. That being said, I know people who fly Southwest regularly, and they all seem to love the idea of open seating. I don't know. I sort of like knowing where I'm going to be sitting before I'm on the plane. Open seating feels a little bit too \"Lord of the Flies\" to me.\n\nWhat do you folks think? Was this a good move by Southwest, or is it getting rid of the one thing that made it really unique among U.S. airlines?", "source": {"uri": "jalopnik.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jalopnik"}, {"uri": "8243366008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:08:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:08:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:07:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://people.com/southwest-airlines-announces-seats-will-now-be-assigned-on-flights-8683516", "title": "Southwest Airlines Is Ending Open Seating Policy and Will Assign Seats Starting in 2025", "body": "The airline said customers who stop flying with Southwest cite its longtime open seating policy as the top reason\n\nSouthwest Airlines is doing away with its open seating policy that is loved by loyalists and loathed by others.\n\nThe airline announced Thursday, July 25, that it will begin assigning seats and offering premium seating, marking a major departure from one of the airline's most famous practices. The company's updates also include plans to redesign the boarding model and introduce redeye flights.\n\nSouthwest says the decision to assign seats came after conducting \"extensive research\" on customers' needs.\n\n\"The airline has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, but preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred,\" the airline said in a press release announcing the changes.\n\nSouthwest added that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat, according to its research.\n\n\"When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" the release said. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future Customers.\"\n\nSouthwest expects about a third of seats on its planes to offer extended legroom, though the airline said the details are still being designed and the new cabin layout requires approvals from the Federal Aviation Administration. The airline expects to make premium bookings available next year.\n\nThe airline's first overnight flights will begin service on Feb. 14, 2025, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to add more redeyes in the future.\n\nEarlier this year, Southwest unveiled its new seat design for 2025 -- and sparked outrage on social media.\n\nThe airline revealed the new layout in a TikTok in February, alongside the caption, \"New fit check! Introducing our updated cabin design and new seats! You can catch this interior on new aircraft deliveries beginning next year. Not to mention our ongoing rollout of adding bigger bins and in-seat power ports to our current planes!\"\n\nIn the clip, the cameraman walked through the aisle of a plane featuring Southwest's old seats. \"The plane interior you see,\" they wrote over the video.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\nThe video then cut to the updated cabin interior with the new, streamlined seats featuring with a small heart detail at the bottom corner of every headrest. A tray to prop iPads and phones against was also shown.\n\nTravelers criticized the new design in the comments section of the video.\n\n\"So we get thinner, more uncomfortable seats with a heart on it,\" someone wrote, while another user asked, \"Why not just put in wooden benches? They'd be just as comfortable!\"\n\n\"Ozempic seats \u2728\ud83d\ude2d,\" someone else joked, referring to the viral weight loss drug. Others compared the seats to \"slates of granite\" and \"plastic pool recliners.\"\n\nOthers commented, \"We are getting lawn chairs!\" and \"is there an option to just stand?\"\n\nWhile some comments observed that it looks like there are more seats but less space in the new design, a spokesperson for the airline confirmed to PEOPLE that the seats \"maintain the Customer-friendly width and legroom we currently offer on all aircraft configurations.", "source": {"uri": "people.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PEOPLE.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243144305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:33:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:33:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:32:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://newsadvance.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_a4b827bd-5ed2-5173-a900-6636f9adf67b.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. The data also revealed that the top reason cited by unhappy passengers has been its open seating policy.\n\nThe policy change comes two years after the airline suffered a severe operations meltdown that led to the cancellation of 17,000 flights during the holiday travel period.\n\nIn addition to assigning seats, Southwest will offer a premium, extended legroom portion of the cabin. While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" Bob Jordan, president, {"uri": "8243422101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:53:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:53:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:48:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/southwest-getting-rid-open-seating-163846705.html", "title": "Southwest is getting rid of open seating. What changes can Des Moines flyers expect?", "body": "Southwest Airlines is listening to the people and doing away with open seating policies for flights.\n\nFor more than 50 years, Southwest has allowed customers to pick seats as they board flights. But the traditions of open seating on the Dallas-based airline will come to an end according to a news release Thursday. While announcing the ending of the policy, Southwest also announced other changes to transform customer experience while improving financial performance, according to a news release.\n\nSouthwest didn't give a specific date for when the open seating policy would end. But an overwhelming number of customers are ready for the change.\n\nA study conducted by Southwest found that 80% of customers and 86% of potential customers preferred assigned seating. Open seating was cited as one of the main reasons customers elected to stop flying with Southwest and chose a competitor, according to the news release.\n\n\"Preferences have evolved with more Customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred,\" Southwest said in the news release.\n\nIn addition to open seating, Southwest will sell premium seating options on all flights. This extend the legroom in the cabin. Research found customers prefer the extra room, according to a press release. The cabin layout is still being designed.\n\nSouthwest also plans to start offering overnight flights on some routes. Flyers at the Des Moines International Airport won't find any new flights right away.\n\nOvernight flights will start in Las Vegas, Las Angeles and Phoenix, offering flights to Baltimore, Orlando and Nashville. Southwest does plan to phase in additional redeye flights over the next three years, according to the news release.\n\nSouthwest first came to Des Moines in 2012. The addition of low-fare carriers like Southwest helped spur increased travel out of Des Moines while driving down airline prices, officials at the airport told the Register in 2013.\n\nSouthwest's non-stop flights out of Des Moines include:\n\nKate Kealey is a general assignment reporter for the Des Moines Register. {"uri": "8243557647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:49:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:49:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:48:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/southwest-airlines-plans-to-assign-seats-instead-of-open-seating-1033596241", "title": "Southwest Airlines Plans To Assign Seats Instead Of Open Seating", "body": "(RTTNews) - Southwest Airlines (LUV) has decided to drop its distinctive open seating policy as \"preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred\".\n\nThe policy, which has been in effect for more than 50 years, allows customers to check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines, instead of assigning seats while buying tickets.\n\nHowever, recent research conducted by the company revealed that 80 percent of Southwest customers, and 86 percent of potential customers prefer assigned seats.\n\n\"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future Customers,\" the Dallas-based airline stated.\n\nSouthwest would also start offering overnight 'red-eye' fights along with 24-hour operational capabilities.\n\nAdditionally, the airline expects around one-third of seats across the fleet to offer premium, extended legroom.\n\n\"We are excited to incorporate Customer and Employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver,\" said Bob Jordan, President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board. \"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nThe company would discuss further about the potential changes at its Investor Day in late September.", "source": {"uri": "markets.businessinsider.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Markets Insider"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RTTNews", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "RTTNews"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Jordan_(businessman)", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Bob Jordan (businessman)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chairperson", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Chairperson"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Chief executive officer"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Leasing_Services", "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Leasing Services", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Fleet_Maintenance", "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Fleet Maintenance", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 71}], "image": null, "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.06666666666666665, "wgt": 182, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243752330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:16:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:16:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:15:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/southwest-airlines-plans-to-start-assigning-seats-breaking-with-a-50-year-tradition/article_82c6b85c-4acf-11ef-aaf9-ef36e6e2428c.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats, breaking with a 50-year tradition", "body": "DALLAS -- Goodbye, cattle calls.\n\nSouthwest Airlines said July 25 that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big carriers.\n\nSouthwest said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. It discovered that preferences have changed over the years, and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting on a plane before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline, which has served Charleston International for more than a decade, operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" group, guaranteeing them window or aisle seats. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest allowed customers to pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many loyalists of the airline still love open seating.\n\nSouthwest thinks they will adapt.\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80 percent of its customers -- and 86 percent of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nSome passengers reacted with sadness and disappointment to news that open seating is going away.\n\n\"Hearing that announcement today, I was like, no, this is my favorite part of Southwest,\" said Lindsey Magness, who works in college athletics in Oklahoma City.\n\nMagness said that with open seating, she can try for a window seat or, depending on her mood, an aisle. And assigned seating doesn't always work either. Magness said American Airlines seated her away from her husband on their honeymoon trip earlier this summer\n\nBrandon Bowser of Odenton, Md., said he flies on different airlines based on which one has the best deal, but he has found Southwest's open boarding to be faster and less complicated than other airlines.\n\n\"The convenience that comes with being able to pick your own seat is what sets Southwest apart and makes them sort of a preferred airline,\" he said. \"A lot of my friends swear by Southwest, that's all they will fly, and they are completely irate about this decision.\"\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nSouth Carolina's castle on the coast continues to amaze tourists Decades-old furniture store in Columbia's Vista set to close its doors Battle lines drawn as Duke prepares to plow through Spartanburg farm community Sea Fox is officially done with Charleston County Parks after monthslong controversy Cafe Strudel owners are opening a new restaurant and market on Lake Murray Want to buy a plane from Clemson? University to sell jets used for athletics recruiting, fundraising Lowes Foods to shutter a Moncks Corner grocery store Dawn Staley's newcomers know the Gamecocks' standard, and want to maintain it Hicks: Nikki Haley predicted the Republican Party's current predicament, and could've helped Former ballet dancer who killed her Charleston husband is on trial amid claim of self-defense\n\nAt Chicago's O'Hare Airport, Kimberly King was happy to learn of the change. She was at a check-in kiosk with her four children for a flight home to California.\n\n\"I used to fly United a lot and I liked the assigned seats, especially with kids, kind of expecting and knowing where we were going to be,\" King said. \"The only reason really why I continue to fly Southwest is for the free bags.\"\n\nSouthwest still lets passengers check two bags for free. It's been a centerpiece of the airline's advertising campaigns for years. Jordan, the CEO, said Southwest has no plans to end bags-fly-free \"at this point.\"\n\nThere are drawbacks to Southwest's boarding method. It's hard to get a good spot in line without paying an extra fee. Southwest executives said 60 percent of passengers check as soon as they can, within the first 30 seconds. Those who miss the rush fear they won't find room in the overhead bins for their carry-on bags. Late boarders can struggle to see an open seat anywhere, and start roaming up and down the aisle -- Southwest calls them \"spinners.\"\n\nThere are a number of tricks that passengers use to game the system.\n\nSome take advantage of early boarding for people who need extra time. Others ignore the age limit (6 or under) for children in families who are allowed to board right after the \"A\" group. Once on the plane, some passengers hold choice seats for mates who are far behind them in line.\n\nPhotos appear occasionally on social media of an unusually large number of people in wheelchairs at Southwest gates. They get to board early.\n\n\"It's certainly one of the things that anger people even if it doesn't have a material impact on them,\" said Brett Snyder, a travel agent and author of the Cranky Flier blog. \"In some cases those are people who have absolutely legitimate reasons. In other cases, it's the 'Jetway Jesus' phenomenon.\"\n\nThat's a reference to recoveries so miraculous that the disability causing the person to need a wheelchair to reach the gate is cured during flight, and they walk off the plane like everybody else.\n\nSnyder doubts that fans of open seating will abandon Southwest.\n\n\"Those people will still fly Southwest,\" he said. \"They may grumble about it, but there's no one else they can go to that has open seating.\"\n\nIn addition to the boarding change, Southwest also plans to convert about one-third of the seats on its planes to premium seating with more legroom, matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers.\n\nThe airline's newest schedule also includes a few redeye flights -- a first for Southwest.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan as CEO and the chairman, Gary Kelly.", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Get a load of this: Southwest Airlines, known for its unique open seating model, has announced that it will be ending its decades-long practice and introducing assigned and premium seating options. Yes, you read that right. This new boarding model aims to meet the preferences of its customers and attract more flying from both current and potential customers.\n\nFor the past 50 years, Southwest has been known for its single economy-class cabin with open seating assignments. Passengers were assigned a boarding group, but once onboard, they were free to choose any available seat. However, the airline has conducted extensive research which indicates that 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\" CEO Bob Jordan also said in a news release Thursday, \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders.\"\n\nRELATED:Delta Airlines Under Investigation Over Passenger Protection Policies As It Continues Struggling To Recover After Global Tech Outage, Unable To Find Pilots And Flight Attendants\n\nRELATED:Breaking: Widespread Technology Outage Disrupts Banks, Media Outlets, Companies, And Forces Airlines To Ground Flights Worldwide\n\nStarting next year, Southwest will begin selling the first flights that offer extra legroom, providing passengers with more comfort during their journey. In addition, the airline plans to introduce overnight flights in February.\n\nWhile the introduction of assigned seating and premium seats will allow Southwest to charge higher rates for its premium offerings, the airline assures that these changes will not compromise its operational efficiency.\n\nSouthwest executives have been studying these changes for years and hinted at the possibility of assigning seats and offering extra legroom options earlier this year. Currently, customers are placed into one of three boarding groups and assigned a number, leading to a rush to check-in a day before the flight. However, customers who purchase higher-priced tickets are given earlier boarding slots.\n\nBy implementing these changes, Southwest aims to broaden its appeal and enhance the overall flying experience for its customers.\n\nSocialites, how do you feel about this? {"uri": "8242938970", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:21:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:21:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:21:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.fox35orlando.com/news/southwest-open-seating-assigning-seats-extra-legroom-july-25-2024", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition and will start assigning seats, offer extra legroom", "body": "Southwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats to travelers, as well as offering premium seating for customers who want more legroom -- a move announced on Thursday that breaks a 50-year tradition for the carrier.\n\nThe airline said it's been studying customer preferences and expectations and is making the changes because of what they've heard, but it could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nFor 50 years, Southwest has used an open seating model - meaning the carrier doesn't assign seats nor can customers choose their seats before the flight.\n\nInstead, passengers are assigned a boarding group (A, B, or C) and position (1-60+) after checking in. Once on board, passengers can sit in any of the remaining seats.\n\nBut the company said that it understands that preferences have changed, with more customers taking longer flights and wanting an assigned seat.\n\nIn June, the carrier announced that it was increasing the price range of certain perks that allow passengers to board sooner and better pick their preferred seat.\n\nSouthwest said it will offer redeye flights for the first time, as well.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025.\n\nThe nonstop markets will include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nIt plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.", "source": {"uri": "fox35orlando.com", {"uri": "8243169445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:50:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:50:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:49:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://simpleflying.com/southwest-airlines-finally-introduces-assigned-seating-after-50-years/", "title": "End Of An Era: Southwest Airlines Finally Introduces Assigned Seating After 50 Years", "body": "Summary Under pressure from external parties and its own financial underperformance, Southwest Airlines has introduced assigned seating and premium seat options. The new cabins, pending the approval of the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) should be available in 2025. In Q2 2024, Southwest Airlines earned a net income of $367 million.\n\nUnder pressure from an activist investor and admitting that the airline has underperformed financially, Southwest Airlines executives have made monumental changes to its onboard experience, introducing assigned seating while also offering premium seat options for its customers.\n\nMeeting customer demand and increasing revenues\n\nThe changes will be coming on all flights, with the airline admitting that while Southwest Airlines has been known for its unique open seating model for more than 50 years, preferences have evolved, which included passengers taking longer flights. As a result, seat assignment was preferred to ensure additional comfort.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest Customers, and 86% of potential Customers, prefer an assigned seat. When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change.\"\n\nPhoto: Joni Hanebutt | Shutterstock\n\nIn addition to assigned seats, premium seating options will also be available to customers. These will offer extended legroom, with many customers preferring such options, according to the carrier.\n\nThe airline stated that one-third of its seats would offer extra legroom, which would be comparable to what its competitors have offered to passengers.\n\nRelated Will Southwest Airlines Transform Its Cabin & Fares?\n\nWould you pay additionally to be seated in a specific cabin section on a Southwest Airlines flight?\n\n6\n\nHowever, Southwest Airlines warned that in addition to incorporating new technologies and procedures for a seamless transition, the new cabin layout will require the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) approval. The carrier said that bookings should become available in 2025.\n\nFurthermore, Southwest Airlines will introduce red-eye flights, which will begin operating in February 2025. The flights will be available on routes from Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) to Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport (BWI), from Las Vegas Harry Reid International Airport (LAS) to BWI, from LAS to Orlando International Airport (MCO), from Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport (PHX) to BWI, and from LAX to Nashville International Airport (BNA).\n\nRelated Welcome To The Red-Eye: Southwest Schedules Its 1st Ever Overnight Flights\n\nFive daily services are planned at first.\n\n5 Pressure from Elliot Investment Management\n\nWhen the airline announced its Q1 2024 results, Bob Jordan, the president and chief executive officer (CEO) of Southwest Airlines, admitted that he was disappointed in its Q1 performance.\n\nStill, Jordan added that there were efforts and progress underway to ensure that the carrier delivers the returns shareholders have expected from Southwest Airlines.\n\nPhoto: Angel DiBilio | Shutterstock\n\nJordan's remarks came despite Southwest Airlines earning record-breaking Q1 revenues, with the company ending the three-month period with operating revenues of $6.3 billion, which were still shy of its aspirations.\n\n\"Separately, we are considering more transformational options and follow-on initiatives. That includes work previously underway to study customer preference around seating and our cabin.\"\n\nNow, the CEO stated that the new cabin experience will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company. While the open seating model has been part of the airline's identity since its inception, research showed that it was the right choice made at the right time, Jordan said.\n\n\"We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nJordan and the rest of the board of directors have been under pressure from Elliot Investment Management. The investment company had built a significant shareholding in the airline, with the board responding by setting up a poison pill, which would dilute Elliot Investment Management's shareholding if it attempted to increase its stake in Southwest Airlines.\n\nRelated Southwest Airlines Issues Shareholders Rights Plan Responding To Elliott Activist Investor\n\nEssentially, Southwest Airlines has prepared a poison pill in case Elliot Investment Management attempts to acquire a significant stake in the airline\n\n7 Must-have changes\n\nHowever, Southwest Airlines, Elliot Investment Management, and executives from the Southwest Airlines Pilot Association (SWAPA) have all admitted that changes were needed at the airline, as it has been struggling financially.\n\nIn particular, the investment firm has blasted the airline's executives and its board for many things, including the fact that in the past 18 months, Southwest Airlines had issued eight guidance reductions.\n\nPhoto: Vincenzo Pace | Simple Flying\n\nElliot Investment Management called for a complete leadership change at the carrier with the plan 'Stronger Southwest,' and when the airline announced the addition of Rakesh Gangwal, an experienced airline executive with prior C-level roles at US Airways, Air France, United Airlines, and being the co-founder of IndiGo, the firm said that Gangwal would be \"supportive of Southwest's current leadership and status-quo approach [...].\"\n\nOn July 8, Elliot Investment Management continued pressuring the airline, publishing an open letter that said the feedback it had received was consistent with its perspective, once again reiterating that leadership changes were a must at Southwest Airlines.\n\nRelated SWAPA President Backs Call For Change As Elliot Responds To 'Poison Pill'\n\nSouthwest Airlines' pilots reiterated that whatever will happen in the next few months, changes will be coming to the airline and its business model.\n\n2 Return to profitability\n\nNevertheless, the airline's announcement about the changes to its seating policy coincided with the publication of its Q2 results, with Southwest Airlines returning to profitability after a net loss of $231 million in Q1.\n\nIn Q2, the airline's revenues were $7.4 billion, resulting in a net income of $367 million, with revenues growing 4.5% year-on-year (YoY). According to Southwest Airlines, this was another all-time quarterly record.\n\nCommenting on the quarterly results, Jordan said that they were impacted by external and internal factors, falling short of what the company believed it was capable of delivering.\n\nPhoto: Markus Mainka | Shutterstock\n\n\"Our goal is to restore industry-leading margins and historical levels of Shareholder returns through our comprehensive plan to deliver transformational commercial initiatives, improved operational efficiency, and capital allocation discipline.\"\n\nLooking forward, Southwest Airlines said that its revenue per available seat mile (RASM), available seat miles (ASM), and cost per ASM (excluding fuel) would flat to down 2%, up around 2%, and up 11% to 13%, respectively, in Q3.\n\nIts 2024 guidance, which includes ASMs growing by 4%, an operational fleet of 802 aircraft, and other metrics, has remained unchanged.\n\nRelated Southwest Airlines Posts Net Loss Of $231 Million In Q1 Against Headwinds Of Boeing Delays\n\nSouthwest Airlines revealed that it has entered into another agreement to amend the contractual delivery schedule with Boeing.\n\n2", "source": {"uri": Currently, passengers are assigned a boarding group but once they are onboard, they can choose any available seat. Customers can pay extra to board early to get their preferred seat.\n\nSOUTHWEST CEO SAYS AIRLINE MULLING CHANGES TO ITS OPEN SEATING POLICY\n\nThe recently announced changes will effectively allow the carrier to boost profits by charging a higher rate for its premium seats across all its flights.\n\nSouthwest said it plans to offer a premium, extended legroom portion of the cabin and expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom. That's in line with what industry peers offer on narrow-body aircraft.\n\nSouthwest said the decision came after research indicated that 80% of its customers and nearly 90% of potential customers prefer having an assigned seat.\n\nSOUTHWEST AIRLINES EXITS MULTIPLE AIRPORTS AS BOEING TROUBLES WEIGH\n\n\"When a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" Southwest said in its Thursday release. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nIn April, Southwest Airlines CEO Bob Jordan hinted that the carrier was considering changing the boarding and seating processes on its planes in order to improve its financial position.\n\nGET FOX BUSINESS ON THE GO BY CLICKING HERE\n\nHis comments came as Jordan warned that the carrier is contending with financial fallout from Boeing delays and announced it's pulling out of multiple underperforming airports.\n\nSouthwest said these changes won't \"compromise the airline's operational efficiency.\"\n\nWhile the carrier didn't disclose when {"uri": "8243301860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:20:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:20:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:20:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.investopedia.com/southwest-airlines-to-introduce-assigned-seating-overnight-flights-8683383", "title": "Southwest Airlines To Introduce Assigned Seating, Overnight Flights", "body": "Southwest has been under pressure in recent months from activist investors to focus on revenue-generating efforts.\n\nSouthwest Airlines (LUV) is abandoning its longtime policy of open seating, announcing plans Thursday \"to assign seats and offer premium seating options to meet evolving Customer preferences and increase revenue opportunities.\"\n\nThe airline has been under pressure from activist investors like Elliott Investment Management, which amassed a large stake in the company last month and has pressed Southwest to focus more on revenue-generating policies.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" Southwest Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Bob Jordan said.\n\nThe company said that its surveys have shown that 80% of Southwest customers would prefer an assigned seat, and importantly, 86% of potential customers said the same, indicating the move could broaden Southwest's customer base. Southwest also said the open seating policy was the most frequently cited reason by customers who decided to stop flying Southwest and choose a competitor instead.\n\nThe airline is also shifting to become operational for 24 hours a day, and said it plans to start selling tickets for overnight flights, beginning in February 2025 with a limited number of initial routes.\n\nSouthwest has been fending off pressure from Elliott to make changes at the executive level, recently adopting a \"poison pill\" plan to prevent the fund from acquiring a larger stake. Elliott has criticized the company's \"stubborn unwillingness\" to evolve and keep pace with other large airlines.\n\nSouthwest shares rose 4% to $27.69 as of about 11:15 a.m. Thursday, as markets reacted to Thursday's announcement along with its second-quarter earnings report, which saw the carrier beat expectations but warn of \"cost pressures for the remainder of the year.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-433710097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:00:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:00:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:52:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/4793013-southwest-scraps-open-seating-new-premium-upgrades/", "title": "When will Southwest Airlines start assigning seats?", "body": "Southwest Airlines will scrap its unique \"open seating\" system next year to make way for assigned seating tickets and new premium upgrades as part of a \"cabin monetization project\" the budget airline hopes will help steady a turbulent financial streak.\n\nThe company is expected to reveal more details about the plan, including price changes and the anticipated early 2025 rollout, during an investors meeting on Sept. 26.\n\nThe company's new executive vice president for commercial transformation, Ryan Green, will lead the project, according to an overview Southwest released Thursday.\n\nIn a memo on strategic initiatives, the company acknowledged that it will be a complex endeavor after five decades operating with its current cattle call boarding process and free-for-all seating selection.\n\n\"Our implementation of assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade to the Customer Experience, one that research shows Customers overwhelmingly prefer,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said in a statement.\n\n\"With record numbers of Passengers choosing Southwest Airlines today and work underway to address the challenges we face, we are excited about what the future holds.\"\n\nSouthwest said it researched the switch and found 80 percent of existing Southwest customers and 86 percent of potential customers prefer assigned seats, like most other airlines provide.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives that are designed to drive meaningful top and bottom-line growth,\" Jordan said.\n\nNew premium cabin offerings will include the option to pay more for additional legroom.\n\nSouthwest also will launch 24-hour operation capabilities with the introduction of overnight, or \"redeye,\" flights on Feb. 14, 2025 in select locations, including Baltimore (BWI). Additional redeye offerings will be rolled out over the year.\n\n\"Redeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings, enabling Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without incremental aircraft capital deployment,\" the company said.", "source": {"uri": "8243001649", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:01:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:01:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:00:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/industry/southwest-airlines-is-ditching-open-seating-on-flights-11721907961406.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines is ditching open seating on flights", "body": "The plans, announced Thursday, also come as it fends off an activist investor pushing for an overhaul of the airline's leadership and operating strategy.\n\nOpen seating has been a hallmark of Southwest flights since the carrier got its start over 50 years ago. It was part of a business model that produced decades of uninterrupted profits and democratized flying in the process. But Southwest executives said that the company needs to adapt to what today's customers want.\n\n\"This is the right change at the right time,\" Southwest Chief Executive Bob Jordan said in an interview.\n\nIt isn't clear when flying with assigned seats and premium rows will start, but Southwest said bookings for them are expected to begin next year. The exact timing of the changes depend on the airline gaining regulatory approval and retrofitting its planes.\n\nIt expects to share more details at an investor presentation in late September. Southwest also plans to operate red-eye flights for the first time starting next year.\n\nThe carrier has been facing challenges on a range of fronts. Its profit margins have lagged behind many rivals and pulled back from some new cities it entered as part of an ambitious expansion strategy.\n\nOther airlines are also grappling with too many empty seats on U.S. flights and weaker fares, but Southwest doesn't have the vast international network and high-end offerings that have offset those problems for rivals.\n\nThrough Wednesday its share price this year is down about 7.9%, compared with a 14% gain in the S&P 500.\n\nElliott Investment Management, an influential hedge fund that has amassed a $1.9 billion stake in the company, has criticized the airline for being slow to adapt to modern flying. Elliott wrote in a letter to Southwest's board that changes it has been contemplating are too little, too late, and that many investors have lost confidence in the airline's leaders.\n\nSouthwest said it started studying potential changes last fall, before Elliott in June disclosed its stake in the airline.\n\nJordan declined to estimate exactly how much extra revenue the airline's new initiatives will bring in, but said he expects it to be \"significantly north\" of the nearly $1 billion Southwest currently generates selling extras like those that allow passengers to board sooner.\n\nSouthwest's plan eases pressure on fliers to check in precisely 24 hours in advance or to pay extra to get a good spot in queues at airport gates.\n\nFans of the airline have said they loved open seating. When flights were emptier, they could often land a window or aisle seat. That is happening far less frequently though, as planes are more packed.\n\nThe airline said it surveyed thousands of customers to understand what they want and what they would be willing to pay for. It found that 80% favored assigned seats -- an overwhelming share that Jordan said took him by surprise. \"Our customers really, really, really want it,\" he said.\n\nAnd the carrier is betting it can bring in more fliers, including those who wouldn't have previously considered Southwest. As it makes a bigger push for corporate travelers, it has found road warriors have little interest in playing seating roulette.\n\nMany employees, tired of refereeing preflight seat disputes, want it too. The airline got more internal complaints when it ditched serving peanuts on flights than when it started discussing potential changes a few months ago, executives said.\n\nExtended legroom seats will eventually account for about a third of seats across Southwest's fleet, but executives say they are not planning on a true first-class cabin.\n\nRyan Green, the executive charged with leading the commercial transformation, said that since Southwest seats are already among the roomiest in economy cabins, it is possible to cede some space without making the experience uncomfortable for those who don't pay up. It isn't clear how much the option will cost passengers.\n\nCurrently, Southwest's boarding procedure involves sorting customers into three groups (A, B or C), assigning them a number, and calling for them to line up in order. Passengers who pay for boarding and check-in upgrades, have elite status or pay for pricier ticket options can improve their position.\n\nTo test out different boarding methods, Southwest enlisted employees along with their families to practice getting on and off planes over several days in Houston. The passengers were loaded up with carry-ons and strollers, and some used wheelchairs. They tried different boarding and assigned seating configurations to determine whether assigning seats would slow things down -- one reason the airline previously opted not to do it.\n\nThe carrier set up cameras to track passengers' movements. Some testers wore Google Glass devices so the airline could see the experience from their perspective -- how they searched out seat numbers and overhead bin space.\n\nSouthwest validated its findings with millions of computer simulations, and found that it could make the change without gumming up operations.\n\nJordan said he knows there may be a small, but vocal group of superfans who are skeptical as their beloved airline transforms.", "source": {"uri": "livemint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "mint"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", {"uri": "8243174509", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:53:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:53:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:53:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.travelandleisure.com/southwest-airlines-ends-open-boarding-policy-adds-first-ever-overnight-flights-8683415", "title": "Southwest Ends Its Open Boarding Policy, Adds First-ever Overnight Flights", "body": "It's been whispered about for months, but now it's official. After more than 50 years, Southwest Airlines is doing away with one of its signature policies -- open seating.\n\nWhile the airline has not announced when the new assigned seating process will roll out, it confirmed the news in a press release shared on Thursday that in addition to assigning seats, premium seating with extra legroom will be introduced.\n\nPremium seating options are one of the most significant sources of revenue for Southwest's competitors, and critics of the airline's financial performance argued it needed to evolve given the softness of domestic air prices. Roughly a third of seats on planes will have the premium, extra-legroom setup, the airline said.\n\nPlus, Southwest noted in the release that \"80 percent of Southwest customers, and 86 percent of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" admitting that, \"when a customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change.\"\n\nIn addition to a shift in its seating policy, it was also announced Thursday that it is introducing red-eye flights for the first time, which will launch in February.\n\nBooking is now available on the following overnight routes: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore. Southwest mentioned it will be adding more of these routes in the coming year.\n\nThe major update comes months the airline's Chief Commercial Officer Ryan Green confirmed that overnight flights were in the carrier's future.\n\n\"We have the aircraft, it's a great way to use an asset that you already have and use it more productively which means more hours in the day,\" Jordan said in March. \"So, {"uri": "2024-07-433545671", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:31:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:31:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:29:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.heraldonline.com/news/nation-world/national/article290423104.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines Makes Biggest Change Ever After Profits Plunge", "body": "Southwest Airlines is ending its open seating system, in the biggest change it has ever made in its 53 years of flying.\n\nThe Dallas-based airline announced the decision in a press release on Thursday, saying it was to \"elevate the Customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive Shareholder value.\"\n\nIt came after Southwest revealed, in a separate press release published on the same day, that its profits dropped more than 46 percent to $367 million, or 58 cents a share in the second quarter. This is despite the firm's revenue rising 4.5 percent from last year to a record $7.35 billion.\n\n\"Our second quarter performance was impacted by both external and internal factors and fell short of what we believe we are capable of delivering,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in an earnings release.\n\nSouthwest has decided to scrap the open seating system it is known for and use assigned seating like its competitors, starting next year.\n\nIt made this decision after its own research showed that 80 percent of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" the airline discovered.\n\nUnder the current system, travelers are split into three groups, which often ends up resulting in a chaotic rush to check in before the flight. Folks can get early boarding if they pay a higher price.\n\nWhen the new structure comes in, people will be assigned seats in the same way other airlines do it, but there will also be a premium seating option on all flights, to pay more for extra legroom.\n\n\"While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft,\" the airline said.\n\nSouthwest also announced that it is introducing redeye flights-overnight flights that depart in the evening and arrive at their destination early the next morning, the first of which will arrive on Valentine's Day next year.\n\n\"Redeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings,\" the release said.\n\nSouthwest is believed to be under pressure from investors to fix its financial situation- likely one of the major triggers for the current changes.\n\nJordan said: \"Our goal is to restore industry-leading margins and historical levels of Shareholder returns through our comprehensive plan to deliver transformational commercial initiatives, improved operational efficiency, and capital allocation discipline.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives that are designed to drive meaningful top and bottom-line growth.\"", "source": {"uri": "heraldonline.com", Log in.\n\n\"Southwest represents the most compelling airline turnaround opportunity in the last two decades,\" the hedge fund Elliott Investment Management said in June when it began its crusade.\n\nSince launching 57 years ago, the airline has had an open seating policy, meaning passengers choose their seats once they board their flight.\n\nThat will now change.\n\nSouthwest said research carried out showed that 80% of customers and 86% of potential customers favored an assigned seat system. The number one reason a passenger chooses a competitor is the open seating model, the company added.\n\nSouthwest did not give an exact date for the changes but said more details will be revealed in September.\n\nSouthwest also announced that it will be introducing premium seating with extended legroom, with possibly up to one-third of a cabin being allocated to this kind of seat.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" said Southwest's CEO, president and vice chairman of the board, Bob Jordan.\n\nPaid seat upgrades are lucrative revenue sources for airlines and have largely allowed mainline carriers like American or Delta to avoid some of the financial stress that's hit low-cost carriers this year.\n\nThe airline will also add 24-hour operations from February of next year, with new overnight redeye flights available.\n\nChanges to Southwest's seating policy were announced on the same day the company reported a significant drop in profits for the second quarter of the year. Southwest reported net income of $367 million for the quarter, down from $683 million in the same period in 2023.\n\nWhile profits fell, revenues climbed, hitting a record $7.4 billion for the {"uri": "8243363793", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:06:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:06:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:05:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/southwest-airlines-profits-seating-plan-1930277", "title": "Southwest Airlines makes biggest change ever after profits plunge", "body": "Southwest Airlines is ending its open seating system, in the biggest change it has ever made in its 53 years of flying.\n\nThe Dallas-based airline announced the decision in a press release on Thursday, saying it was to \"elevate the Customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive Shareholder value.\"\n\nIt came after Southwest revealed, in a separate press release published on the same day, that its profits dropped more than 46 percent to $367 million, or 58 cents a share in the second quarter. This is despite the firm's revenue rising 4.5 percent from last year to a record $7.35 billion.\n\n\"Our second quarter performance was impacted by both external and internal factors and fell short of what we believe we are capable of delivering,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in an earnings release.\n\nSouthwest has decided to scrap the open seating system it is known for and use assigned seating like its competitors, starting next year.\n\nIt made this decision after its own research showed that 80 percent of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" the airline discovered.\n\nUnder the current system, travelers are split into three groups, which often ends up resulting in a chaotic rush to check in before the flight. Folks can get early boarding if they pay a higher price.\n\nWhen the new structure comes in, people will be assigned seats in the same way other airlines do it, but there will also be a premium seating option on all flights, to pay more for extra legroom.\n\n\"While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft,\" the airline said.\n\nSouthwest also announced that it is introducing redeye flights -- overnight flights that depart in the evening and arrive at their destination early the next morning, the first of which will arrive on Valentine's Day next year.\n\n\"Redeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings,\" the release said.\n\nSouthwest is believed to be under pressure from investors to fix its financial situation -- likely one of the major triggers for the current changes.\n\nJordan said: \"Our goal is to restore industry-leading margins and historical levels of Shareholder returns through our comprehensive plan to deliver transformational commercial initiatives, improved operational efficiency, and capital allocation discipline.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives that are designed to drive meaningful top and bottom-line growth.\"", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com",
