{"uri": "8243749743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:12:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:12:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:11:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.frommers.com/blogs/arthur-frommer-online/blog_posts/southwest-airlines-to-end-open-seating-so-why-fly-it-at-all-there-s-still-one-reason", "title": "Southwest Airlines to End Open Seating, So Why Fly It At All? There's Still One Reason | Frommer's", "body": "Social media is so infected with liars and bad actors that we can't trust it even to tell us the sky is blue anymore.\n\nBut the minute Southwest Airlines announced that, after some 50 years, the carrier will do away with its open seating system, the online reaction seemed to repeat a certain point that rings true.\n\nYou might hear it said that open seating was the best thing about flying Southwest. The lack of assigned seating made it easier for families to sit together without paying too much more. All you had to do was check in 24 hours before departure and secure an early boarding group -- it was all about jostling for that A group.\n\nI personally found the boarding experience anxiety-inducing and dehumanizing, but millions of customers have felt it made Southwest easier and more affordable to use.\n\nNow Southwest has announced it will begin charging for seating assignments, and will deviate from its long-running system of seat equality to add seats with extra legroom, which will also come with an extra charge.\n\nLet's be honest. Southwest's no-class system had already deteriorated before today, eroded by cash grabs. The airline's \"EarlyBird\" check-in upcharge, available 36 hours before departure for $15 a person, was already infuriating customers who bought it, thinking the service would allow them to seat their entire families together, yet still finding themselves in group B.\n\n\"What's up?\" Denver TV host Jeff Schroeder asked Southwest on the air on July 16. \"What am I paying for? ... I'm paying to be average?\"\n\nNow, just like the other airlines, Southwest will charge you to access higher-quality versions of the same service. Southwest will also force you to shell out for seats, just like the other airlines do, except in Southwest's case premium service is highly unlikely to be much more than an afterthought.\n\nSouthwest has caved to the class system. Why would the airline change the central personality trait that sets it apart?\n\nYou know the answer. It's green and it fills bank accounts.\n\nThe people who built Southwest are no longer in charge. In early July 2024, activist fund managers at Elliot Investment Management took control of the airline.\n\nThe new puppeteers at Southwest care nothing for tried-and-true egalitarian passenger boarding systems, nor for the operational advantages they have been said to provide in helping Southwest board planes quickly and keep flying.\n\nTwenty years ago, Southwest was flying high on low-priced, negotiated fuel expenses and an aviation system that gave power to Southwest's focus on one-way domestic short hauls. But our fraught era has bedeviled the airline, dragging it below the profit line via a combo of inflation and antiquated systems.\n\nSouthwest's most recent earnings report, issued this week, showed a profit drop of 46%, all but forcing the airline's new puppet masters to take drastic measures.\n\nHours later, open seating was abandoned and the new seating fees were brought in to generate cash.\n\nBut there's still one major aspect of flying Southwest Airlines that sets it apart from its rivals.\n\nSouthwest still grants two free checked bags per passenger. While competitors charge $45 each way for luggage, Southwest's bag policy stands out and often makes its airfares the cheapest when you factor in all charges.\n\nSouthwest is strapped for easy cash, and bag fees represent big, fat, juicy, low-hanging fruit that could be plucked for desperately needed income. In 2022, U.S. airlines collected $6.8 billion in bag fees, double the amount from a decade earlier, and Southwest didn't reap that bounty.\n\nThe airline's operational meltdowns over the past few years have been the subject of sorrow, satire, and federal scrutiny, and the airline's executives have been scrambling to shore up business. In January, Southwest tried to ease its redemption program for the airline's most dedicated customers, and in the spring, Southwest departures finally began appearing on Google Flights, when third-party engines had previously been blocked.\n\nBut those moves weren't fast enough to turn profits around.\n\nIf Elliott is willing to sweep away the core democratic principles that made Southwest Airlines unique, how long do you think the free baggage allowance is going to last? Take advantage of the perk while you can.\n\nThe future of free checked bags at Southwest is now in doubt.\n\nThe change in boarding procedures also means the efficient turnaround of Southwest planes at the gate, a keystone in the aggressive operational schedule that once made the airline viable, is on the line.\n\nWhat isn't in doubt is that Wall Street types have finally caught up with the carrier, and just like JetBlue before it, Southwest is being forced to behave like all the other airlines, erasing the points of difference that fueled Southwest's rise in the first place.", "source": {"uri": "8243287824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:11:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:11:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:10:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/southwest-airlines-to-discontinue-open-seating-policy/articleshow/112020458.cms", "title": "Southwest Airlines to discontinue open seating policy - Times of India", "body": "Major US airline operator Southwest Airlines is set to discontinue its open seating policy, which has been a distinctive feature of the airline for over 50 years. The announcement comes amid pressure from an activist investor seeking changes in the company's leadership and operating strategy, reported the Wall Street Journal.\n\nThe shift will involve assigned seats with some having extra legroom, marking a significant shift for Southwest, as the model has contributed to the airline's long-standing profitability and democratization of air travel.Southwest Chief Executive Bob Jordan believes that this change is necessary to meet the evolving preferences of customers. The exact timing for the implementation of assigned seats and premium rows is yet to be determined, but bookings for these options are expected to commence next year, pending regulatory approval and the retrofitting of planes. \"This is the right change at the right time,\" said Jordan.\n\nDespite achieving record quarterly operating revenue, Southwest reported a 46% decrease in second-quarter profit compared to the previous year. The airline acknowledged that it sold many summer tickets too early, resulting in the loss of lucrative last-minute bookings. However, the profit still surpassed analysts' expectations. The company's shares experienced a decline of 3.8% in premarket trading on Thursday, following a 7.9% drop year-to-date, in contrast to a 14% gain in the S&P 500.\n\nElliott Investment Management, a prominent hedge fund with a substantial stake in Southwest, has criticized the airline for its slow adaptation to modern flying practices. In a letter to the airline's board, Elliott expressed that the proposed changes are insufficient and overdue, and that many investors have lost faith in the company's leadership.\n\nSouthwest's plan aims to alleviate the pressure on passengers to check in precisely 24 hours in advance or pay extra for a favorable spot in the boarding queue. While open seating has been appreciated by the airline's fans, especially when flights were less crowded, this is becoming less common as planes are now more packed. A survey conducted by the airline revealed that 80% of customers preferred assigned seats. Surprised by the results, chief executive Jordan said, \"Our customers really, really, really want it.\"\n\nThe airline is optimistic that these changes will attract more passengers, including those who may not have previously considered Southwest. As the company targets more corporate travelers, it has observed that frequent flyers have little interest in unpredictable seating arrangements. Many Southwest employees also support the change, with executives noting that the airline received more internal complaints when it stopped serving peanuts on flights than when it began discussing these potential changes.\n\nTo test various boarding methods, Southwest conducted trials in Houston, to ensure that the changes does\"not compromise the airline's operational efficiency\", enlisting employees and their families to practice boarding and deplaning over several days. The airline set up cameras to monitor movements and equipped some testers with Google Glass devices to gain a first-person perspective on the process. The findings were confirmed through millions of computer simulations, leading Southwest to conclude that it could implement the change without disrupting operations.\n\nJordan acknowledged that there might be a small but vocal group of loyal customers who are skeptical about the transformation. However, he remains confident that the airline will be able to win them over.\n\nApart from the shift in seating policy, Southwest Airlines is also introducing red-eye flights, which means late-night or overnight flights. Beginning in February of the upcoming year, Southwest Airlines will be launching overnight flights on five initial routes. These routes include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore. These changes are also aimed to increase revenue according to the airlines.\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. With an unwavering commitment to accuracy, depth, and timeliness, we strive to keep you informed about the ever-evolving world, delivering a nuanced understanding of international affairs to our readers. {"uri": "2024-07-433763300", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:18:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:18:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.news.com.au/travel/travel-advice/major-airline-ends-53yearold-boarding-rule/news-story/db86172fae6d2ccd0335c73c9b699c76", "title": "Major airline ends 53-year-old boarding rule", "body": "One of the world's largest airlines will change the way passengers board its planes - half a century after the policy was first put in place.\n\nUS low cost carrier Southwest said the major alteration was because modern customers no longer liked the rule and it was putting potential passengers off.\n\nFrom early 2024, it will end its policy where passengers are not assigned seats and so it's a seat free-for-all when they board.\n\nIt will move instead to the system used by most airlines were seats are assigned prior to boarding.\n\nThe US' third largest carrier by passenger numbers - behind only American and Delta - will also, for the first time, introduce overnight flights and higher priced seats with more leg room.\n\nThe moves comes as Southwest announced an almost 50 per cent drop in its profits from April - June, to $561 million.\n\nAmericans have benefited from cheaper fares due to an overcapacity of flights in the market. While they has seen airline revenue shoot up, as people cram planes profits have fallen.\n\nCEO Bob Jordan noted the longstanding tradition was \"part of Southwest Airlines since our inception,\" reported the New York Post.\n\nIt had been in place for 53 years since the airline was formed in 1971 in Dallas.\n\nCurrently, Southwest passengers are assigned a boarding code at check-in which relates to where they stand in the queue at the gate. People then board in that order. Once on the jet, flyers then choose where to sit from whatever seats remain.\n\nPeople with disabilities are also given priority. In the US that has led to the \"Jetway Jesus\" meme.\n\nThis is the perception that there are long queues of people in wheelchairs at Southwest gates who board first and so get the prime choice of seating.\n\nHowever some flyers have claimed - not always fairly - that a number of these passengers then miraculously don't need a wheelchair when they leave the plane, as if they have been heeled by a messiah on the jet way.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium leg room options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the company,\" said Mr Jordan.\n\nSouthwest justified the move from survey data that showed 80 per cent of its current customers and 86 per cent of potential customers preferred having assigned seats.\n\n\"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers,\" said Mr Jordan.\n\nSouthwest has also announced it will offer red eye flights across the US.\n\nTravelling through the night from the west to east coasts - from San Francisco to New York for instance - is common in the US due to the time zones and large land mass. It's similar to overnight flights offered from Perth to the east coast.\n\nBut Southwest, almost uniquely among its rivals, has never flown scheduled trips that land after 11pm California time due to IT and staffing issues.\n\nSouthwest's first overnight flights will launch on Valentine's Day 2025 on five routes: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and The first overnight flights will land next Valentine's Day in five initial nonstop markets:\n\nEventually, the airline will roll out red-eye flights to other markets.\n\nSouthwest Airlines to offer direct flights from Rochester NY to Las Vegas\n\nSouthwest entered the Rochester market in 2013. On Oct. 3, it will begin offering direct service between Frederick Douglass Greater Rochester International Airport and Harry Reid International Airport in Las Vegas.\n\nFlights will operate four {"uri": "8243004649", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:02:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:02:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:02:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://qz.com/southwest-airlines-open-seating-profits-q2-2024-1851604590", "title": "Southwest Airlines is getting rid of open seating in a big change as profits plummet", "body": "Southwest Airlines is finally getting rid of its open seating plan as it looks to pull off a massive turnaround.\n\nThe Dallas-based airline's profits declined 46% in the three months ended June 30, despite bringing in record quarterly revenue of $7.35 billion, the company said Thursday. Bob Jordan, Southwest's president and CEO, blamed the weak quarterly performance on \"both external and internal factors\" and said the company is \"taking urgent and deliberate steps\" to improve margins.\n\nThose steps include getting rid of the airline's long-standing open seating plan, which has given the customers the ability to choose any available seat when they board for 50 years.\n\n\"As we announced this morning, our implementation of assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade to the Customer Experience, one that research shows customers overwhelmingly prefer,\" Jordan said in a statement.\n\nRead more: Southwest Airlines is under new FAA scrutiny after a series of safety issues\n\nThe airline carried out more than eight million simulation-based boarding trials, and found that 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seating over the airline's previous free-for-all approach. Southwest also said the results showed that when a customer opts to fly with a competitor airline, open seating is cited as the No. 1 reason for the change.\n\nOther changes include premium seating with extra legroom and overnight flights, the airline said. The changes are part of Southwest's \"modernization efforts,\" which in past years have included the addition of in-flight WiFi, charging ports, and larger overhead bins.\n\nDespite the announcement, Southwest stock fell 6% in pre-market trading Thursday.\n\nThe weak results were not unexpected. Late last month, the company adjusted its guidance for the quarter and said it's \"intensely focused on improving its financial results.\" After reporting a $231 million loss in the first quarter of the year, Southwest similarly took immediate action, including layoffs and eliminating service to handful of airports. Southwest said it expects to end the year with 2,000 fewer employees than it had to start 2024.\n\nSouthwest is also facing pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management, which bought a $2 billion stake in the airline in early June. Elliott is expected push the company to shake up some of its business practices, including potential changes in the C-suite, in an effort to get its performance off the ground.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243005020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:03:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:03:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:02:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.rocketnews.com/2024/07/southwest-to-get-rid-of-open-seating-offer-extra-legroom-in-biggest-shift-in-its-history/", "title": "Southwest to get rid of open seating, offer extra legroom in biggest shift in its history - RocketNews", "body": "In this articleLUVFollow your favorite stocksCREATE FREE ACCOUNTA Southwest commercial airliner takes off from Las Vegas on Feb. 8, 2024.Mike Blake | ReutersSouthwest Airlines is ending open seating and will offer extra legroom seats on its airplanes as mounting pressure on the carrier to increase revenue prompts the biggest changes to its business model in its 53 years of flying.The airline plans to start selling the first flights that will offer extra legroom next year, it said Thursday. The airline also plans to start overnight flights, starting in February.Southwest executives have said for years that they were studying such changes and hinted in April that it was seriously considering assigning seats and offering pricier seats with more legroom. The airline currently puts customers in one of three boarding groups and assigns a number, setting off a mad dash to check in a day before the flight. Customers can get earlier boarding though if they pay for a higher-priced ticket, they'll get a better boarding slot.When travelers choose a competitor over Southwest, the airline found in its research that its open seating model was the No. 1 reason for that choice, the carrier said in a release that outlined the changes. It also said 80% of its own customers prefer an assigned seat.\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in a news release Thursday.The airline is under even more pressure now to segment its product like other airlines after activist investor Elliott Investment Management disclosed in June a nearly $2 billion stake in the airline and called for new leadership as the airline underperformed competitors.\"We will adapt as our customers' needs adapt,\" Jordan said at an industry event last month.Southwest said it expects about a third of the seats on its Boeing 737s will offer \"extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\" The Federal Aviation Administration would need to approve the cabin layouts, the airline added.The Dallas-based airline had prided itself and raked in steady profits for most of its more than five decades of flying on its simple business model. Jordan said last month that not assigning seats was easier to offer when planes weren't so full.Analysts criticized Southwest for moving too slowly. Rival carriers offer a host of options to upsell customers like extra legroom seats, premium economy or business class. Other airlines, however, like Delta, United and American, four years ago took a cue from Southwest and ended flight-change fees for most tickets.Southwest will provide more details about the upcoming changes at an investor day at the end of September.Read more CNBC airline newsSouthwest to get rid of open seating, offer extra legroom in biggest shift in its historyBoeing's missteps have cost it billions. {"uri": "8243569421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:00:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:00:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:00:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/southwest-seating-change-what-it-means/", "title": "Here's why Southwest is assigning seats  --  and what it means for customers", "body": "Southwest will start selling assigned seats, marking a major shakeup of a signature policy that has set the low-cost carrier apart from airlines for half a century. The new policies, announced Thursday, will make flying Southwest look and feel remarkably different for customers.\n\nThe new policies will affect how customers select seats and board planes. Southwest passengers, including longtime fans of the open seating policy, will also now be able to choose different types of seats for a price, including those with more legroom. These changes could affect ticket costs across the board, according to experts, although Southwest has not addressed pricing, or indicated that regular seat costs will change.\n\nSome experts are cheering the move, saying it's an improvement for both passengers and the airline.\n\n\"Southwest's decision to start assigning seats and plan to add extra-legroom seats prove an old dog can learn new tricks,\" Henry Harteveldt, president of Atmosphere Research Group, told CBS News. \"It will make their flights more orderly and comfortable. And it should also improve the airline's bottom line as well.\"\n\nSouthwest will begin selling tickets with assigned seats beginning in 2025. The airline will reveal additional details around changes to the flight boarding process in September.\n\nHere are three ways flying Southwest could change.\n\nSouthwest is ending its open seating policy, in which customers find a cabin seat on a first-come, first-serve basis. When the changes go into effect next year, customers will purchase tickets with assigned seating, eliminating some of the stress associated with the current boarding process.\n\n\"It's a pretty big change for Southwest, which always had an open seating system, and you had to run into the cabin and try to find the seat you want,\" Clint Henderson, managing editor of The Points Guy, told CBS MoneyWatch.\n\nHenderson said this turned off some business travelers like himself from choosing to fly Southwest, and he predicted the change could attract a new crop of customers to the airline.\n\n\"Many business travelers don't want to fight for a seat and deal with the drama that sometimes entails,\" Henderson said.\n\nTensions can run high on airplanes too, with testy passengers quibbling over limited and sometimes shared real estate.\n\n\"Since the pandemic, airline passengers may be less cordial and less amicable,\" said airline customer experience analyst Marbue Brown. \"There are certainly benefits to environments where there is no ambiguity about who owns a seat.\"\n\nIn addition to assigned seats, Southwest will introduce premium seating, offering passengers extended legroom on one-third of a cabin's seats.\n\nSouthwest already lets customers pay to be first in line to board aircraft, \"but this is a much bigger change now, with premium seats available for purchase,\" Going.com's Keyes said.\n\nThe airline is likely responding to travelers' penchant for more premium travel experiences following the pandemic, according to Keyes. \"The demand is for premium economy, business class and better seats, which Southwest doesn't have to offer,\" he said.\n\nSouthwest's seats already offer more legroom than traditional carriers', which has been a selling point for the airline. They come with 32 inches of space, versus the industry standard of 30-31 inches. It's possible Southwest's new cabin configuration could shrink its current standard of 32 inches of space, some experts said.\n\n\"They haven't announced the new cabin design, but the most likely outcome is we're going to see that 32 inches of legroom to start to shrink for main cabin, and for it to be more like 31 or 30,\" Scott Keyes, founder of Going.com, told CBS MoneyWatch. \"That's normal for people who are used to flying American or United, but cramped for people who fly Southwest.\"\n\nThe new cabin configurations could drive up ticket prices across the board because Southwest's aircraft might contain fewer number of total seats, industry analysts said. On the other hand, the dramatic policy changes could be price-neutral, depending on how Southwest redesigns its plane cabins.\n\n\"Some folks will pay more for extra legroom, and, based on how you reconfigure planes, you might not have to raise prices on other seats,\" Brown said.\n\nWhat remains to be seen is whether Southwest will introduce a bare-bones, basic economy-type offering.\n\nCurrently, all tickets come with free checked bags and free changes. \"But might they start to offer an economy package that includes more restrictions on baggage? That's something we'll have to wait and see,\" Keyes said.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243408662", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:39:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:39:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:39:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.kuow.org/stories/southwest-airlines-says-assigned-and-premium-seating-will-replace-open-seating-plan", "title": "Southwest Airlines says 'assigned and premium seating' will replace open seating plan", "body": "An unofficial motto of Southwest Airlines' open seating process for its people boarding its planes was once, \"You can sit anywhere you want -- just like at church.\"\n\nBut after some 50 years, Southwest passengers will soon encounter a different process when they book and board a flight. The airline will offer assigned and premium seats and a revamped boarding model, it announced on Thursday.\n\nAdopting a system of \"assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade\" for customers, Southwest President and CEO Bob Jordan said, adding that research shows passengers \"overwhelmingly prefer\" an assigned-seat system like that used by other carriers.\n\nIn another change, Southwest also said it would introduce redeye flights. It did not say when the new policies would be enacted.\n\nThe company unveiled the dramatic shifts in how it does business as it announced financial results for the second quarter, showing net income of $367 million on record operating revenues of $7.4 billion. In the previous quarter, Southwest lost $231 million. The airline has $11 billion in liquid funds, but it also has $8 billion in debt and is affected by the ongoing struggles at Boeing, its longtime partner.", "source": {"uri": "kuow.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "KUOW-FM (94.9, Seattle)"}, "authors": [{"uri": "bill_chappell@kuow.org", "name": "Bill Chappell", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Jordan_(businessman)", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Bob Jordan (businessman)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Chief executive officer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Airline"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_name", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Trade name"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 89}], "image": "https://kuow-prod.imgix.net/store/f7d1fbaa138038cd9f210625b8cb882b?fm=jpg&fit=max&w=1200&h=628&q=80", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.02745098039215688, "wgt": 176, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243777218", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:50:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:50:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:49:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/southwest-airlines-plans-to-start-assigning-seats-breaking-with-a-50-year-tradition/article_5aecd835-1863-5ab0-b965-6fad3f950990.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats, breaking with a 50-year tradition", "body": "By DAVID KOENIG - AP Airlines Writer\n\nDALLAS (AP) -- Goodbye, cattle call.\n\nSouthwest Airlines said Thursday that it plans to drop the open-boarding system it has used for more than 50 years and will start assigning passengers to seats, just like all the other big airlines.\n\nThe airline said it has been studying seating options, running tests and surveying customers. Southwest discovered that preferences have changed over the years and the vast majority of travelers now want to know where they are sitting before they get to the airport.\n\nSouthwest's unusual boarding process started as a fast way to load passengers and limit the time that planes and crews spend sitting idly on the ground, not making money. It helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington teen rebuilds landscape of alma mater for Eagle Scout project Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Man struck by gunfire early Saturday in north Normal Video: Springfield woman ducked, apologized before fatal police shooting McLean County Fair selects 2024 royalty Pritzker, Illinois leaders react to Biden leaving presidential race 'Shocked, horrified,' Illinois leaders condemn police killing of Sonya Massey Funerals today for July 23 Flick Fact: That J.D. Vance beard and its McLean County significance? U High senior Jeremy Coleman willing his way to volleyball future Normal police investigating shots fired Tuesday night Ronald & Wanda Coyne Update: Canton police say missing 2-year-old has been found alive McLean County Fair food vendors offer something for everyone \ud83c\udf2d Bloomington man detained, accused of sexually assaulting teen at knifepoint\n\nIt was one reason that Southwest alone among U.S. airlines remained profitable every year until the coronavirus pandemic.\n\nHere's how it works: Instead of being assigned a seat when they buy a ticket, Southwest customers check in exactly 24 hours before departure to secure their spots in boarding lines. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nThe system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line. Despite that, many Southwest loyalists still love open seating. The airline thinks they will adapt.\n\n\"I know there are going to be customers who say, 'I want to stay with open seating.' It's a minority,\" Southwest CEO Robert Jordan told CNBC, \"but we had the same thing when we switched from plastic boarding passes. We had the same thing when we took peanuts out of the cabin. I'm convinced we can win them over.\"\n\nThe airline said surveys showed that 80% of its customers -- and 86% of \"potential\" customers -- want an assigned seat. Jordan said open seating was the top reason that travelers cited for choosing another airline over Southwest.\n\nSome Southwest passengers reacted with sadness and disappointment to news that open seating is going away.\n\n\"Hearing that announcement today, I was like, no, this is my favorite part of Southwest,\" said Lindsey Magness, who works in college athletics in Oklahoma City.\n\nMagness said that with open seating, she can try for a window seat or, depending on her mood, an aisle. And assigned seating doesn't always work either. Magness said American Airlines seated her away from her husband on their honeymoon trip earlier this summer.\n\nBrandon Bowser of Odenton, Maryland, said he flies on different airlines based on which one has the best deal, but he has found Southwest's open boarding to be faster and less complicated than other airlines.\n\n\"The convenience that comes with being able to pick your own seat is what sets Southwest apart and makes them sort of a preferred airline,\" he said. \"A lot of my friends swear by Southwest, that's all they will fly, and they are completely irate about this decision.\"\n\nAt Chicago Midway airport, Kimberly King was happy to learn of the change. She was at a check-in kiosk with her four children for a flight home to California.\n\n\"I used to fly United a lot and I liked the assigned seats, especially with kids, kind of expecting and knowing where we were going to be,\" King said. \"The only reason really why I continue to fly Southwest is for the free bags.\"\n\nSouthwest still lets passengers check two bags for free. It's been a centerpiece of the airline's advertising campaigns for years. CEO Jordan said Southwest has no plans to end bags-fly-free \"at this point.\"\n\nThere are drawbacks to Southwest boarding. It's hard to get a good spot in line without paying an extra fee. Southwest executives said 60% of passengers check in the first 30 seconds. Those who miss the rush fear there won't be room in the overhead bins for their carry-on bag. Late boarders can struggle to see an open seat anywhere, and start roaming up and down the aisle -- Southwest calls them \"spinners.\"\n\nThere are a number of tricks that passengers use to game the system.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nSome take advantage of early boarding for people who need extra time. Others ignore the age limit (6 or under) for children in families that are allowed to board right after the \"A\" group. Once on the plane, some passengers hold choice seats for mates who are far behind them in line.\n\nPhotos appear occasionally on social media of an unusually large number of people in wheelchairs at Southwest gates. They get to board early.\n\n\"It's certainly one of the things that anger people even if it doesn't have a material impact on them,\" said Brett Snyder, a travel agent and author of the Cranky Flier blog. \"In some cases those are people who have absolutely legitimate reasons. In other cases, it's the 'Jetway Jesus' phenomenon.\"\n\nThat's a reference to recoveries so miraculous that the disability causing the person to need a wheelchair to reach the gate is cured during flight, and they walk off the plane like everybody else.\n\nSnyder doubts that fans of open seating will abandon Southwest.\n\n\"Those people will still fly Southwest,\" he said. \"They may grumble about it, but there's no one else they can go to that has open seating.\"\n\nIn addition to the boarding change, Southwest also plans to convert about one-third of the seats on its planes to premium seating with more legroom, matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers.\n\nThe airline's newest schedule also includes a few redeye flights -- a first for Southwest.\n\nThe overnight flights will start in mid-February on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. More routes will be added over time, the airline said.\n\nThe changes come as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management. The hedge fund argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance and has failed to change with the times. It wants to replace Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.\n\nSouthwest also faces increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a series of worrisome flights, including one that dove within 400 feet of the ocean off Hawaii, two that flew at extremely low altitudes while still miles from landing at airports in Oklahoma and Florida, and another that was discovered to have rudder-area damage after an unusual \"Dutch roll\" wiggle during a flight.\n\nSouthwest announced the seating move and other changes on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue. Airlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million. CEO Robert Isom said the airline was held back by a sales strategy that it is now rolling back and by an oversupply of domestic flights.\n\nAmerican said its earnings per share in the third quarter will be break-even, well below Wall Street's expectation of 48 cents per share. American also cut its forecast of full-year earnings to between 70 cents and $1.30 per share, down from a previous prediction of $2.25 to $3.25 per share.\n\nShares of the leading U.S. airlines rose Thursday. Southwest Airlines Co. gained 5.5% and American Airlines Group Inc., based in Fort Worth, Texas, rose 4%. Delta, United, Alaska and JetBlue also gained.\n\nAssociated Press writer Wyatte Grantham-Philips in New York and video journalist Teresa Crawford in Chicago contributed to this report.\n\nThis story has been updated to correct that King was interviewed at Chicago Midway airport, not O'Hare.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-07-433460555", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:08:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:08:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.fastcompany.com/91121186/is-southwest-airlines-losing-what-makes-it-southwest-brand-open-seating", "title": "Southwest's new assigned seating is bound to change the brand", "body": "Branded is a weekly column devoted to the intersection of marketing, business, design, and culture.\n\nSouthwest Airlines, a long-beloved brand in a seldom-beloved category, is navigating one of the most turbulent patches in its history -- and lately, the budget-carrier innovator has been considering some truly surprising maneuvers to get back on course. In its most recent disappointing quarterly results, the company reported a loss of $230 million, worse than analysts expected. Its stock is down about 20% since early March.\n\nNow, the airline doing away with one of the key features that has defined it for more than 50 years. Southwest announced it is replacing its open seating policy, which let fliers choose their own seats, with assigned seats. It is also rolling out premium seating options and red-eye flights.\n\nAccording to the research conducted by the company, 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, say they prefer an assigned seat. \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" Southwest CEO and President, Bob Jordan, said in a statement.", "source": {"uri": "fastcompany.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243599069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:30:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:30:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:29:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/heres-why-southwest-assigning-seats-185811953.html", "title": "Here's why Southwest assigning seats, and what it means for customers", "body": "Southwest will start selling assigned seats, marking a major shakeup of a signature policy that has set the low-cost carrier apart from airlines for half a century. The new policies, announced Thursday, will make flying Southwest look and feel remarkably different for customers.\n\nThe new policies will affect how customers select seats and board planes. Southwest passengers, including longtime fans of the open seating policy, will also now be able to choose different types of seats for a price, including those with more legroom. These changes could affect ticket costs across the board, according to experts, although Southwest has not addressed pricing, or indicated that regular seat costs will change.\n\nSome experts are cheering the move, saying it's an improvement for both passengers and the airline.\n\n\"Southwest's decision to start assigning seats and plan to add extra-legroom seats prove an old dog can learn new tricks,\" Henry Harteveldt, president of Atmosphere Research Group, told CBS News. \"It will make their flights more orderly and comfortable. And it should also improve the airline's bottom line as well.\"\n\nSouthwest will begin selling tickets with assigned seats beginning in 2025. The airline will reveal additional details around changes to the flight boarding process in September.\n\nHere are three ways flying Southwest could change.\n\nAssigned seats\n\nSouthwest is ending its open seating policy, in which customers find a cabin seat on a first-come, first-serve basis. When the changes go into effect next year, customers will purchase tickets with assigned seating, eliminating some of the stress associated with the current boarding process.\n\n\"It's a pretty big change for Southwest, which always had an open seating system, and you had to run into the cabin and try to find the seat you want,\" Clint Henderson, managing editor of The Points Guy, told CBS MoneyWatch.\n\nHenderson said this turned off some business travelers like himself from choosing to fly Southwest, and he predicted the change could attract a new crop of customers to the airline.\n\n\"Many business travelers don't want to fight for a seat and deal with the drama that sometimes entails,\" Henderson said.\n\nTensions can run high on airplanes too, with testy passengers quibbling over limited and sometimes shared real estate.\n\n\"Since the pandemic, airline passengers may be less cordial and less amicable,\" said airline customer experience analyst Marbue Brown. \"There are certainly benefits to environments where there is no ambiguity about who owns a seat.\"\n\nSome seats will have more leg room\n\nIn addition to assigned seats, Southwest will introduce premium seating, offering passengers extended legroom on one-third of a cabin's seats.\n\nSouthwest already lets customers pay to be first in line to board aircraft, \"but this is a much bigger change now, with premium seats available for purchase,\" Going.com's Keyes said.\n\nThe airline is likely responding to travelers' penchant for more premium travel experiences following the pandemic, according to Keyes. \"The demand is for premium economy, business class and better seats, which Southwest doesn't have to offer,\" he said.\n\nSouthwest's seats already offer more legroom than traditional carriers', which has been a selling point for the airline. They come with 32 inches of space, versus the industry standard of 30-31 inches. It's possible Southwest's new cabin configuration could shrink its current standard of 32 inches of space, some experts said.\n\n\"They haven't announced the new cabin design, but the most likely outcome is we're going to see that 32 inches of legroom to start to shrink for main cabin, and for it to be more like 31 or 30,\" Scott Keyes, founder of Going.com, told CBS MoneyWatch. \"That's normal for people who are used to flying American or United, but cramped for people who fly Southwest.\"\n\nPrice changes\n\nThe new cabin configurations could drive up ticket prices across the board because Southwest's aircraft might contain fewer number of total seats, industry analysts said. On the other hand, the dramatic policy changes could be price-neutral, depending on how Southwest redesigns its plane cabins.\n\n\"Some folks will pay more for extra legroom, and, based on how you reconfigure planes, you might not have to raise prices on other seats,\" Brown said.\n\nWhat remains to be seen is whether Southwest will introduce a bare-bones, basic economy-type offering.\n\nCurrently, all tickets come with free checked bags and free changes. \"But might they start to offer an economy package that includes more restrictions on baggage? That's something we'll have to wait and see,\" Keyes said.\n\nHydrothermal explosion sends water, rocks flying at Yellowstone National Park's Biscuit Basin\n\nWhat polls say about a Trump-Harris matchup", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airline", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8243206857", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:16:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:16:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:14:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://uk.investing.com/news/company-news/southwest-airlines-to-introduce-assigned-seating-and-premium-options-93CH-3610944", "title": "Southwest Airlines to introduce assigned seating and premium options By Investing.com", "body": "DALLAS - Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE: NYSE:LUV) has announced plans to introduce assigned seating and premium seating options on all flights, a significant shift from its longstanding open seating policy. This change is part of a broader strategy to enhance customer experience and increase shareholder value.\n\nAfter conducting extensive research, which indicated a strong customer preference for assigned seating, Southwest is preparing to revamp its seating arrangements. The data revealed that 80% of Southwest customers and 86% of potential customers favor an assigned seat. The open seating model, a cornerstone of Southwest's service for over 50 years, has been a point of contention for some customers, leading them to choose other airlines.\n\nThe premium seating will offer extended legroom, targeting roughly one-third of the seats on Southwest's fleet, aligning with competitors' offerings on similar aircraft. The company is also working on a cabin redesign that includes new RECARO seats, aiming to provide a more comfortable experience.\n\nIn addition to the seating changes, Southwest is expanding its operations to include redeye flights. Bookings for these overnight flights, starting on Valentine's Day 2025, are now open for select nonstop markets. This move towards 24-hour operations is expected to drive additional revenue and cost savings, aligning with the airline's three-year plan to optimize capacity without increasing aircraft capital deployment.\n\nRyan Green, previously Executive Vice President & Chief Commercial Officer, will lead these initiatives as the new Executive Vice President Commercial Transformation. Green's experience with customer trends and cabin transformation will be pivotal in rolling out these new features.\n\nThe company will provide more details, including product designs, cabin layout, and financial implications, during its Investor Day in late September. The transition to the new seating model will require Federal Aviation Administration approvals, with bookings anticipated to be available in 2025.\n\nSouthwest's leadership, including President, CEO, & Vice Chairman of the Board Bob Jordan and Executive Chairman of the Board Gary Kelly, expressed confidence in these strategic initiatives to meet evolving customer needs while staying true to Southwest's legacy.\n\nThis information is based on a press release statement from Southwest Airlines Co.\n\nIn other recent news, airlines such as American, Southwest, and Alaska Airlines have reported less-than-expected earnings despite a surge in summer travel demand. This is attributed to an oversupply of seats and increased operating expenses.\n\nTD Cowen expressed concerns over America's vulnerability to oversupplied markets and navigating a higher cost environment. Southwest also reduced its second-quarter revenue outlook, citing limited options for significant revenue performance improvement. European airlines are also grappling with similar challenges, with Ryanair (LON:0RYA)'s profits dropping significantly due to a fall in ticket prices.\n\nTD Cowen has revised Southwest Airlines' stock outlook, reducing the price target to $19.00 from the previous $26.00, while maintaining a Hold rating on the shares. This adjustment comes amid concerns over the airline's performance forecasts for the second quarter and second half of 2024.\n\nThe firm also expressed a cautious stance on Southwest's ability to significantly improve its Revenue per Available Seat Mile (RASM) and narrow the profit margin gap with its competitors.\n\nThe Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating a series of incidents involving Southwest Airlines related to low-altitude flights. These incidents have raised questions about operational safety and protocols within the airline. In response, Southwest Airlines has stated that it is working with the FAA to resolve any irregularities and emphasized safety as its utmost priority.\n\nLastly, Southwest Airlines has announced the appointment of Rakesh Gangwal, a seasoned aviation executive, to its Board of Directors. This move comes amidst Elliott Investment Management's call for leadership changes within the company, following Southwest's continued underperformance. In response, Southwest has implemented a \"poison pill\" strategy to prevent Elliott from increasing its stake beyond 12.5%.\n\nAs Southwest Airlines Co. (NYSE: LUV) embarks on a transformation of its seating policy and cabin experience, it's important to consider the company's financial health and market performance, which can be illuminated by key metrics and insights from InvestingPro.\n\nInvestingPro Tips indicate that Southwest holds more cash than debt on its balance sheet, which could provide the financial flexibility needed to implement the new seating arrangements and cabin redesigns. Additionally, while 9 analysts have revised their earnings downwards for the upcoming period, the company is still expected to be profitable this year and has been profitable over the last twelve months.\n\nFrom a financial standpoint, Southwest Airlines has a market capitalization of $15.92 billion and is trading at a high earnings multiple, with a P/E ratio of 40.47. The adjusted P/E ratio for the last twelve months as of Q1 2024 stands at 18.36, signaling investor confidence in future earnings potential. Moreover, the company's revenue growth has been positive, with a 7.6% increase over the last twelve months and a 10.92% quarterly revenue growth in Q1 2024.\n\nFor readers interested in deeper analysis and additional insights, there are more InvestingPro Tips available for Southwest Airlines at https://www.investing.com/pro/LUV. {"uri": "8243049887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:31:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:31:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:31:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.flightglobal.com/airlines/southwest-to-end-50-years-of-open-seating-as-it-overhauls-product/159370.article", "title": "Southwest to end 50 years of 'open' seating as it overhauls product", "body": "Southwest Airlines will end its signature \"open\" seating model and offer premium seating options as it seeks new revenue sources to address concerns around the business's performance.\n\nIt made the announcements as chief executive Bob Jordan outlined second-quarter earnings that \"fell short of what we believe we are capable of delivering\".\n\nSouthwest's net profit fell 46% in the April-June period to $367 million. Its operating profit was down 50% at $398 million on revenue up 5% at $7.5 billion.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives that are designed to drive meaningful top and bottom-line growth,\" Jordan says.\n\nJordan had hinted in late April that the carrier was considering \"transformational\" changes to its cabin, after it recorded a first-quarter loss.\n\nSouthwest says its research shows that the vast majority of its passengers prefer the idea of assigned seating. The move brings to an end the \"open seating\" model that Southwest has been known for throughout its history.\n\nIts premium seating option will involve \"extended legroom\" seats that will account for around one third of the total seats on offer. Southwest says specific cabin layout details are yet to be firmed.\n\nThe airline will also introduce \"redeye\" flights and redesign its boarding processes as part of the transformation effort.\n\nSouthwest says it will release more details - including on timings - on the new products in September.\n\nThe moves comes as United Airlines chief executive Scott Kirby continues to insist that a structural change is under way in the US airline market, where his carrier, along with Delta Air Lines, are prospering at the expense of budget carriers - a dynamic reflected in the earnings at Southwest and other US low-cost carriers in recent quarters.\n\nIt also follows strong criticism of Southwest's leadership and management from investors including Elliott Investment Management, which earlier this month characterised the company's board of directors as \"profoundly out of touch\" with investors. It had previously called on Southwest's leaders to be replaced, while adding that the business \"represents the most compelling airline turnaround opportunity in the last two decades\".", "source": This move comes after considering feedback and recognizing a shift towards longer flights where passengers prefer assigned seating.\n\nOn the same day, Southwest reported better-than-expected second-quarter profits and revenue. The airline also announced its first overnight redeye flights, starting on February 14, 2025, covering routes such as Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore. {"uri": "8243662848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:33:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:33:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:32:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3030460-southwest-airlines-unveils-major-changes-amid-investor-pressure", "title": "Southwest Airlines Unveils Major Changes Amid Investor Pressure | Business", "body": "Southwest Airlines is ending its open seating policy amid pressure from activist investors. Delays in Boeing deliveries and industry-wide pricing pressures have impacted earnings. The airline plans to introduce assigned seating, premium options, and overnight flights to enhance revenue. CEO Bob Jordan highlights a fundamental transformation aimed at financial recovery.\n\nSouthwest Airlines announced sweeping changes on Thursday, including plans to end open seating that has been the hallmark of its brand for decades as it faces investor pressure to improve results and shore up its share price. Earnings have been under pressure in recent quarters, partly because of delays in plane deliveries from Boeing, which have hit revenue and worsened cost pressures. Southwest is also facing pricing pressure as an industry-wide overcapacity in the domestic market has dampened airfares.\n\nBut Southwest's shares have lost about 30% of their value over the past two years, during a time when the broad-market S&P 500 has gained about 37%. Activist investor Elliott Investment Management is pushing for leadership changes, saying the company needs fresh perspectives to compete in the modern airline industry. It has warned of a proxy fight. Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said on Thursday that Elliott has not shown willingness to engage in any meaningful conversations, adding that the airline is taking steps to transform itself and hit its financial goals.\n\n\"We do see this as a fundamental transformation of Southwest Airlines,\" Jordan said on the company's earnings call. That includes the end of open seating that the company has been known for since the 1970s when it started operations, driven by its founder, Herb Kelleher.\n\nShares rose 6% at $28.31 in afternoon trade. While all U.S. carriers are facing pressure to discount fares due to an excess supply of seats in the domestic market, airlines like Delta and United are leaning on long-haul international flights and high-margin premium cabins to protect their profit.\n\nSouthwest currently doesn't offer these products, but said on Thursday that it now plans on offering seats with extra legroom on its airplanes. The company's research shows that 80% of its customers, and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. It also plans to offer premium, extended legroom seats, which will account for roughly one-third of seats across its fleet.\n\nThe company said the new cabin layout will require approvals from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration and is expected to be available for bookings in 2025. U.S. carriers have been reporting strong demand for high-margin premium cabins. Alaska Airlines last week said it would add 1.3 million premium seats annually to its mainline fleet.\n\nThe company said adding premium seats will require little investment, without offering more details. It did not quantify the boost to its earnings and revenue, either. Southwest plans to share more details at its investor day in September. It will also start overnight flights in February.\n\n\"Southwest's announcement of revenue-enhancement initiatives, purporting to offer assigned seating, premium-seating options and redeye flights, comes more than a decade late,\" Elliott Investment said in a statement. Elliott also reiterated its call for a new leadership at the carrier.\n\nJordan said the company currently has no plans to start charging for bags, adding the airline's data shows that a no-bag fee policy is the number one reason customers choose it. Southwest said it was in discussions with Boeing about the negative financial impact it faces from delayed deliveries. It expects compensation in the form of price discounts.\n\nIt expects third-quarter unit revenue to be flat to down 2% year-on-year, while non-fuel operating costs are estimated to be up 11%-13%. TD Cowen analyst Thomas Fitzgerald said Southwest's outlook implies losses in the current quarter and breakeven in the fourth quarter.\n\nSouthwest's second-quarter adjusted profit came in at 58 cents per share, compared with analysts' average estimate of 51 cents per share, according to LSEG data.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "https://www.devdiscourse.com/remote.axd?https://devdiscourse.blob.core.windows.net/aiimagegallery/28_06_2024_12_36_39_4872119.png?width=920&format=jpeg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": {"uri": "8243704889", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:19:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:19:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:18:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/07/25/chicago-travelers-pleased-with-southwest-airlines-decision-to-assign-seats-if-it-doesnt-raise-ticket-prices/", "title": "Chicago travelers pleased with Southwest Airlines' decision to assign seats  --  if it doesn't raise ticket prices", "body": "At Midway International Airport, Amy Schuber gathered her three young children near baggage claim with her husband Thursday afternoon. She was heading back to her home in Oswego after a nearly weeklong vacation in Tampa.\n\nThe 37-year-old was happy with her Southwest flight, namely the relatively cheap price and ability to bring two checked bags for free. But something that can cause a headache, she said, is not having a guarantee that her whole group can sit together.\n\nThis won't be a worry for much longer. The airline announced Thursday that it will start assigning seats and offering premium seating for customers seeking more legroom, a change some loyal travelers at Chicago's airports said they welcome -- if it doesn't raise ticket prices.\n\nAs the dominant airline at the Southwest Side airport, Southwest is used by many Chicagoans and visitors to the city. The airline has some service at O'Hare International Airport, although it moved to trim flights in April.\n\nThe airline said it changed its 50-year model in response to changing consumer preferences, with travelers booking longer flights and wanting an assigned seat. Surveys showed 80% of its customers, and 86% of potential customers preferred assigned seating, and the top reason passengers selected a different airline was Southwest's open seating policy, the company said in a statement. It hopes the moves will generate revenue and boost its financial performance.\n\nDuring Schuber's flight, she said she had to go to the back of the plane to find a spot to sit with her kids, an 8-, 5- and 2-year-old. While she's appreciative of Southwest's family boarding -- which allows two adults traveling with a child 6 years old or younger to board between the \"A\" and \"B\" group -- it would be nice to know where they are seated beforehand.\n\nWhen asked if she would take advantage of the new policy, she replied \"Oh yeah.\"\n\nHenry Harteveldt, an aviation industry analyst who said he's previously worked with Southwest, said it's a \"terrific move\" by the airline that will please many customers and attract new ones. It will \"take away all of the drama\" from open seating, which Harteveldt called \"boarding bingo.\"\n\nSouthwest's boarding process started as a way to quickly load passengers, limiting the time planes and crews spent sitting idly on the ground. In the beginning, the first 30 to check in were put in the coveted \"A\" boarding group, guaranteeing them a window or aisle seat. Dawdlers landed in \"B,\" which was still OK, or \"C,\" which would often result in a middle seat.\n\nWhile it helped the airline operate more efficiently and even squeeze a few more flights into the daily schedule, the system became less democratic over time as Southwest let people pay extra to guarantee a spot near the front of the line.\n\n\"Some people like the community that is built in the boarding lines, and open seating has been a hallmark of how Southwest has operated for more than 52 years,\" Harteveldt said. \"But no business stays the same in a 50-year-plus operating history, and this evolution of how Southwest is going to do business makes a lot of sense.\"\n\nLeena Saleh, 27, flew into Midway Thursday from Florida to visit family. She never particularly minded open-seating, but said it would be convenient to sit by her husband when she doesn't fly alone.\n\n\"I would definitely (select a seat) if it doesn't have any added money, like with some flights you can choose if you put money toward it,\" she said.\n\nAnn Gabriel, who is visiting Chicago from Columbus for her cousin's granddaughter's quincea\u00f1era, agreed. She said as long as the prices stay reasonable and she can check in early she's fine with the change.\n\n\"They have the free bags,\" the 75-year-old said. \"It's a little bit of a cattle call when you get on, but there's plenty of room.\"\n\nSouthwest also plans to sell premium seating with more legroom -- matching a practice that is standard among other large U.S. carriers -- and to offer redeye flights for the first time, starting Feb. 14, on nonstop routes including Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore, with more routes added over time.\n\nExtra legroom options, in previously all-coach cabins, will help Southwest increase its competitiveness in the market, Harteveldt said, as airlines struggle with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on domestic flights. Harteveldt anticipates Southwest will leverage the new seat assignment model to promote its rewards program and credit card, offering loyal customers free or early access to top seats.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, announced the changes on the same day both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue. The airline is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management, which argues that the airline lags rivals in financial performance.\n\nHarteveldt pointed to the airline's decision to keep its two free checked bags policy, despite investor pressure, as an example of it balancing its financial gains and customer satisfaction.\n\n\"I think that Southwest does want to find ways to find a balance between improving its revenue, giving customers much more control over their journey, but also still being fair to customers,\" Harteveldt said. \"And so it remains this relatively egalitarian airline.\"", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "rebecca_johnson@chicagotribune.com", "name": "Rebecca Johnson", "type": {"uri": "8242993285", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:55:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:55:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:54:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://abc7amarillo.com/news/nation-world/southwest-airlines-to-stop-allowing-passengers-to-pick-their-own-seats-red-eye-flights-earnings-call-open-seating", "title": "Southwest to stop allowing passengers to pick their own seats", "body": "(TND) -- Passengers on Southwest Airlines flights will soon have assigned seats and be able to pay a premium for more legroom, breaking a tradition of more than 50 years of allowing travelers to choose their own seats.\n\nIn its earnings call to investors on Thursday, the airline said it had been studying seating options and decided to change its longstanding policy because passengers have shifted their preferences. Changes to the seating policy could also boost revenue, which comes as it had a steep decline in its profits in the second quarter of the year.\n\n\"Our implementation of assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade to the Customer Experience, one that research shows Customers overwhelmingly prefer,\" Bob Jordan, the airline's president and CEO, said in a statement.\n\nSouthwest had used an open-seating model since the airline was founded where passengers line up to get on board and then choosing their own seat once they get on the plane. But on longer flights, passengers want an assigned seat, they said.\n\nThe airline also said it will offer redeye flights for the first time. Its first overnight flights will land on Valentine's Day in nonstop markets like Las Vegas, Baltimore, Los Angeles and Orlando. It's the end of an era for the airline, which debuted the concept on its very first flight in the 1970s.\n\nInstead, it will offer assigned and premium seating as part of a \"strategic transformation.\" In a press release, Southwest said that more than 80 percent of its customers and 86 percent of potential customers preferred assigned seating over open seating. To accommodate the changes, the airline says it is working on a \"refreshed cabin design\" that will include more comfortable seats and the ability to offer premium seats with extended legroom. No timeline was provided for when premium seating would be available. (It's expected that a third of the seats across the fleet will offer it.)\n\nThe airline also announced that redeye flights will be available to book starting today. The first flights will land on Valentine's Day on five routes: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore.", "source": {"uri": in revenue from options like \"economy plus\" seating with extra legroom for slightly higher fares.\n\nZoom out: In addition to the seating changes, Southwest said it would begin offering overnight, redeye flights in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nWhat they're saying: Bob Jordan, Southwest's president and CEO, said in a statement Thursday that the shift to assigned seating and better legroom options \"will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the {"uri": "2024-07-433580574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:09:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:09:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:03:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.mensjournal.com/news/southwest-airlines-ends-boarding-process", "title": "Southwest Airlines to End Controversial Boarding Process After 50 Years", "body": "In a major change, Southwest Airlines will end its controversial open seating boarding process and begin assigning seats to all of its customers. Its the first time in 50 years that the low-cost carrier has changed its unique boarding process, which previously saw customers lining up next to numbered posts when called by boarding group.\n\nAccording to the company, the update comes due to changing customer demand.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" the airline said in a press statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nIt's worth noting, however, that the move will also allow the airline to charge a premium on some of its seats, potentially earning the company more money in the process. There is currently no implementation date for the change, but it comes after months of speculation that open seating was on the chopping block.\n\nThe company is under pressure from both ends, with the three major carriers making significant profits from premium offerings, while budget carriers like Spirit and Frontier offer extremely low ticket prices while charging for add-ons. Investors have been pushing for the company to become more profitable. Southwest currently stands alone amongst major airlines for offering two complementary checked bags to all customers, and it doesn't charge for changed flights.\n\n\"Although our unique open-seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our customers, our people and our shareholders,\" CEO Bob Jordan said.", "source": {"uri": "mensjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Men's Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_mench@mensjournal.com", "name": "Chris Mench", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-433697487", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:40:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:40:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:29:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/25/travel/southwest-open-boarding-change-reactions.html", "title": "Passengers Loved Southwest Airlines' Open Boarding. Now What?", "body": "On Thursday, the airline announced it would eliminate a boarding process that allowed passengers to choose their seats. Many Southwest fans were not happy -- and expressed worry that more changes might be coming.\n\nOn Thursday, Southwest Airlines announced that its unique boarding system allowing passengers to choose their own seats would change to assigned seating. The carrier had been mulling the change for months, but the announcement still came as a shock to passengers, as the open-seating policy had been in place for more than 50 years and earned the airline ardent and loyal fans -- as well as plenty of detractors.\n\nWith open seating, passengers weren't assigned seats at purchase or upon check in, but instead received a boarding position -- a letter group and a number. At the gate, passengers would stand in line according to their boarding position, and then once on the plane, could choose any seat they wanted, first come, first served.\n\nAs word of the change quickly spread, dedicated Southwest travelers expressed strong emotional reactions on social media and the discussion forum on Southwest's website. Some, like Evan Bell, hope the carrier reverses the plan.\n\n\"I'm definitely discouraged from flying with Southwest,\" said Mr. Bell, of Indianapolis. \"I looked forward to flying with them, because I could sit anywhere.\"\n\nTo Mr. Bell and other passengers, the airline had little comfort: \"We know that assigned seating is not preferable for every customer,\" it responded repeatedly on X to worried posts. \"We're evolving to meet changing customer preferences, and our research clearly indicates a desire for assigned seating.\"\n\nTravelers also speculated online about when assigned seating would begin next year, how it would work with current expedited boarding offerings and what other changes could follow: Will the airline charge for assigned seats, putting it squarely in line with most other domestic airlines? And what about the two free checked bags that Southwest allots each traveler, another of the airline's idiosyncrasies. When other airlines are increasing baggage fees, will that appreciated perk disappear as well?\n\nOpen seating, which felt classless, was a hallmark of the Southwest flying experience\n\nOpen seating was a primary reason they remained loyal to Southwest, many travelers said, and the policy was a major differentiator from competing carriers.\n\n\"I liked open seating because it didn't classify people based on levels or cost, rather people could sit anywhere,\" said Mr. Bell, 27, who works in communication and marketing. The airline's decision felt, he said, like \"just another corporate money grab.\"\n\n\"Why do I have to pay for a seat? If I wanted that I would go to Delta, American or United,\" he continued. \"Flight tickets already cost a lot, so why nickel-and-dime folks more?\"\n\nSome travelers believe that the policy was more efficient than that of other airlines and shaved minutes off boarding.\n\nBut others remarked that the airline's open boarding had recently been on a steady decline, saying they saw other travelers engaging in bad or improper behavior, like saving seats for others and abusing expedited boarding policies.\n\nOne person posted on Reddit said they saw lines of more than a dozen people in wheelchairs waiting to board Southwest flights early. The poster alleged that upon arrival, some travelers seemed to no longer need the assistance.\n\n\"The flights to Vegas are miraculous,\" another person wrote. \"Half the plane is healed over the Rocky Mountains!\"\n\nFlexibility for business travelers\n\nThe flexibility provided by open boarding facilitated -- and eased -- last-minute work travel, one business traveler said.\n\nBefore moving to Cleveland in 2020, Michael Gerhart flew Southwest for years from Bradley International Airport in Hartford, Conn., reaching the airline's A-list status that granted same-day changes and priority boarding -- yes, even Southwest had tiers.\n\n\"I didn't have to pay more for preferred seating, and then have to justify it to my company's accountants, but had my choice of seating on any flight,\" said Mr. Gerhart, a 49-year-old industrial sales executive. \"I hate shuffling slowly through first class, and comfort class, then having to fight for baggage space on other airlines, unless I pay a load more. It's demeaning.\"\n\nComing soon: premium seating\n\nSouthwest has been struggling financially: The airline reported a loss of $231 million for the first quarter of this year, and cost-cutting measures in recent months included eliminating service to certain airports and reducing its flight schedule at others.\n\nThe policy changes are part of a broader effort \"to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives,\" Bob Jordan, the airline's chief executive, said in a statement on Thursday announcing the airline's second quarter performance, which he said \"fell short.\"\n\nTimothy Sandefur, vice president for legal affairs at the libertarian think tank Goldwater Institute, said in a post on X that the airline had made a \"terrible decision.\"\n\n\"Trying to appeal to new customers by eliminating the things that make existing customers loyal seems unwise,\" he wrote.\n\nUnlike other airlines, Southwest doesn't charge for choosing a seat, and it's unclear if this will change when assigned seating begins next year. The carrier also announced on Thursday that it will begin offering premium seating with more legroom, a popular and potentially lucrative option sold by other airlines, in a bid to increase revenue.\n\nFollow New York Times Travel on Instagram and sign up for our weekly Travel Dispatch newsletter to get expert tips on traveling smarter and inspiration for your next vacation. Dreaming up a future getaway or just armchair traveling? Check out our 52 Places to Go in 2024.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "christine_chung@nytimes.com", "name": "Christine
