{"uri": "8242974533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:44:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:44:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:43:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/transportation/2024/07/25/southwest-ends-open-seating/", "title": "Southwest Airlines to shift to assigned seats, offer red-eye flights", "body": "The carrier, long known for its unique model of having passengers board in groups of 30 and then choose their seats once on board, said it will now assign seats and unveil \"premium seating options\" that offer more legroom. In its announcement, the carrier said it expects about one-third of seats across its fleet to offer more legroom.\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said in a statement.\n\nThe company said its research showed that 80 percent of its customers and 86 percent of \"potential\" customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\n\"When a Customer elects to stop flying with Southwest and chooses a competitor, open seating is cited as the number one reason for the change,\" it said in a news release.\n\nJordan first hinted at the change in April. \"But early indications both for our customers and for Southwest look pretty darn interesting,\" he said at the time.\n\nThe changes are the most significant shifts in decades for the airline, which built its reputation as a scrappy discount underdog but has evolved to become one of the dominant carriers in the United States. Even so, Southwest has been under pressure to boost revenue. As other airlines have found ways to charge for various \"upgrades,\" including more legroom and early boarding, Southwest's model left it with few options.\n\nThe carrier will also begin offering overnight \"red-eye\" flights, confirming an announcement from earlier this year. It said the flights will begin in February, with the first overnight flight landing on Valentine's Day 2025. {"uri": "8243179876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:57:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:57:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:57:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://richmond.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_207f7162-4f4c-58d2-966e-7e9fa0a4332d.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nPeople are also reading... Richmond's Columbus statue finds new home outside Virginia EAT Restaurant Partners opening two more restaurants in 2025 Gill endured turbulent 9 years as Hanover superintendent New Virginia state law changes the way reading is taught Woman featured on '16 and Pregnant' pronounced dead in Sandston Review of city's credit card program shows apparent violations, misuse UPDATE: Police identify man found dead in vehicle in Chesterfield pond Youngkin names Scalia daughter to Board of Education Pipe leak that led to James River health advisory began July 2 'It's just a tragic situation' The nearly forgotten law that kept Virginia universities segregated for 30 years Douglas Freeman pitcher Cayman Goode drafted by Atlanta Braves, plans to go pro Dive team recovers body of man reported missing in Chesterfield County Williams: Hanover leadership drain is a preview of Project 2025 Richmond police officer Mervin Mayo wows judges on 'America's Got Talent'\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-02", "textStart": 1669, "textEnd": {"uri": "8243369913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:11:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:11:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:10:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://viewfromthewing.com/southwest-airlines-abandons-its-brand-can-assigned-seats-premium-cabin-and-redeyes-save-them/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Abandons Its Brand: Can Assigned Seats, Premium Cabin, And Redeyes Save Them? - View from the Wing", "body": "Southwest Airlines has been the most consistently profitable airline in the United States for decades. Coming out of the pandemic, though, they've struggled. There are two basic reasons why.\n\nThey have several strategies to address their deficiencies. None of them address their fleet limitations, that don't allow them to serve smaller or farther-flung destinations. They've toyed around with partnerships and codeshares that would allow them to sell more destinations but that hasn't been part of the recent narrative.\n\nWhat the airline is doing is trying to get customers to spend more, in part by flying their current planes more and in part by shifts in their product. These are likely to offer mixed results.\n\nThis is a huge break for Southwest Airlines. I expected they would offer some premium seating, and that this would require assigning those seats, but that they would keep boarding groups for the rest of the cabin. That's not the direction they're going.\n\nCurrently Southwest sells Early Bird check-in, which means earlier boarding and better seats. They earn hundreds of millions of dollars from this product. And their most expensive Business Select fares come with the first 15 boarding slots on a flight. That's the reason to buy up. So monetizing seat assignments isn't all revenue upside. It's unclear how much it will contribute to the bottom line.\n\nHowever the airline recognizes that while their seating method is beloved by some, it also keeps many others away from choosing the airline. I don't like queueing half an hour before my flight. I'd prefer to board at my leisure and have my chosen seat.\n\nOn the other hand, though, the current seating strategy means that most seats are available when you board. On competitors, the best seats are often booked up weeks prior to travel. If you make last minute travel plans, or change your travel plans, you have a shot at a better seat on Southwest but often not on competitors.\n\nSouthwest's current boarding is also highly efficient, getting people queued and onto planes quickly. It supports their quicker turnaround times and in turn makes their aircraft utilization more efficient. That saves them money - the cost of several planes a year.\n\nAssigned seats will appeal to some, not others, and comes with real inefficiencies. So it's an open question how this plays out.\n\nOf course there are two other huge advantages seat assignments will bring,\n\nWith one simple change - assigned seating - you'll solve many of the problems that turn boarding a Southwest Airlines flight into an exercise in game theory.\n\nThe reason you want to board earlier and select your seat is to get a better seat. That may just mean an aisle seat, but it can also mean one nearer the front or one that offers more legroom.\n\nAnd for longer flights especially knowing you'll have enough space to open your laptop and work matters, or just not to feel squished.\n\nSouthwest hasn't been able to meet market demand for this. I'd certainly prefer extra legroom coach over non-extra legroom coach, either via my status or even paying (a reasonable price) for it.\n\nThis makes sense, and it requires some element of assigned seating or else early boarders would just take the best seats. Everyone would fake a wheelchair-requiring disability!\n\nWe don't yet know whether the premium seat product will come with other benefits, like free drinks or upgraded snacks?\n\nAdding premium seats means giving more space to some seats and that space has to come from somewhere. You can remove rows of seats, and potentially sell fewer tickets. Southwest could do that with their lower load factors, but trying to appease Wall Street that seems unlikely.\n\nCurrently Southwest and JetBlue offer the most space per passenger in regular coach of any airline, up to a couple more inches at every seat compared to Delta, United and American. They really do not promote this.\n\nThey also are introducing new seats that appear firmer and less padded. That offers the potential of some additional space in the cabin. There is a strong likelihood that premium seat space comes at the expense of space in the rest of the cabin.\n\nSouthwest Airlines is introducing redeye flying, and has added flights into its schedule starting in February such as\n\nLos Angeles - Baltimore at Southwest.com\n\nThis makes sense. First, they already have the planes, so the additional overnight flying is relatively inexpensive. They need to pay for crew and fuel, but they've added this flying into their labor contracts. Second, it allows connections and destination pairs that weren't previously possible. Southwest is big in Hawaii, but without redeye departures from Hawaii they're limited to mostly passengers between Hawaii and the West Coast. They can't fly passengers from Hawaii to Texas, for instance, without an overnight.\n\nIt's not a panacea, and this is likely to be lower-yield revenue overall on these flights. Cheap overnight seats could also compete down the fares they're able to get on other service. But it makes sense.\n\nSouthwest's core value proposition has been 'Transfarency' that they don't nickel and dime you. Before the majors went along, they had no change fees (but you do pay a difference in fare when changing flights). They don't charge for up to two 50 pound checked bags. Now their flight credits don't even expire.\n\nThe airline hasn't had a basic economy product - everyone has had access to the same fares regardless of the experience they wanted to buy. They didn't price discriminate between price-insensitive business travelers and price-sensitive leisure travelers. And they have used only incremental benefits of more expensive fare types to try to get customers to spend more.\n\nThere's been much discussion of the likelihood that they'll impose basic economy. They might even preserve free checked bags... but only one, rather than two. They could limit full-sized carry-ons like United does. They could make seats available for assignment only at check-in. And they could make fares non-changeable. Basic economy is an idea that's been pushed by activist investors who took a nearly $2 billion stake in the airline, and who are pushing for a change in leadership.\n\nThe best value benefit in travel is the Southwest Airlines Companion Pass. Regular flyers, or those earning substantial points through their co-brand credit card, can bring someone with them for just the cost of taxes. If there are two seats for sale, that second one is virtually free.\n\nAnd Southwest's elite members get to extend their earlier boarding privileges to their companion. That means they currently get the best seats for both passengers at no extra cost.\n\nIn a paid seating arrangement, where elites may not have access to all of the paid seating options free, what happens to companion seating? In other to sit together, and sit together in better seats, will the companion need to pay a seat fee? If so, the companion cost might go from just security taxes to security taxes plus the cost of preferred seating - making companion travel more costly, and the companion pass less valuable.\n\nTo offer elite benefits comparable to domestic competitors like American, United and Delta, elite members will need some access to complimentary assigned seats - perhaps not premium seats, at least until check-in if still available - but some seating benefit.\n\nAnd top elites should have access of some sort to premium seats, whether in advance or subject to availability at check-in. We don't know yet the extent to which this will be offered.\n\nSouthwest is currently offering elite status for sale through end of next year, and promoting an earlier boarding position, which people buy precisely to get the best seats. Surely they can't pull a bait-and-switch.\n\nWill Southwest still offer to sell earlier boarding? If they keep free checked bags for everyone, even basic economy, the only reason left to board early (since it doesn't gain seat choice) is overhead bin space but in general Southwest has less of a problem with that since passengers don't try to haul all their belongings on to save on bag fees.\n\nWe'll get some color during the Southwest Airlines earnings call today, but for the most part aren't likely to learn the answers to key questions at least until their Investor Day this fall and then closer to the launch of changes early next year.\n\nThey need to take care not to lose the value proposition that does still distinguish them, and for which the market continues to value their business at a higher multiple than competitors, even as they work to provide a product that more people want to buy and to pay more for. But they also need to address their inability to sell small town and long haul flights through partners in order to continue to grow.", "source": {"uri": "viewfromthewing.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243134401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:27:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:27:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:25:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/southwest-airlines-seats-flying-red-eye-b2585810.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines ends 50-year tradition as it announces major change to policy", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nAn American airline is doing away with a 50-year tradition in a bid to boost profit.\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to start assigning seats, as well as premium seating for customers who are seeking more legroom.\n\nThe airline said on Thursday that it has been studying customer preferences and expectations and is making the changes because of what they've heard, but it could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nWhile Southwest has used an open seating model for 50 years, the company said that it understands that preferences have changed, with more customers taking longer flights and wanting an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline said it will also offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nEarlier this week it was revealed drinks cans are rupturing on Southwest flights, in some cases injuring flight attendants, as extreme heat continues.\n\nAccording to CBS News, airline officials say they're aware of a series of incidents involving carbonated drink cans rupturing mid-flight while being opened. So far this summer, the instances have resulted in 20 reported employee injuries.\n\nSome of the employees had injuries to their hands. At least one needed to get stitches.\n\n\"We're aware of this issue and have been taking steps to keep onboard beverages cooler, especially in our airports experiencing extreme temperatures,\" a spokesperson for the airline said in an emailed statement to The Independent. \"It's a cross-functional effort between our airport teams and those in the air.\"\n\nSimilar issues occurred last year but the new ones are creating more interest because they appear to be happening more frequently, the outlet reported. The airline reportedly said it is working to rectify the issue at its hotter locations, which include Austin, Dallas, Houston, Phoenix, Las Vegas and Sacramento.\n\nSouthwest Airlines canceled nearly 17,000 flights over 15 days in December 2022 during the winter storm. A Transportation Department investigation ended with the company agreeing to pay a $35 million fine as part of a $140 million settlement.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243796026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:13:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:13:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:12:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.denver7.com/news/local-news/southwest-flyers-react-to-the-company-ditching-open-seating", "title": "Southwest flyers react to the company ditching 'open seating'", "body": "DENVER -- There are big changes coming to Southwest Airlines starting next year as the company gets rid of its signature open seating model.\n\nCurrently, passengers check-in for their flight and are assigned a number to get in line during boarding. Once they're on-board, they are free to take whatever seat they'd like. That will go away and it will be replaced with assigned seating.\n\nIt's something Southwest has been known for more than 50 years, but company officials said after polling it's own customers and potential travelers aboard their airline, the choice was clear.\n\nSouthwest officials said 80% of their customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. The reaction from travelers across the nation has been mixed.\n\n\"Shock and awe to some extent, it probably doesn't matter in the grand scheme of things, but it's one of the things that seems like it defined Southwest,\" said Chris Spence, who travels with his wife and kids using Southwest.\n\n\"I actually kind of like that. I wonder it's going to change the prices. But there's something about knowing I'm going to be on the aisle or I'm going to be by the window, especially being tall,\" said Jeneine Welch, a Southwest flyer.\n\n\"I was livid, because the reason I fly with Southwest is because of their flexibility and the lack of assigned seating,\" said another traveler, Cynthia Reed.\n\nIn addition to the company's research, they said they did over eight million simulation-based boarding trials before making their decision.\n\nSouthwest will also offer a premium, extended legroom options, although pricing for any of the changes have not been determined yet. A spokesperson with Southwest told Denver7 more details on that would be released in September.\n\nIn a statement, President, CEO & Vice Chairman of Southwest's Board, Bob Jordan said:\n\n\"Moving to assigned seating and offering premium legroom options will be a transformational change that cuts across almost all aspects of the Company. Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders. We are excited to incorporate Customer and Employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver. We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nPassengers Denver7 spoke with said another main draw to Southwest is their policy of allowing passengers to check two bags for free. That policy is remaining in place and is not changing.\n\nWith Southwest's open seating rule ending, Denver7 asked frequent travelers their advice on how handle the unique boarding experience.\n\n\"I think it's willing to be flexible, so I'm kind of happy with anything I've ridden on all parts of the plane,\" said Reed.\n\n\"Get it in your mind that you're going to have a seat, and it may not be exactly where you want, but you're going to have a seat, and just let it go,\" said Welch.\n\n\"Some people get a little touchy. This morning, there was a guy in line and I [had to ask], 'What's your number?' And he was like, 'This is it.' So I'm like, 'Okay then. I am in the right spot.' You know, people be people,\" explained Michelle Polson of handling confrontational customers who are unfamiliar with Southwest's boarding process.\n\nColoradans making a difference | Denver7 featured videos Denver nonprofit helping bridge Colorado labor shortage gap by teaching trade skills Denver City Council skeptical of Mayor Mike Johnston's affordable housing sales tax plan Unhealthy air quality has Coloradans concerned about short, long-term health impacts Chime Banking App refunds money to Aurora woman after scammer drains account Organizers hope to create a new Asian American Community Center in Centennial\n\nAt Denver7, we're committed to making a difference in our community. We're standing up for what's right by listening, lending a helping hand and following through on promises. {"uri": "2024-07-433587547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:16:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:16:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:36:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.scarymommy.com/lifestyle/southwest-airlines-assigned-seats-news", "title": "Southwest Airlines Is Getting Rid Of Their Open Seating Policy", "body": "The change, while polarizing, could be a great thing for families.\n\nAfter over 50 years, Southwest passengers will no longer select any seat they want when boarding a flight. Instead, the airline will offer assigned and \"premium\" seats with a revamped boarding model, the airline announced in a press release.\n\nSouthwest is calling the change \"part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade\" for customers. The company's President and CEO Bob Jordan added that research shows passengers \"overwhelmingly prefer\" an assigned-seat system like that used by other carriers.\n\nThe company said customers have been asking for such changes, noting that people often cite the airline's open seating as top reason they switch carriers.\n\n\"The research is clear and indicates that 80% of Southwest customers, and 86% of potential customers, prefer an assigned seat,\" said the airline in a statement. \"By moving to an assigned seating model, Southwest expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers.\"\n\nPeople had mixed reactions to the change. But let's be real, when you're traveling with family, that s**t is stressful -- especially if you're in a later boarding group. Southwest does offer Family Boarding between Group A and Group B, however, kids must be 6 years of age or younger to qualify.\n\nSeveral X (formally Twitter) users agree with this sentiment, noting that Southwest's out-of-the-box boarding practices are anxiety-inducing, especially when trying to grab a seat with your loved ones.\n\n\"Southwest Airlines used to be what we flew as a family. We stopped flying them because they tried separating my brother and I from our parents on multiple occasions,\" one user wrote after the news broke.\n\n\"American is significantly better than Southwest if you have a family. If you're flying alone it's fine, if you have a child or a wife it's pretty much unusable,\" another said.\n\nAnother user wrote in April 2024, \"I am flying Southwest today because it was the cheapest when I booked. This boarding process is ridiculous. As a solo traveler it kind of makes sense, but why would you ever do this with a partner or family? Is it really that worthwhile with the priority boarding I don't have?\"\n\nOthers were excited for the change, noting that since Southwest introduced the \"Early Bird\" special -- which allowed passengers to pay extra for a higher boarding number -- people had been abusing the system.\n\n\"The strategy I saw is that one person in a family would buy early boarding and save seats for their whole group. I used to enjoy southwest, but once everyone started doing things like this, you either had to pay for early boarding or get stuck with a bad seat,\" they wrote.\n\nSome people were peeved about the change, remarking the end of the Family Boarding process.\n\n\"Unfortunately, I think our family will be flying on something other than @SouthwestAir soon. We loved that the open seating meant that we could guarantee sitting together without paying extra. With that open seating coming to an end, how long until bags don't fly free?\" they asked.\n\nAnother user noted that without open seating, a guaranteed spot next to a friend might not be so easy to obtain.\n\n\"I'm actually disappointed in Southwest decision on assigned seating. I love picking my own seat. Can guarantee I sit with the person I'm traveling with,\" they wrote.\n\nSouthwest did not give details about when the changes will go into effect, but it said it would be discussed further in With declining earnings and delayed Boeing deliveries impacting revenue, the airline will introduce assigned seating and premium options by 2025, aiming to enhance customer appeal and financial performance.\n\nSouthwest Airlines announced major changes on Thursday, including the end of its longstanding open seating policy, as the company responds to investor pressure to improve financial performance and share prices. The changes come as the airline deals with reduced earnings due to delays in Boeing plane deliveries and a surplus of seats in the domestic market.\n\nShares of Southwest have declined by roughly 30% over the past two years, in contrast to the S&P 500's 37% rise. Activist investor Elliott Investment Management is pushing for leadership changes, indicating a potential proxy fight. CEO Bob Jordan stated that while Elliott has been uncooperative in discussions, the airline is committed to transformative steps to reach its financial targets.\n\nAmong these measures, Southwest plans to implement assigned seating and introduce premium, extended legroom seats, making up a third of seating on its fleet by 2025. These changes are contingent on approval from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration. Additionally, the company will start overnight flights in February and remains in talks with Boeing over compensation for delivery delays.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243584338", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:14:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:14:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:13:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/business/airlines/2024/07/25/i-will-still-fly-with-southwest-travelers-react-to-airline-ending-open-seating-policy/", "title": "'I will still fly with Southwest': Travelers react to airline ending open seating policy", "body": "On Thursday, Southwest Airlines announced it was ending its open seating policy.\n\nHiep Nguyen and her husband have a \"system\" for traveling with their four children under 7.\n\nNguyen's husband drops her and the kids off curbside at Dallas Love Field to get ready to board their Southwest Airlines flight. She'll check the kids in for the flight while he parks the car and brings out any heavy luggage. The ease of flying together as a family and the cheap airfares for six people have kept the Prosper-based family loyal Southwest customers for over 10 years, even before they had kids, she said.\n\nAdvertisementAdvertisement\n\nOn Thursday, Southwest announced it would do away with an over-50-year-old open seating policy that allowed passengers to choose wherever they'd like to sit, rather than pay for or be assigned to a seat on a flight, like Southwest's competitors. Southwest did not share further details on the rollout, but it plans to have more information for its investor day in late September.\n\nAviation News\n\nStay prepared. Receive the latest airlines news, delivered straight to your inbox.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nDespite the change, some passengers, like Nguyen, say they remain loyal to the Dallas-based airline, even if the company makes the historic shift to its business model.\n\n\"I will still fly with Southwest,\" Nguyen said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHowever, passengers are curious to how Southwest will implement these changes and if more changes are on the way.\n\nOne question that Nguyen and another Texas mother of three, Jenai Bacon, have is related to family boarding. Southwest has traditionally allowed families to board after its \"A Group\" to allow children to sit with their parents.\n\nBacon, 40, has three children with special needs. Because Bacon's children needed to travel to Houston from their home in Midland for doctor appointments, Southwest has provided cheaper airfares and frequent flight times for the four of them to get where they need to be.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nShe's been flying with Southwest since she was a child and has remained a loyal customer of the airline.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"They really care about their passengers, and I can tell that everyone at Southwest really enjoys their job, because I fly different carriers and Southwest stands out at the top,\" Bacon said.\n\nWhen asked about family boarding, Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said there are still many details Southwest needs to work through. Greene added that almost 60% of Southwest customers are checked in within the first 30 seconds of the 24-hour check-in window and 75% are checked in within the first hour.\n\n\"If you're a busy family and you don't hit the check-in window right on the nose, that causes anxiety,\" Greene said. \"This is a way to solve a lot of those friction points the current open seating process has introduced.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMarbue Brown, an airline customer experience analyst, called it a \"monumental\" change for the airline. Brown is the founder of The Customer Obsession Advantage, an organization that works to help companies achieve business results through \"customer obsession.\"\n\n\"The environment we're in now is not the same as it used to be 50 years ago when they put this policy in place,\" Brown said.\n\nHe said despite the change, the seating policy can be implemented in a \"customer-friendly\" way. He said the reputation of the airline has been built in a way that has created a \"special environment\" for travelers.\n\nBacon said she hopes Southwest will work out those details and communicate with families on how the policy will work. She hopes this won't change the happy memories she's made over the years with the airline, like the time a Southwest gate agent allowed her daughter to sing \"Happy Birthday\" to her over the PA system at Midland International Airport or friendly pilots allowing her children in the cockpit.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nGreg Kelminson, 40, of Richardson said he's been flying Southwest for most of his life, a lot within the last 15 years. He said he has several reasons why he's stayed a loyal customer.\n\n\"They fly out of Love (Field),\" Kelminson said. \"No change fees. Bags fly free. No assigned seats. It just made sense for me for business and personal travel.\"\n\nBut he shares a concern that this might not be the last change Southwest makes. On Thursday's investor call, Jordan said he believes it to be a \"strategic transformation of the company.\"\n\n\"My concern is this is maybe the first domino to fall that makes them lose some of their identity, and what helps make that customer base loyal,\" Kelminson said.\n\nAdvertisement", "source": {"uri": "dallasnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Dallas Morning News"}, {"uri": "8243614683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:46:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:46:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:45:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/25/passengers-loved-southwest-airlines-open-boarding-now-what/", "title": "Passengers Loved Southwest Airlines' Open Boarding. Now What?", "body": "On Thursday, Southwest Airlines announced that its unique boarding system allowing passengers to choose their own seats would change to assigned seating. The carrier had been mulling the change for months, but the announcement still came as a shock to passengers, as the open-seating policy had been in place for more than 50 years and earned the airline ardent and loyal fans -- as well as plenty of detractors.\n\nWith open seating, passengers weren't assigned seats at purchase or upon check in, but instead received a boarding position -- a letter group and a number. At the gate, passengers would stand in line according to their boarding position, and then once on the plane, could choose any seat they wanted, first come, first served.\n\nAs word of the change quickly spread, dedicated Southwest travelers expressed strong emotional reactions on social media and the discussion forum on Southwest's website. Some, like Evan Bell, hope the carrier reverses the plan.\n\n\"I'm definitely discouraged from flying with Southwest,\" said Mr. Bell, of Indianapolis. \"I looked forward to flying with them, because I could sit anywhere.\"\n\nTo Mr. Bell and other passengers, the airline had little comfort: \"We know that assigned seating is not preferable for every customer,\" it responded repeatedly on X to worried posts. \"We're evolving to meet changing customer preferences, and our research clearly indicates a desire for assigned seating.\"\n\nTravelers also speculated online about when assigned seating would begin next year, how it would work with current expedited boarding offerings and what other changes could follow: Will the airline charge for assigned seats, putting it squarely in line with most other domestic airlines? And what about the two free checked bags that Southwest allots each traveler, another of the airline's idiosyncrasies. When other airlines are increasing baggage fees, will that appreciated perk disappear as well?\n\nOpen seating was a primary reason they remained loyal to Southwest, many travelers said, and the policy was a major differentiator from competing carriers.\n\n\"I liked open seating because it didn't classify people based on levels or cost, rather people could sit anywhere,\" said Mr. Bell, 27, who works in communication and marketing. The airline's decision felt, he said, like \"just another corporate money grab.\"\n\n\"Why do I have to pay for a seat? If I wanted that I would go to Delta, American or United,\" he continued. \"Flight tickets already cost a lot, so why nickel-and-dime folks more?\"\n\nSome travelers believe that the policy was more efficient than that of other airlines and shaved minutes off boarding.\n\nBut others remarked that the airline's open boarding had recently been on a steady decline, saying they saw other travelers engaging in bad or improper behavior, like saving seats for others and abusing expedited boarding policies.\n\nOne person posted on Reddit said they saw lines of more than a dozen people in wheelchairs waiting to board Southwest flights early. The poster alleged that upon arrival, some travelers seemed to no longer need the assistance.\n\n\"The flights to Vegas are miraculous,\" another person wrote. \"Half the plane is healed over the Rocky Mountains!\"\n\nThe flexibility provided by open boarding facilitated -- and eased -- last-minute work travel, one business traveler said.\n\nBefore moving to Cleveland in 2020, Michael Gerhart flew Southwest for years from Bradley International Airport in Hartford, Conn., reaching the airline's A-list status that granted same-day changes and priority boarding -- yes, even Southwest had tiers.\n\n\"I didn't have to pay more for preferred seating, and then have to justify it to my company's accountants, but had my choice of seating on any flight,\" said Mr. Gerhart, a 49-year-old industrial sales executive. \"I hate shuffling slowly through first class, and comfort class, then having to fight for baggage space on other airlines, unless I pay a load more. It's demeaning.\"\n\nSouthwest has been struggling financially: The airline reported a loss of $231 million for the first quarter of this year, and cost-cutting measures in recent months included eliminating service to certain airports and reducing its flight schedule at others.\n\nThe policy changes are part of a broader effort \"to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives,\" Bob Jordan, the airline's chief executive, said in a statement on Thursday announcing the airline's second quarter performance, which he said \"fell short.\"\n\nTimothy Sandefur, vice president for legal affairs at the libertarian think tank Goldwater Institute, said in a post on X that the airline had made a \"terrible decision.\"\n\n\"Trying to appeal to new customers by eliminating the things that make existing customers loyal seems unwise,\" he wrote.\n\nUnlike other airlines, Southwest doesn't charge for choosing a seat, and it's unclear if this will change when assigned seating begins next year. The carrier also announced on Thursday that it will begin offering premium seating with more legroom, a popular and potentially lucrative option sold by other airlines, in a bid to increase revenue.", (Aaron P. Bauer-Griffin/GC Images via Getty Images)\n\nSouthwest Airlines announced Thursday that for the first time in its 50-year history, it will ditch its open seating policy in favor of assigned seats.\n\nThe company also said it will begin to introduce red-eye flights and \"premium\" seating with more legroom -- changes that come as the budget airline faces continued financial struggles.\n\nSouthwest said it expects roughly one-third of seats across its fleets to be converted to \"premium\" with extra legroom, which it called \"in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\" Aircraft cabins will be redesigned to accommodate the boarding and seating changes, with an anticipated debut in 2025.\n\nOvernight flights are starting in mid-February with three routes: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville, and Phoenix to Baltimore. {"uri": "8243153861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:39:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:39:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:38:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_121f7a00-d58d-5925-89f7-51536f12daf1.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nPeople are also reading... National Ice Cream Day 2024: Get cool deals and freebies at Dairy Queen, Cold Stone and more HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: All Wolves now playing at West Ridge Bristol Casino records solid $14.35M month during June Kilgore remembered as \"larger than life\" trailblazer Housing complex rehab in Saltville wins $2.4 million state loan Campus keeps tradition strong Only the name has changed; 'The Classic' expected to become bigger and better This theater season brings friendship, camaraderie and nostalgia to the stage Herald Courier receives awards from Tennessee Press Association BRIEFS: VHSL to hold public forum at Abingdon on Wednesday; Top-15 finish for Adam Hooker (Lebanon) at State Open of Virginia HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Next man up part of high school football PREP FOOTBALL: Marquee games await Northeast Tennessee teams Wise free clinics have come a long way in a quarter century Washington board updated on new cell phone directive Southern Gap Outdoor Adventure Unveils New Entrance Sign\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hometown superhero: College Station's Brianna Hildebrand lands in 'Deadpool & Wolverine' Bryan man arrested for alleged sexual abuse of a child New College Station girls basketball coach Shawnte' Goff elated for challenge The Eagle's 2024 All-Brazos Valley Softball Team A&M's Prager passes on Angels and will return A&M Performance, Visualization and Fine Arts dean has big plans for new college Marcus Heard announces transfer to UTRGV Centerville's Pineda commits to Army West Point Bryan minor arrested for aggravated robbery, credit card abuse Watch: SEC's John McDaid explains if 'Horns Down' will be penalized CESSNA: Schedule gives A&M a much better chance to finish higher than it was picked Texas A&M picked 9th in preseason SEC poll, 3 Aggies earn All-SEC honors Texas A&M selected for research security initiative by National Science Foundation A&M's Elko is mending fences with state's high school coaches Trump campaign releases letter on his injury, treatment after assassination attempt\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8243105796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:08:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:08:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:07:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/25/nx-s1-5051580/southwest-airlines-assigned-seats", "title": "Southwest Airlines says 'assigned and premium seating' will replace open seating plan", "body": "An unofficial motto of Southwest Airlines' open seating process for its people boarding its planes was once, \"You can sit anywhere you want -- just like at church.\"\n\nBut after some 50 years, Southwest passengers will soon encounter a different process when they book and board a flight. The airline will offer assigned and premium seats and a revamped boarding model, it announced on Thursday.\n\nAdopting a system of \"assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade\" for customers, Southwest President and CEO Bob Jordan said, adding that research shows passengers \"overwhelmingly prefer\" an assigned-seat system like that used by other carriers.\n\nIn another change, Southwest also said it would introduce redeye flights. It did not say when the new policies would be enacted.\n\nThe company unveiled the dramatic shifts in how it does business as it announced financial results for the second quarter, showing net income of $367 million on record operating revenues of $7.4 billion. In the previous quarter, Southwest lost $231 million. The airline has $11 billion in liquid funds, but it also has $8 billion in debt and is affected by the ongoing struggles at Boeing, its longtime partner.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives that are designed to drive meaningful top and bottom-line growth,\" Jordan said.\n\nThe Southwest CEO said in April that delivery delays of new planes from Boeing, which has been embroiled in regulators' concernsover safety issues, \"presents significant challenges for both 2024 and 2025.\"\n\nIn its update, Southwest said it received five Boeing 737-8 MAX planes in the second quarter while retiring seven older Boeing planes. Southwest had ordered 58 Boeing 737-8 MAX planes for 2024; it now expects to receive around 20 of the aircraft this year.\n\nSouthwest says it's carrying passengers in record numbers. But it's also retiring more aging aircraft than it can add this year: With the delivery delays from Boeing, the airline's fleet will fall from 817 planes at the end of the second quarter to roughly {"uri": "8243399769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:33:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:33:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:31:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/pittsburgh/news/pittsburgh-travelers-react-to-southwest-airlines-ending-open-seating-for-the-first-time-in-its-history/", "title": "Pittsburgh travelers react to Southwest Airlines ending open seating for the first time in its history", "body": "PITTSBURGH (KDKA) - For the first time in the history of Southwest Airlines, the company announced Thursday it's going to start assigning seats, similar to its competitors. Travelers at Pittsburgh International Airport said they have mixed feelings.\n\n\"I can get my seat when I go on,\" Farah Middleton, who lives in Pittsburgh, said.\n\nThis has remained the Southwest model for more than 50 years. You pick your seat on the plane and get the better choice, based on your boarding position and the earlier you check in.\n\nWhile Middleton doesn't mind it, others feel there's always a rush that comes with flying the airline.\n\n\"If I'm flying by myself, I don't really care, but if I'm with my family then I want to sit with them,\" Tomasso Valerio, who lives in Steubenville, Ohio, said.\n\nNow what's synonymous with the company is going away. Southwest will soon have assigned seats and will begin charging for premium seats with more legroom. It also will offer red-eye flights for the first time.\n\nThey're changes welcomed by many travelers like Nancy Steltzer, who lives in Morgantown.\n\n\"People like to have some sort of control over what and where they're going to sit and with who they're going to sit,\" Steltzer said.\n\nThe airline said it will broaden its appeal, citing research showing 80 percent of its customers and 86 percent of potential customers prefer assigned seating. It also says open seating is the top reason travelers stop flying Southwest and choose another airline.\n\nHowever, for Steltzer and Middleton, when picking an airline, seating is not their top priority, and they say that will stay the same.\n\n\"Mostly what I pick is related to where I'm going, you know, what is flying to where I'm going,\" Steltzer said.\n\n\"I will still fly the cheapest deal whether it's Southwest, Delta, United, American, I'll fly them all,\" Middleton said.\n\nIt's unclear when the changes will go into effect, but Southwest said it will provide more details on its plans in late September. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington teen rebuilds landscape of alma mater for Eagle Scout project Riverdale man gets 123 years for 2020 murder in Bloomington Man struck by gunfire early Saturday in north Normal Video: Springfield woman ducked, apologized before fatal police shooting McLean County Fair selects 2024 royalty Pritzker, Illinois leaders react to Biden leaving presidential race 'Shocked, horrified,' Illinois leaders condemn police killing of Sonya Massey Funerals today for July 23 U High senior Jeremy Coleman willing his way to volleyball future Flick Fact: That J.D. Vance beard and its McLean County significance? Ronald & Wanda Coyne Update: Canton police say missing 2-year-old has been found alive Normal police investigating shots fired Tuesday night McLean County Fair food vendors offer something for everyone \ud83c\udf2d Bloomington man detained, accused of sexually assaulting teen at knifepoint\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. Instead, it will begin assigning seats and offer premium, extra leg room seating.\n\nShares of the domestic carrier rose more than 5% in early trading.\n\nSouthwest CEO Bob Jordan said \"our implementation of assigned and premium seating is part of an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade to the Customer Experience, one that research shows Customers overwhelmingly prefer.\"\n\nThe low-fare airline has had a tradition of open seating for more than 50 years. Customers taking longer flights preferred assigned seats, according to Southwest.\n\nAirlines can also charge more for assigned and premium seating, enabling them to boost profits.\n\nBut CFRA equity analyst Zachary Warring didn't seem convinced the airline's declining margins would be helped by the seating change.\n\n\"The company announced the end of its open seating policy in a move to turn around its margin problem, but we believe may upset its customer base,\" Warring wrote on Thursday morning.\n\n\"We remain neutral on shares as we believe the U.S. consumer is showing signs of cracking while capacity remains elevated while LUV's multiple remains elevated,\" he added.\n\nThe changes come amid pressure from activist investor Elliott Management, who earlier this month warned of a proxy fight as it seeks a \"new, truly independent\" board of directors.\n\nSouthwest also announced it will add the introduction of overnight, redeye flights with the first routes starting on Valentine's Day in 2025.\n\nThe carrier also posted its quarterly results on Thursday. Adjusted earnings per share came in at $0.58 versus Wall Street estimates of $0.51. Revenue came in at $7.35 billion versus $7.33 billion expected by analysts.\n\nIncreased competition and higher labor costs have weighed on domestic carrier's profits. {"uri": "8243342796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:50:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:50:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:49:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://johnnyjet.com/huge-news-southwest-airlines-ends-longstanding-open-seating-policy-and-now-selling-seats-for-red-eye-flights/", "title": "Huge news: Southwest Airlines ends longstanding open seating policy and now selling seats for red-eye flights", "body": "This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. For an explanation of our Advertising Disclosure, visit this page.\n\nIf you've ever flown Southwest Airlines (SWA), then you know it's a unique airline in many ways: The airline only uses Boeing 737 aircrafts, they have fun flight attendants, they give customers two free checked bags (up to 50 pounds each), they don't charge change fees, you have to book tickets using their website, they don't fly red-eye flights and most notably, they don't assign seats.\n\nWell, the last three things are changing, according to a big announcement made by the airline today. In May, Southwest\n\nYears ago, when I first learned that the airline didn't do red-eyes, I was extremely surprised ... because aircrafts don't make money on the ground, which was the main reason Southwest didn't offer assigned seating. They wanted to turn the planes around as fast as possible and one way to do that was to have passengers choose any seat they wanted when they got on the plane, instead of trying to figure out where their assigned seat was located.\n\nAlmost all SWA travelers know that not all seats are created equal, which is why some will pay a premium ($30 to $80) to get Southwest Airlines Boarding Group A, so they can board the plane first, snag the exit row seats, bulkhead, or aisle or window seats closest to the front of the cabin, and be among the first to deplane.\n\nNot assigning seats was essentially a social experiment and it always brought out both the best and the worst in people. I met some nice people trying to find my place in line but have also seen the dirty tricks customers with no conscience would play to keep the seat beside them open. The worst trick I saw was when some passengers claimed they had an injury or medical condition that required them to be in a wheelchair so they could get a seat towards the front of the aircraft and not have to pay extra or worry about their bags not making it into the overhead bins.\n\nFlight attendants sometimes quip that they work miracle flights because passengers board with a wheelchair but walk off when they land. It was infuriating for travelers who paid extra or who had a legitimate handicap. The other trick some SWA passengers have played is having just one member of their family or party pay for Group A boarding and then they would save seats for the others. Some flight attendants would crack down on it but others wouldn't. Here are some of the other tricks.\n\nTaylor Swift told the graduates of NYU in her commencement speech a couple of years ago that even her and her mom used to play a funny trick back when she flew commercial. Others do the same, like this guy pretending he's about to throw up in a barf bag or the one below, pretending to be comforting a crying baby under a blanket.\n\nSouthwest's CEO, Bob Jordan, has been under fire because customers were getting sick and tired of the games and ruining the whole SWA experience. Then when a hedge fund, Elliott Management, bought a huge stake in the company, they were pushing for change to make more money and for Jordan to resign.\n\nWell, all those tricks are about to come to an end. Jordan had to cave to save his job and possibly the airline. According to a SWA press release, Jordan said, \"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception, our thoughtful and extensive research makes it clear this is the right choice -- at the right time -- for our Customers, our People, and our Shareholders. We are excited to incorporate Customer and Employee feedback to design a unique experience that only Southwest can deliver. We have been building purposefully to this change as part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience as we focus on Customer expectations - and it will unlock new sources of revenue consistent with our laser focus on delivering improved financial performance.\"\n\nSouthwest also announced it is \"adding 24-hour operation capabilities with the introduction of overnight, redeye flights. Booking on initial routes is available today through Southwest.com, with the first overnight flights landing on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. Southwest plans to phase in additional redeye flying in the carrier's coming schedules as part of its multi-year transformation to a 24-hour operation. Redeye flying, coupled with continued reductions in turn-time through new technologies and procedures, is expected to provide incremental revenue and cost savings, enabling Southwest to fund nearly all new capacity over the next three years without incremental aircraft capital deployment.\"\n\nAs you can imagine, some customers are not happy with the changes but I think it's great. I stopped flying SWA because they didn't assign seats. I didn't want to chance not getting a row without extra legroom so I can work. I don't mind spending more money to have that space.\n\nHow do you feel about these changes? Will they make you more or less likely to fly Southwest Airlines? Leave a comment with your thoughts.\n\nKEEP READING", "source": {"uri": "johnnyjet.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Johnny Jet"}, "authors": [{"uri": "johnny_jet@johnnyjet.com", "name": "Johnny Jet", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_attendant", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Flight attendant"}}, {"uri": (WSMV) - Some big changes are coming to Southwest. The airline revealed it will assign seats, offer premium legroom seating, and start red-eyes including between BNA and LAX.\n\nAs a musician on tour, Asa Wiggins flies with Southwest several times a month. The band likes the open seating - they say if they check in on time they can all sit together, without paying for a seat like other airlines.\n\n\"Southwest has kind of always been different and unique in that way,\" Wiggins said.\n\nBut that is coming to an end - the airline is making the change to assigned seats after they said 80% of their customers prefer it. Wiggins is not part of the 80%.\n\n\"If you're going to be like every other airline, then we're going to choose another airline that maybe has better prices if you're not going to give us the convenience of the relaxed environment that we're used to,\" Wiggins said.\n\nThere will also be new red-eye flights and extra legroom for a price.\n\n\"I'm 5'2 so that's not for me, but I can see why people would,\" Southwest flyer Anna Love said.\n\nFor others - this all comes as good news.\n\n\"This was our first time flying Southwest and I loved it. My only complaint - like I told my husband - was I wish we could have chosen our seats. So this works out for us completely,\" Kassandra Hammond said.\n\nHaving two children - Hammond said picking seats works better. Right now Southwest only has family boarding for children younger than seven.\n\n\"I like to be able to know I'm going to sit by my kid. That's the most important thing,\" Hammond said.\n\nStill - some are holding out hope the airline will reconsider.\n\n\"Don't change Southwest that's why we love you because you're different,\" {"uri": "8243188909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:05:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:05:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:03:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3030020-southwest-airlines-unveils-strategic-changes-amid-investor-pressure", "title": "Southwest Airlines Unveils Strategic Changes Amid Investor Pressure | Business", "body": "Southwest Airlines announced significant changes, including the introduction of assigned seating and extra legroom options to improve its financial performance. The airline is grappling with revenue declines due to Boeing delivery delays and pricing pressures in the domestic market. Activist investor Elliott Investment Management is advocating for leadership changes to enhance competitiveness.\n\nSouthwest Airlines on Thursday announced sweeping changes, including plans to end open seating and offer seats with extra legroom on its airplanes as it faces pressure from an activist investor to improve financial results. The airline's earnings have been under pressure in recent quarters, partly because of delays in plane deliveries from Boeing, which have hit its revenue and worsened cost pressures. It is also facing pricing pressure as an industry-wide overcapacity in the domestic market has dampened airfares.\n\nThe outlook for the September quarter is not upbeat, either. It expects third-quarter unit revenue to be flat to down 2% year-on-year, while non-fuel operating costs are estimated to be up 11%-13%. TD Cowen analyst Thomas Fitzgerald said Southwest's outlook implies losses in the current quarter and breakeven in the fourth quarter.\n\nSouthwest's shares were up about 1.5% at $27.03 in morning trade. While all U.S. carriers are facing pressure to discount fares due to an excess supply of seats in the domestic market, airlines like Delta and United Airlines are leaning on long-haul international flights and high-margin premium cabins to protect their profit.\n\nSouthwest currently doesn't offer these products. Activist investor Elliott Investment Management is pushing for leadership changes, saying the company needs fresh perspectives to compete in the modern airline industry. It has warned of a proxy fight.\n\nSouthwest said its research shows that 80% of its customers, and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. It also has plans to offer premium, extended legroom seats, which will account roughly one-third of seats across its fleet.\n\nThe company said the new cabin layout will require approvals from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration and is expected to be available for bookings in 2025. \"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said on Thursday.\n\nU.S. carriers have been reporting strong demand for high-margin premium cabins. Alaska Airlines last week said it would add 1.3 million premium seats annually to its mainline fleet. Southwest will also start overnight flights in February.\n\nThe company plans to share more details at its investor day in September. Southwest said it was in discussions with Boeing about the negative financial impact it faces from delayed deliveries. It expects compensation in the form of price discounts.\n\nIts second-quarter adjusted profit came in at 58 cents per share, compared with analysts' average estimate of 51 cents per share, according It also comes with other changes that include options for more expensive seats that offer additional legroom.\n\nSouthwest Airlines says that this change is to encourage customers to fly with it. A study conducted by the airline shows that open seating was the main reason that travelers chose its competitors.\n\nIt will still be some time before Southwest Airlines open seating is gone. That's due to the company not offering the new seating option until sometime next year. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nPeople are also reading... 15-foot shark spotted 20 miles off Sea Isle City Construction has not started yet on new ShopRite in Galloway after four years Hours expanded for Atlantic City stores in high-crime areas, over mayor's veto What type of restaurant would you like to see at the former Tilton Inn site? Holy Spirit hires new girls basketball coach 'Cake Boss' Buddy Valastro expands empire to Atlantic City with new Harrah's spot\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8243069426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:45:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:45:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:44:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://simpleflying.com/southwest-first-ever-overnight-flights/", "title": "Welcome To The Red-Eye: Southwest Schedules Its 1st Ever Overnight Flights", "body": "Summary Southwest has revealed two significant developments: assigned seating and overnight flights. Overnight flights are the focus of this article, with five routes seeing them in February 2025. More routes will have such services in March/April.\n\nMark the date: July 25, 2024. This was when Southwest revealed the end of 'open' seating in exchange for assigned seating. The considerable change, to be operational next year, is all about attracting more passengers and benefiting from their additional revenue. Like other carriers, it will also generate extra revenue by enabling passengers to pick particular seats and extra legroom options. Elsewhere, its first overnight flights have been loaded.\n\nWelcome to overnight flights\n\nSouthwest has not had red-eye flights in its 53-year history, so it has always been highly unusual in the US sky. Indeed, many other US carriers regularly fly overnight, such as American, Alaska Airways, Breeze, Delta, Frontier, Spirit, Sun Country, United, and so on. Southwest will join them in February 2025.\n\nImage: GCMap\n\nWhile start dates and the specific routes and flights are subject to change, searching Southwest's website indicates that the following are available to book as of July 25. Unsurprisingly, they're all longer services to/from some of its major airports that pass various time zones.\n\nLos Angeles-Baltimore: 21:30-05:20+1 (begins February 13) Las Vegas-Baltimore: 22:00-05:30+1 (begins February 13) Las Vegas-Orlando: 22:50-06:05+1 (begins February 13) Phoenix-Baltimore: 23:05-05:10+1 (begins February 13) Los Angeles-Nashville: 23:45-06:00+1 (begins February 13) Image: Southwest Why no overnight flights until now?\n\nWhile Southwest has not had overnight services, it has many departures from 05:00 and many extremely late (or early) arrivals past 01:00. As hard as it might be to appreciate, Southwest couldn't schedule overnight services until 2017 due to its old reservation system.\n\nShifting to a much newer system enabled it, but it has taken years to get to this point. While unconfirmed, it is believed that no contractual problems with pilots or cabin crew stood in the way.\n\nPhoto: Southwest\n\nAircraft on the ground at night enable routine maintenance, keeping things simple. However, this means that Southwest might be somewhat missing out on additional revenue opportunities, which the airline is now evidently keen to pursue, undoubtedly because of its new investor, Elliott Investment Management.\n\nIt should also enable higher aircraft productivity, a meaningful way to reduce seat-mile costs. Indeed, according to the US Department of Transportation Form 41 for Q1 2024, Southwest's block hours per aircraft per day averaged 9.82. It fell from 11.08 hours 30 years ago and 10.93 hours 20 years ago and is about the same as a decade ago.\n\nRelated Long & Short: Top US Airlines Ranked By Average Domestic Flight Length\n\nThis article examines the situation for 13 airlines with 94% of US domestic flights in July.\n\nA few overnight flights won't make much difference, but they are intriguing. Combined with Southwest's new seating policy, it suggests a significant change in mindset. What else will be next? Pay-for checked bags? {"uri": "2024-07-433306734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:49:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:49:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:37:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/finance/companies/southwest-airlines-assigned-seats/2024/07/25/id/1173877/", "title": "Southwest Airlines to Assign Seats to Lift Earnings", "body": "Southwest Airlines Thursday announced sweeping changes, including plans to end open seating and offer seats with extra legroom on its airplanes as it faces pressure from an activist investor to improve financial results.\n\nThe move marks a significant shift away from its traditional business model and came alongside its second-quarter earnings, which topped Wall Street estimates.\n\nSouthwest's shares were down 6% in premarket trading.\n\nThe Dallas-based airline is under pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management, which has warned of a proxy fight to push for leadership changes.\n\nThe company expects the changes to strengthen financial performance. It plans to share more details at its investor day in September.\n\nSouthwest said it research shows that 80% of its customers, and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\nIt also has plans to offer premium, extended legroom seats, which will account roughly one-third of seats across its fleet.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said on Thursday.\n\nU.S. carriers have been reporting strong demand for high-margin premium cabins.\n\nAlaska Airlines last week said it would add 1.3 million premium seats annually to its mainline fleet.\n\nSouthwest reported second-quarter adjusted profit of 58 cents per share, about half of what it reported a year earlier, but managed to beat analysts' average estimate of 51 cents per share, according to LSEG data.\n\nIt reported a 3.8% year-on-year decline in unit revenue in the quarter, citing excess industry-wide domestic capacity. It expects third-quarter unit revenue to be flat to down 2%.\n\nThe airline has been hit hard by Boeing's jet delivery delays and is reeling from elevated operating expenses, including high aircraft maintenance costs, as it keeps older planes in the air.\n\nSouthwest said it was in discussions with Boeing about the negative financial impact it faces from the delayed deliveries.", "source": Southwest also plans to introduce premium seating options on all flights and red-eye flights.\n\n\"While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft,\" the airline said.\n\nSouthwest already unveiled a cabin refresh earlier this year and is in the middle of upgrading its fleet with changes announced in 2022, including in-seat USB charging and stronger Wi-Fi.\n\nSouthwest's new red-eye flights include California options\n\nBooking for the airline's new red-eye flights opened Thursday. The first overnight flights will land next Valentine's Day, in five initial nonstop markets:\n\nThe airline plans to eventually roll out red-eye flights to other markets and offer 24-hour operational capabilities.\n\nSouthwest said the changes are \"designed to elevate the customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive shareholder value\" without sacrificing operational efficiency.\n\nWhere does Southwest fly out of in California?\n\nSouthwest Airlines flies out of several airports in California, including: Los Angeles International Airport, Palm Springs
