{"uri": "8243145039", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:33:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:33:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:32:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_b76defc0-6c78-5bd4-94fe-c1e5cb304c83.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man who had himself banned from Iowa casinos wins jackpot at the Isle Chased out of Buchanan County, Balance music festival coming to Waterloo UPDATE: 69 John Deere Waterloo salaried employees let go Wednesday, 34 in Dubuque Waterloo traffic cameras adjust ticket threshold by 1 mph State: NewAldaya Lifescapes resident suffocated while trapped in bed rails Teen seriously injured in Dunkerton rollover crash Denver girls' track coach fired for unknown reason despite petition from community UPDATE: Man who died in lawnmower accident was Don Bosco teacher College Wrestling: UNI receives major gift toward new training facility Name released in Hudson fatal shooting Neighbors, crews rescue man from sinking vehicle UPDATE: 15 year old injured in reported shooting 2024 Iowa Shrine Bowl: North squad downs South in offensive shootout Waterloo woman who dumped 13 pounds of meth in chase sent to prison 40,000 fish dead on Crane Creek in Bremer County; Iowa DNR seeking answers\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8243334512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:44:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:44:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:44:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/southwest-airlines-abandoning-free-all-boarding-policy-assigned-seats", "title": "Southwest Airlines Is Abandoning 'Free-For-All' Boarding Policy For Assigned Seats", "body": "Passengers familiar with Southwest Airlines know the sometimes chaotic free-for-all boarding policy has been around for decades. However, this policy is ending as the airline plans to introduce assigned seating. The change aims to boost revenue in response to worsening revenue challenges and mounting pressure from an activist investor demanding an overhaul of the airline's leadership and operating strategy.\n\nThe Wall Street Journal reports that Southwest's business model will undergo \"sweeping changes in a bid to broaden its appeal to passengers and boost revenue.\" These changes include ditching the free-for-all boarding policy for assigned seating with premium options and extra legroom.\n\n\"It isn't clear when flying with assigned seats and premium rows will start, but Southwest said bookings for them are expected to begin next year,\" WSJ wrote, adding, \"The exact timing of the changes depend on the airline gaining regulatory approval and retrofitting its planes.\"\n\nAdditional details about the policy shift will be provided to investors in late September. There's also a plan to operate red-eye flights, attracting overnight travelers starting next year.\n\nThe revenue challenges were highlighted in the company's second-quarter earnings report today, with a profit last quarter beating expectations. However, its forward guidance for revenue costs in the quarter was much worse than Wall Street's estimates.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in a statement, quoted by Bloomberg, adding seat changes are a critical move to \"an ongoing and comprehensive upgrade\" to passenger accommodations.\n\nThe airline has faced several challenges, including fewer-than-expected aircraft deliveries from Boeing, a series of safety incidents that prompted a Federal Aviation Administration review this week, and slowing growth. As a result, its shares have fallen nearly 8% this year.\n\nLast month, Elliott Investment Management revealed a $1.9 billion stake in the carrier, calling for leadership to reverse years of underperformance and calling management \"stubborn unwillingness to evolve the company's strategy.\"\n\n\"Southwest's executive chairman and its CEO, who have spent a combined 74 years at the company, have presided over a period of severe underperformance, and they have demonstrated that they are not up to the task of modernizing Southwest,\" the activist said.\n\nSouthwest has said it will examine Elliott's proposed changes: \"The Southwest board of directors is confident in our CEO and management's ability to execute against the company's strategic plan.\"\n\nWhile Southwest was quick to act on reformatting its boarding policy, which could very well attract new customers, we doubt the airline will change the \"bags fly free\" policy - or face a boycott with customers.", "source": {"uri": Revenue per available seat mile, a gauge of airline pricing power, fell 3.8%, roughly in line with the carrier's reduced forecast last month.Southwest reported adjusted per-share earnings of 58 cents a share, above analysts' expectations.\"Our second quarter performance was impacted by both external and internal factors and fell short of what we believe we are capable of delivering,\" CEO Bob Jordan said in an earnings release.Southwest said Thursday that it is in talks for compensation from Boeing as its sole supplier of airplanes struggles to deliver aircraft on time because of its safety and manufacturing crises. Southwest said it continues to expect just 20 deliveries from Boeing this year -- less than half of what it had previously forecast.The airline is in the middle of an overhaul as pressure mounts from investors to do more to increase revenue. Elliott Investment Management disclosed a nearly $2 billion stake in the carrier last month and called for a leadership change.Read more CNBC airline newsSouthwest to get rid of open seating, offer extra legroom in biggest shift in its historyBoeing's missteps have cost it billions. Here's its plan to get back to its gloryDelta says the Olympics will cost it $100 million as travelers skip ParisEarlier Thursday, Southwest announced that it will do away with its open seating plan and offer some seats on its Boeing aircraft that have extra legroom and add overnight flights, the biggest changes to its business model in its more than five decades of flying. The changes, which start next year, would make Southwest more like its network carrier rivals.\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges and implement longer-term transformational initiatives that are designed to drive meaningful top and bottom-line growth,\" Jordan said in the release.Delta Air Lines and United Airlines executives earlier this The airline announced it will change its open seating policy.\n\nTravelers and visitors at the Buffalo Niagara International Airport reacted to the planned changes for Southwest\n\n\"You just get on and get a good seat and you get her early like you're supposed to then you get the better seats,\" remarked Nadine Kramer.\n\nSelecting your own seat has been a very popular Southwest Airlines feature over the last 50 years, but that will soon end.\n\nI informed Kramer from Holland, New York about the change.\n\n\"Oh, I feel bad about that because I know what it's like to be assigned to seat or have that taken away or having to deal with that when you forget it -- so I think that sad,\" Kramer said.\n\nKramer brought Katherine Wahl, also from Holland to the airport. Wahl was getting ready to fly Southwest to South Carolina.\n\n\"And why did you pick Southwest?\" asked Buckley. \"I just heard it was good. I don't know - I just picked it,\" replied Wahl.\n\nWahl got to the airport early hoping to pick a window seat, but says she isn't too picky.\n\n\"Wherever they put me is fine,\" Wahl noted.\n\nSouthwest said the seating change will allow the low-fare carrier to charge a premium for certain seats on its planes, like seats with more legroom.\n\nSouthwest says research shows that 80 percent of its customers and 86 percent of potential customers prefer assigned seating.\n\n7 News Senior Reporter Eileen Buckley learned many travelers out of Buffalo like flying Southwest. Numbers show from July of 2023 to June of 2024, 677,287 passengers departed from the Buffalo Airport.\n\nThat compares to JetBlue, with more than 98,000 passengers out of Buffalo, Delta with over 80,000 and more than 66,000 headed out of Buffalo on American Airlines.\n\n\"Southwest has been our largest carrier for a very, very long time and they are growing tremendously. In fact, next month, the daily services to Phoenix are returning. Last year, daily service to Las Vegas returned. They start a new service to Nashville, so they're really rocking and rolling,\" described Pascal Cohen.\n\nI met with Cohen, senior marketing manager for the airports at the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority, to ask him about the Southwest switch.\n\n\"I think it's good news. I think a lot of people like to know where they're sitting and I think research has shown I mean, Southwest can tell you that directly to people want to know where they're sitting,\" Cohen responded.\n\n\"So, in the future, I'd probably pick a window, but for now doing the checkout and early to get the window seat,\" explained Tim Van Oss.\n\nVan Oss of Buffalo was heading to Nashville and always flies on Southwest because he prefers open seating.\n\n\"I don't really like the board in the group, so I just by the early check in so I don't have to deal with it,\" noted Van Oss.\n\nNo {"uri": "8241960133", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:12:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:12:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:12:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://viewfromthewing.com/southwest-airlines-now-selling-elite-status-hints-at-what-assigned-seats-might-look-like/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Now Selling Elite Status, Hints At What Assigned Seats Might Look Like - View from the Wing", "body": "Through August 22, Southwest Airlines is offering to sell elite status. They will sell you the qualifying points you need to earn elite benefits through December 31, 2025.\n\nSouthwest will sell you up to 35,000 qualifying points, which is the amount required for A-List status. And it's not cheap: up to $2,190.\n\nThis is unusual. Airlines frequently sell loyalty program members the qualifying points they need to make status at the end of the year, so that they can keep their status if they haven't flown enough. And the amounts aren't unusual. American Airlines earns tens of millions of dollars each year doing this.\n\nHowever it's early in the year - just past the halfway mark! - so this isn't taking the place of end of year mileage runs. It's straight up selling the status, seeking cash for the benefits. And it's going to mean more people clamoring for the earliest boarding positions.\n\nThere's a lot of discussion about Southwest Airlines moving to assigned seating as part of offering a new premium product, perhaps with extra legroom and blocked middle seats at the front of the cabin. I'm skeptical that they go entirely in this direction. Those premium seats may be blocked and assigned, but for everything else I think they keep traditional boarding order.\n\nThis offer is suggestive of why! They monetize Early Bird check-in, and they promote early boarding positions as the key benefit of what they are selling you today and that you'll receive through the end of next year. Sure, they could just take your money and not deliver the benefit, or refund your money.\n\nBut if they were to go with fully assigned seats, I don't see that happening before 2026.\n\nBoarding positions will be automatically reserved for you and the Passengers on your reservation 36 hours prior to the flight. You and Passengers on your reservation will still need to check in within 24 hours of scheduled departure to retrieve your boarding passes.\n\nI actually think Southwest's seating model is a core part of their value proposition and I wouldn't eliminate the cattle car boarding. On the one hand it does mean needing to line up half an hour prior to flight (I prefer to wait in a lounge, Southwest doesn't have those) but on the other hand it means that all the 'good seats' aren't pre-reserved by passengers booking weeks or months out. Last minute travelers still have a shot. That makes them attractive for a business traveler.\n\nAnd having status means you're much more likely to have that A boarding position (\"A-List\" status, get it?) and get a decent seat. Even if you change flights at the last minute you still get to board before the B group, along with families. That's not bad.\n\nI'm not sure it's worth the price. That depends how many Southwest trips you'll take. To me, the question is whether the price saves you enough in Business Select fares that come with the best boarding or in Early Bird check-in fees (they don't sell this on all flights). You'll have to decide for yourself.", "source": {"uri": "viewfromthewing.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "View from the Wing"}, "authors": [{"uri": "gary_leff@viewfromthewing.com", "name": "Gary Leff", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwest_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Southwest Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loyalty_program", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Loyalty program"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Airlines", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "American Airlines"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airport_check-in", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Airport check-in"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_reservation", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Indian reservation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boarding_pass", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Boarding pass"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattle", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Cattle"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Travel/Transportation", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming_Out", "label": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming Out", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 76}], "image": "https://viewfromthewing.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/20221130_120719.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9762572", "eventUri": "eng-9762572", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-08-22", "textStart": 8, "textEnd": 17}], "sentiment": 0.09019607843137245, "wgt": 148, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243838642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-26", "time": "00:13:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-26T00:13:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-26T00:12:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/tourism/1st-southwest-redeyes-from-vegas-take-off-in-february-3102168/", "title": "1st Southwest redeyes from Vegas take off in February", "body": "Southwest Airlines will roll out \"redeye\" flights from Las Vegas to Orlando, Florida, and to Baltimore-Washington International Airport in February.\n\nThe Dallas-based airline, the busiest commercial air carrier at Harry Reid International Airport, announced Thursday that the two routes would be among the five that will begin Feb. 14 and tickets are on sale.\n\nA Southwest spokesman said more redeye routes are expected to be unveiled in future months.\n\nThursday's announcement came the same day Southwest announced plans to discontinue its decades-old open seating boarding system. Beginning in February, Southwest will implement assigned seating and premium seating with greater legroom for passengers.\n\nSouthwest confirmed in March that Las Vegas would be among the first Southwest cities to get late-night flights, established to add capacity and generate revenue without acquiring additional aircraft.\n\nWest-to-east late-night flying is popular because passengers from western destinations can arrive in the early morning on the East Coast for breakfast meetings.\n\nThe Las Vegas airport has a history of accommodating late-night flights with its 24-hour environment.\n\nWhen America West Airlines, a predecessor to what is now American Airlines, operated between 1981 and 2007, it used the Las Vegas airport, then known as McCarran International, as a \"night hub\" for late-night flying. Most of America West's flights left Las Vegas after 9 p.m.\n\nContact Richard N. Velotta at rvelotta@reviewjournal.com or 702-477-3893. {"uri": "2024-07-433209946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:25:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:25:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T06:35:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://money.usnews.com/investing/news/articles/2024-07-25/southwest-airlines-beats-q2-profit-expectations-marks-shift-to-premium-seating", "title": "Southwest Airlines Beats Q2 Profit Estimates, Marks Shift to Premium Seating", "body": "(Reuters) - Southwest Airlines beat analysts' expectations for second-quarter profit on Thursday and said it would introduce both assigned and premium seating in its cabins, marking a significant shift away from its traditional business model.\n\nShares of the carrier were up 4.2% in premarket trading.\n\nAirlines are enjoying a summer travel boom, borne out by the fact that more than 3 million people passed through U.S. airport security checkpoints on July 7.\n\nHowever, carriers have increased seats in the domestic market in excess of demand, pressuring airfares at the price-sensitive end of the market.\n\nSouthwest reported second-quarter adjusted profit of 58 cents per share, about half of what it reported a year earlier, but managed to beat analysts' average estimate of 51 cents per share, according to LSEG data.\n\nIt said its unit costs, excluding fuel, were better than expected, due in part to cost mitigation efforts, including voluntary time off.\n\nOn the other hand, demand for premium seats has gone up. Delta Air Lines reported a double-digit increase in revenue from its premium cabins in the second quarter, while sales in its main cabins remained flat.\n\nSouthwest, which lowered its second-quarter unit revenue forecast last month, is also facing pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management, which is pushing for a management and board overhaul.\n\nElliott took an about 11% stake in the carrier and has urged it to consider making commercial changes to its business model, including exploring revenue opportunities such as assigned seats, checked bag fees and premium products.\n\nHistorically, Southwest has shied away from these changes.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges...,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said on Thursday.\n\nThe airline has also been hit hard by Boeing's jet delivery delays and is reeling from elevated operating expenses, including high aircraft maintenance costs, as it keeps older planes in the air.\n\nSouthwest said it was in discussions with Boeing about the negative financial impact it faces from the delayed deliveries.\n\nSouthwest reported total operating revenue of $7.35 billion in the quarter ended June 30, compared with Wall Street expectations of $7.32 billion.\n\n(Reporting by Shivansh Tiwary in Bengaluru; Editing by Pooja Desai)", "source": {"uri": "money.usnews.com", {"uri": "2024-07-433614081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:48:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:48:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:42:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/southwest-scraps-unassigned-seating-50-165842897.html", "title": "Southwest scraps unassigned seating after 50 years", "body": "Southwest Airlines is to allow customers to reserve seats, scrapping the free-for-all of unassigned seating it has operated for 50 years.\n\nThe company said it also planned to charge for \"premium\" seats with more leg room, add red-eye flights, and redesign its boarding system.\n\nThe announcements came as the firm reported that profits plunged in the April-June period to $367m, down 46% compared with last year.\n\nChief executive Bob Jordan said the seating changes would \"unlock new sources of revenue\".\n\nThe company currently assigns passengers to boarding groups based on when they check in, a system intended to help planes turn around quickly. Travellers can also pay extra to board earlier.\n\nBut it said its research had found that 80% of customers preferred assigned seats.\n\nThe airline said it would provide more detail about the changes in September.\n\nThe new red-eye flights will launch next year on five routes, including between Las Vegas and Baltimore and Los Angeles and Nashville.\n\nPremium seats are expected to account for about one third of space, it said.\n\nSouthwest started in the 1970s gaining popularity with lower fares and good customer service.\n\nIt had been known as a holdout in the industry for not hitting customers with extra fees for items such as checked baggage.\n\nBut its share price has dropped sharply over the last few years, as its profitability lags others in the industry.\n\nLast month, Elliott Investment Management, which is known for its aggressive and public showdowns with firms it sees as underperforming, said it had taken an 11% stake in the firm and would push for major changes, including the removal of Mr Jordan.\n\n\"Southwest's rigid commitment to a decades-old approach has inhibited its ability to compete in the modern airline industry,\" Elliott said, adding that the airline \"outdated software, a dated monetisation strategy and antiquated operational processes\".\n\nMr Jordan said he knew that the firm's performance this spring had fallen short.\n\nThe company has been affected by issues such as delayed plane deliveries from Boeing.\n\nThe airline, like others in the industry, is also facing pressure on fares, after overestimating demand for domestic travel.\n\nThe firm said it was cutting back capacity in the months ahead and the seating changes, in the works for months, would also drive improvements. It said the seating changes could generate more than $1bn in revenue.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception... this is the right choice - at the right time - for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" Mr Jordan said.\n\nShares in the firm rose more than 6% after the announcement.", "source": {"uri": "ca.finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! The new, extra legroom seats will be made available on about a third of Southwest's fleet and will be \"in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft.\"\n\nThat rework, which came after the airline's February seat redesign crashed and burned with customers for appearing uncomfortable, still needs to be approved by the FAA.\n\nSouthwest's first overnight flights will launch on Valentine's Day for five routes: Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore.\n\nThe changes come after investors put pressure on the airline to turn a profit in June, CNBC reported.\n\n\"Together, these strategic initiatives play an integral role in the airline's comprehensive strategy to meet Customer needs and enhance Shareholder {"uri": "8243333199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:43:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:43:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:43:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.newser.com/story/353452/big-changes-are-coming-at-southwest.html", "title": "Big Changes Are Coming at Southwest", "body": "Red-eye flights (initially Las Vegas to Baltimore; Las Vegas to Orlando, Florida; Los Angeles to Baltimore; Los Angeles to Nashville, Tennessee; Phoenix to Baltimore) to begin in February\n\nTravelers cited Southwest's model of grabbing any available seat as the top reason for choosing to fly with a competitor, and 80% of Southwest fliers said they preferred an assigned seat. \"Preferences have evolved with more customers taking longer flights where a seat assignment is preferred,\" Southwest said Thursday, per USA Today. With the change, the low-cost airline said it \"expects to broaden its appeal and attract more flying from its current and future customers,\" per CNN.\n\nThe FAA still needs to approve new cabin layouts for the airline's fleet of Boeing 737s, which will extend legroom for a third of its seats. This is \"in line with that offered by industry peers on narrowbody aircraft,\" Southwest said. The change means the airline can charge more for some tickets. Southwest, once the most profitable US airline, reported a 51% drop in profit in the second quarter, down to $370 million, after losses in the last two quarters. The airline said it would provide more details about the changes at the end of September. As of now, there's no sign of change to some of Southwest's most beloved policies, including two free checked bags and no flight change fees. {"uri": "8243144237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:33:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:33:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:32:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/travel/southwest-breaks-50-year-tradition-plans-to-start-assigning-seats/article_171e683c-9530-5661-a29a-fb8bc8195cb2.html", "title": "Southwest breaks 50-year tradition, plans to start assigning seats", "body": "The FAA told Scripps News it has increased oversight of the airline to ensure it is complying with federal safety regulations. (Scripps News)\n\nSouthwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.\n\nThe airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted. The moves could also generate revenue and boost financial performance.\n\nSouthwest made the announcement on the same day that both it and American Airlines reported a steep drop in second-quarter profit despite higher revenue.\n\nAirlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.\n\nSouthwest, based in Dallas, said its second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier, to $367 million, as higher costs for labor, fuel and other expenses outstripped an increase in revenue. The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nPeople are also reading... Crash in Shoshone claims life of motorcyclist Death Notices Death Notices 2 injured after Sun Valley Tour de Force crash A bank collapses on the Snake River near Burley, threatening eagle nest American Legion roundup: Minico B wins state title, Minico A wins district title Twin Falls infant hospitalized after possible drug exposure Ben Gillette powers Minico B back to American Legion state final Death Notices CrossFit Twin Falls -- building hearts, minds and bodies Second time around: Jury finds Kimberly man guilty of video voyeurism Gooding Police Department seeks help identifying subjects Death Notices Elizabeth Boulevard and Hankins Road closed for Hankins Pressure Zone project Gooding's Colston Loveland earns Big Ten Preseason honors\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. But, the airline said, preferences have \"evolved\" -- as more travelers take longer flights, they want an assigned seat.\n\nThe airline is said it will offer redeye flights for the first time.\n\nSouthwest said that its first overnight, redeye flights will land on Feb. 14, 2025 in nonstop markets that include Las Vegas to Baltimore and Orlando; Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. It plans to phase in additional redeye flights over time.\n\nAirfares are down, but baggage fees are up Low-cost airlines are reshaping how we pay for flights The rise of low-cost carriers How to navigate low-cost carrier fees\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-07-433164661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:46:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:46:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:46:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.streetinsider.com/Corporate+News/Southwest+Airlines+reports+Q2+results+ahead+of+estimates%2C+plans+to+end+open+seating/23502257.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines reports Q2 results ahead of estimates, plans to end open seating", "body": "Southwest Airlines (NYSE: LUV) saw its shares slip in premarket trading Thursday despite reporting Q2 earnings and revenue that beat analyst estimates.\n\nThe US carrier posted Q2 earnings per share (EPS) of $0.58, surpassing the consensus estimate of $0.52. Revenue came in at $7.35 billion, also ahead of the consensus projection of $7.32 billion.\n\nStill, the company's shares fell more than 2% in the pre-open trade.\n\nSouthwest reported an adjusted operating income of $405 million, compared to the estimated $334.5 million.\n\nAvailable seat miles (ASMs) were 46.25 billion, marking an 8.6% increase year-over-year and slightly above the estimate of 46.22 billion. Revenue passenger miles (RPMs) were 38.22 billion, a 7.6% year-over-year increase but below the estimate of 38.34 billion.\n\nLooking ahead, Southwest projects ASMs to rise by about 2% year-over-year in Q3.\n\nThe airline also said it is engaged in ongoing discussions with Boeing (NYSE: BA) and anticipates delays in aircraft deliveries, planning for about 20 -8 aircraft deliveries in 2024.\n\nFor Q3, Southwest expects unit revenue to range from flat to a 2% decline year-over-year, with a positive inflection anticipated in Q4.\n\n\"Our second quarter performance was impacted by both external and internal factors and fell short of what we believe we are capable of delivering,\" CEO Bob Jordan stated.\n\nAlongside earnings, Southwest Airlines also announced it is making significant changes to its business model for the first time in 53 years, introducing assigned seating and extra legroom seats to boost revenue.\n\nStarting next year, the carrier will offer flights with extra legroom seats. moreover, the airline will begin overnight flights in February.\n\nMore information about these changes will be shared at the company's investor day at the end of September.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243487077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:43:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:43:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:42:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/national/southwest-airlines-turns-to-assigned-and-premium-seats-to-lift-earnings/article_b9a2365f-777c-50f4-8810-1ef6a7b61ace.html", "title": "Southwest Airlines turns to assigned and premium seats to lift earnings", "body": "(Reuters) -Southwest Airlines on Thursday announced sweeping changes, including plans to end open seating and offer seats with extra legroom on its airplanes as it faces pressure from an activist investor to improve financial results.\n\nThe airline's earnings have been under pressure in recent quarters, partly because of delays in plane deliveries from Boeing, which have hit its revenue and worsened cost pressures. It is also facing pricing pressure as an industry-wide overcapacity in the domestic market has dampened airfares.\n\nThe outlook for the September quarter is not upbeat, either. It expects third-quarter unit revenue to be flat to down 2% year-on-year, while non-fuel operating costs are estimated to be up 11%-13%.\n\nTD Cowen analyst Thomas Fitzgerald said Southwest's outlook implies losses in the current quarter and breakeven in the fourth quarter.\n\nSouthwest's shares were up about 1.5% at $27.03 in morning trade.\n\nWhile all U.S. carriers are facing pressure to discount fares due to an excess supply of seats in the domestic market, airlines like Delta and United Airlines are leaning on long-haul international flights and high-margin premium cabins to protect their profit.\n\nSouthwest currently doesn't offer these products.\n\nActivist investor Elliott Investment Management is pushing for leadership changes, saying the company needs fresh perspectives to compete in the modern airline industry. It has warned of a proxy fight.\n\nSouthwest said its research shows that 80% of its customers, and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nIt also has plans to offer premium, extended legroom seats, which will account roughly one-third of seats across its fleet.\n\nThe company said the new cabin layout will require approvals from the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration and is expected to be available for bookings in 2025.\n\n\"We are taking urgent and deliberate steps to mitigate near-term revenue challenges,\" Southwest CEO Bob Jordan said on Thursday.\n\nU.S. carriers have been reporting strong demand for high-margin premium cabins. Alaska Airlines last week said it would add 1.3 million premium seats annually to its mainline fleet.\n\nSouthwest will also start overnight flights in February.\n\nThe company plans to share more details at its investor day in September.\n\nSouthwest said it was in discussions with Boeing about the negative financial impact it faces from delayed deliveries. It expects compensation in the form of price discounts.\n\nIts second-quarter adjusted profit came in at 58 cents per share, compared with analysts' average estimate of 51 cents per share, according to LSEG data.\n\n(Reporting by Rajesh Kumar Singh in Chicago and Shivansh Tiwary in Bengaluru; Editing by Pooja Desai and Nick Zieminski)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": The airline's robust cost management efforts, such as offering voluntary time off to employees, resulted in unit costs, excluding fuel, being better than expected. Additionally, Southwest plans to introduce assigned and premium seating, aligning with rising demand for premium travel options, evidenced by Delta Air Lines' double-digit increase in revenue from its premium cabins. This strategic pivot aims to capture new revenue streams, while the airline contends with activist investor Elliott Investment Management's push for management changes and new revenue opportunities.\n\nSouthwest Airlines' move towards assigned and premium seating marks a significant shift in its business model, aiming to tap into the higher revenue potential of premium travel amidst a summer travel surge. However, with domestic seat capacity surpassing demand, the competitive pressure on airfares could impact profitability. Investors should watch Southwest's ability to balance this new strategy with market dynamics and cost control, especially given the airline's discussions with Boeing over delayed jet deliveries and elevated operating expenses.\n\nThe bigger picture: Navigating revenue turbulence.\n\nSouthwest Airlines' latest results and strategic changes reflect broader trends in the aviation industry, where demand for premium seating is on the rise despite economic uncertainties. The airline's efforts to manage costs and innovate its service offerings could set a precedent for other low-cost carriers. Meanwhile, pressure from activist investors and operational challenges like delayed aircraft deliveries highlight the complex landscape airlines must navigate to stay profitable and competitive.", The results met Wall Street expectations.\n\nAmerican Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit, to $717 million, and said it would break even in the third quarter -- well below Wall Street expectations for the July-through-September period.\n\nSouthwest has used an open-seating model since its founding, with passengers lining up to board, then choosing their own seat once they are on the airplane. These were, of course, done in an effort to prevent future terrorist attacks.\n\nA few years later, we began to see the rise of the low-cost carriers. Allegiant Air, JetBlue Airways, Breeze Airways, and Frontier, for example. While these airlines may not have had all of the complimentary amenities as the larger airlines, their ticket prices were significantly lower than many other airlines. Additionally, these airlines also frequently offered direct flights from smaller airports to in-demand destinations. Portland to Orlando or Portland to Nashville, for example.\n\nIn 2020, the pandemic caused major issues for many of the larger, more established, carriers.\n\nWhile the roller coaster ride of the airline industry has leveled out, some airlines are still making changes in order to adapt to the current environment.\n\nSouthwest Airlines Announces a Major Change to Its Boarding Process\n\nAccording to an article on WGN's website, Dallas-based airline Southwest has announced a major change to its decades-old boarding process.\n\nFrequent customers of the airline probably know that Southwest Airlines has been using an 'open seating' boarding process. While you still board in groups, just like every other airline, once you are on the aircraft you are able to choose any seat you want. The policy has reportedly been around for over 50 years.\n\nWhile the process does frustrate people who are not used to it, fans of the airline seem to love the concept.\n\nIt appears that the process is going to be changing.\n\nThe article explains that the airline will soon start using assigned seats and will allow customers the option of paying more to choose an aisle or window seat.\n\nThere is no word on when this policy change will start.\n\nThe article also explained that, for the first time, Southwest will begin offering 'redeye' flights in February of 2025.\n\nThe announcement came on the same day that the airline announced a steep drop in profit in Q2. {"uri": "8243436203", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:01:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:01:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:00:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cmj2prz1e28o", "title": "Southwest Airlines scraps unassigned seats and plans 'premium' options", "body": "Chief executive Bob Jordan said the seating changes would \"unlock new sources of revenue\".\n\nThe company currently assigns passengers to boarding groups based on when they check in. Travellers can also pay extra to board earlier.\n\nIt said its research had found that 80% of customers preferred assigned seats.\n\nThe airline said it would provide more detail about the changes in September.\n\nThe new red-eye flights will launch next year on five routes, including between Las Vegas and Baltimore and Los Angeles and Nashville.\n\nPremium seats are expected to account for about one third of space, it said.\n\nSouthwest started in the 1970s gaining popularity with lower fares and good customer service.\n\nIt had been known as a holdout in the industry for not hitting customers with extra fees for items such as checked baggage.\n\nBut its share price has dropped sharply over the last few years, as its revenue growth lags others in the industry.\n\nLast month, Elliott Advisors, which is known for its aggressive and public showdowns with firms it sees as underperforming, said it had taken an 11% stake in the firm and would push for major changes, including the removal of Mr Jordan.\n\n\"Southwest's rigid commitment to a decades-old approach has inhibited its ability to compete in the modern airline industry,\" Elliott said, adding that the airline \"outdated software, a dated monetisation strategy and antiquated operational processes\".\n\nMr Jordan said he knew that the firm's performance this spring had fallen short.\n\nThe company has been affected by issues such as delayed plane deliveries from Boeing.\n\nThe airline, like others in the industry, is also facing pressure on fares, after overestimating demand for domestic travel.\n\nThe firm said it was cutting back capacity in the months ahead and the seating changes, in the works for months, would also drive improvements.\n\n\"Although our unique open seating model has been a part of Southwest Airlines since our inception... this is the right choice - at the right time - for our customers, our people, and our shareholders,\" Mr Jordan said.", "source": {"uri": "bbc.com", This forecast puts Southwest into tough adjustment as it contends with higher expenses and a competitive market that has forced airlines to discount ticket prices during a typically profitable period.\n\nREAD MORE: Boeing Plans Major Overhaul to Rebuild Trust Following 737 Max Crashes That Cost Them $30 Billion\n\nTo hopefully bounce back from this, Southwest is implementing several major changes.\n\nThe airline will eliminate its open seating policy and introduce seat assignments, as well as offer an extra-legroom product starting next year, to increase revenue and align more closely with its network carrier rivals.\n\nSouthwest also plans to add overnight flights to its schedule as part of this overhaul.\n\nThese changes are expected to return what the company had lost as it dealt with delays in aircraft deliveries from Boeing, its sole supplier, due to ongoing safety and manufacturing issues.\n\nMeanwhile, pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management, which recently acquired a nearly $2 billion stake in the company, has intensified calls for revenue growth and potential leadership changes.\n\nCEO Bob Jordan emphasized that Southwest is taking {"uri": "8243580695", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:11:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:11:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:10:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://viewfromthewing.com/southwest-airlines-investor-call-9-game-changing-new-product-updates-for-flyers/", "title": "Southwest Airlines Investor Call: 9 Game-Changing New Product Updates For Flyers - View from the Wing", "body": "Southwest Airlines announced plans for redeye flights, premium seats, and assigned seating but left a lot of questions unanswered.\n\nThey don't know all the answers yet! But during the carrier's second quarter investor call on Thursday they provided more information and filled in several gaps, as well as shared other useful tidbits, that flyers need to know about these changes and the airline's business.\n\nSouthwest is going to sell extra legroom seats, and they're going to do it on the cheap. They're going to sell assigned seats. Somehow they think it makes sense to keep their current boarding process where passengers line up in advance - though of course nobody needs to do this anymore. There's no more incentive, since as long as they offer free bags (and therefore have plenty of overhead bin space) and your boarding order doesn't influence your seat choice you might as well board last.\n\nNonetheless, since they no longer even offer Early Bird Check-in on all flights, it'll be nice to have a seat pre-assigned. That will make the boarding process more civilized. And with one-third of seats extra legroom, there should be enough of those left to buy an aisle or group of seats together on most flights without doing so weeks in advance.\n\nThere's no surprise that this is just an extra legroom product and not a new first class cabin. They won't earn the same revenue premium as some of their peers. There are elements of the plan that'll increase revenue (paid seating) and some that will reduce revenue (no more need for paid Early Bird check-in, and less incentive to buy the highest Business Select fares). (\"Southwest\" or the \"Company\") and its recent revenue enhancement initiatives:\n\nSouthwest's announcement of new revenue-enhancement initiatives, including assigned seating, premium-seating options, and redeye flights, is more than a decade overdue. This comes after a 50% decline in its share price over the past three years. The same leadership team responsible for this decline is now proposing these new measures, despite a history of failed attempts to improve performance, repeated operational missteps, and poor financial results.\n\nToday, Southwest finally acknowledged that the preferences of four out of five customers have gone unmet in recent years. The airline said it will continue to allow passengers to check baggage for free.\n\nThe changes are the result of an 18-month process to make the airline more profitable. \"We are completely focused on our plan to transform the airline, transform our financial performance,\" Chief Executive Officer Bob Jordan said.
